speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as the labour critic for the Liberal Party and following the tragedy at the Westray mine, I have received many letters from the families who have been affected by the events. I would like to read one of the letters. It is from Mr. David Sample, a draegerman:
The inquiry is quashed, the federal government has voted four to two not to investigate the financing into Westray mine. Now the company wants to flood the evidence of the explosion. This reads like a cover-up.
The top seven managers of Westray seem to have all the rights. What happened to the 26 men? Is this of little importance? When they died did their rights die with them? Are other miners going to die because it was or is against some people's constitutional rights to find out the truth?
The wives of our deceased comrades were told in court by Westray lawyers that they have no legal standing as to whether or not the mine should be flooded. If they have no legal standing, who does?
We the miners, draegermen, and the family members will not be pushed aside. We will be heard and will not let this issue go until our questions have been answered.
I ask this House to demand an inquiry into the Westray mine disaster.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in a study on sustainable economic development published in November 1992 the Cornell du Patronat du Quebec asked the federal government to drop a proposal in the 1991 Wilson budget whereby businesses would no longer be able to deduct provincial payroll taxes, which are used to finance health services, and provincial capital taxes from federal corporate income tax.
The Conseil du patronat commented that at a time when the economy is in bad shape, payroll taxes are a particularly regressive form of taxation because they mainly penalize labour intensive businesses. Implementation of this tax measure would inevitably result in a loss of jobs in Quebec.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the public hearings on the North American free trade deal are a complete sham. The government has failed to provide Canadians the opportunity to debate the future of our nation. These hearings have been intentionally structured to limit public debate and scrutiny of this trade package.
At the subcommittee hearings this week in Vancouver participants repeatedly rebuked the government for its blatant attempt to stifle debate and minimize opposition of this deal. Participants did not have time to prepare detailed critiques. They did not have time to adequately present them. They could not even get printed copies of the trade agreement.
During testimony the interpretation by the telecommunications workers' union of a particular chapter arose and, surprise, surprise, committee members could not even get a copy of the agreement to refer to.
During the referendum Canadians demanded opportunities to learn about and participate in purposeful debate. Once again, this government is selling Canadians short by keeping us in the dark on the rewriting of our

December 2, 1992
economic constitution through the North American free trade agreement.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, at the upcoming Council of Europe meeting in Edinburgh there could be a tendency toward reversing the Lisbon decision which states that the Republic of Skopje would not be recognized if it insisted on the use of the word Macedonia as its name.
Macedonia is a Greek name. It has always been part of the history of Greece and of the Greek people. It is not to be usurped by others including the Slavo-Albanian country of Skopje which has neither ethnological nor historical relation to Alexander the Great's Macedonia.
A reversal of the Lisbon agreement would not only be dangerous but would also wound the European Community's credibility and prestige. It would also loosen the solidarity among its numbers and create greater destabilization in the Balkans.
However, the compliance of Skopje with the Lisbon decision not to use the name Macedonia in its name would go a long way toward the establishment of security and friendly relationships between the two countries, Greece and Skopje. Let us hope this will be the case.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this past Saturday, Jill Jackson passed away after a courageous battle with breast cancer. She was 33 years old.
A co-founder of Breast Cancer Action, Jill was determined to do something about this dreadful disease. Those who knew Jill talked about her tremendous energy and optimism, and about her efforts to ensure that the government not only agree with the June 1992 report of the status of women subcommittee on breast cancer but indeed act upon its recommendations.
Jill helped design the ribbon I am wearing today. The tear-drop shape represents the tears shed when we or our loved ones are diagnosed with breast cancer. The rose pink colour represents the 15,000 Canadians diagnosed with breast cancer each year and the black lining is
in memory of the 5,000 women who lose their lives to this disease every year in Canada.
Today across Canada 40 women will be diagnosed with breast cancer and 12 will die. Thus, there are 52 families who are today devastated by this disease for which there is no prevention, no known cause, and for which the treatments currently being offered fail thousands of patients each year.
Breast cancer must be a national priority. In 30 years the probability of getting this disease has risen from one in 20 Canadian women to one in nine.
As Jill said: "The time for action is now".

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, yesterday The Toronto Star announced that a group of women were coming to Ottawa to prevent the Prime Minister from wearing the white ribbon symbolizing the campaign against violence against women. These women claim the government has not done enough to fight violence to earn the privilege of wearing that ribbon.
I would like to ask these women, who intend to invade the private residence of the Prime Minister and his family, where they were when the Prime Minister's own daughter was verbally assaulted in a local rag. Did any of these women come to Ottawa or demonstrate against this kind of humour, which is degrading and humiliating for all women?
Not one.
Before accusing others, these women should make sure their position is consistent. I would urge them to show some compassion and support for their sisters before preaching to their brothers.

speakerposition: subtopic
Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the massive lay-offs at the Lingan and Phalen collieries in Cape Breton have resulted in 1,000 miners out of work just before the Christmas holidays.
December 2, 1992

Given the urgency of this situation, it is absolutely critical that the Government of Canada work with the provincial Government of Nova Scotia and assist the Cape Breton Development Corporation in getting the Donkin coal mine in operation.
As an international coal supplier Devco cannot afford to lose any of its market.
The Donkin mine was launched in 1980 at a cost to the federal treasury of approximately $55 million.
I call upon the minister responsible for the Cape Breton Development Corporation as well as the Minister of Employment and Immigration to open the Donkin mine immediately and to put a program in place to assist the displaced miners who are affected at the Lingan colliery, to clarify immediately when exactly these miners will be in receipt of the unemployment insurance benefits they so desperately need.
At the present time, these workers have been receiving conflicting information with regard to their unemployment insurance.
The situation is critical. On behalf of the miners and their families, I urge the minister responsible to process these claims and get some money out to these men and their families before the Christmas holiday season.
* Sic *

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Minister of State for the Environment has asked me to report to the House an unprecedented event that occurred last week in Aylmer, Quebec.
The federal government's green plan made commitments for protected spaces and species, including the completion of the national parks system by the year 2000 and the establishment of a national wildlife habitat network.
In the spring of 1991 there was a unanimous House of Commons resolution calling on the federal government to consider the advisability of preserving and protecting in its natural state at least 12 per cent of Canada by
working co-operatively with the provincial and territorial governments and assisting them to complete the protected areas networks by the year 2000.
In support of the foregoing and in recognition of Canada's 125th anniversary the Canadian Council of Ministers of Environment, the Canadian Parks Ministers Council and the Wildlife Ministers Council of Canada met jointly for the first time ever.
They supported ratification of the biodiversity convention and agreed on a plan to develop the Canadian biodiversity strategy. They endorsed a statement of commitment to complete Canada's networks of protected areas.
This meeting of three councils of ministers received support in their actions from the Canadian Council of Forestry ministers and representatives of the four major aboriginal organizations in the country: the Inuit Tapiri-sat of Canada, the Assembly of First Nations, the Native Council of Canada, and the Metis National Council.
The recurring theme throughout the session was the emphasis upon the need for co-operation and strong working relationships between all jurisdictions and interested parties.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Canada is again deporting genuine Iranian refugees.
Last year it took a public outcry to prevent the removal of a woman who was flogged in Iran because she did not wear the traditional veil.
Now Caroline Teghisadeh faces removal on December 7 because the IRB disputes her claims of torture and does not consider sex discrimination a ground for refugee status.
Amnesty International, the European Parliament and the United Nations Human Rights Commission have condemned Iran for public flogging and stoning of women in accordance with the Iranian Penal Code.
Sixty-two United States senators have written to the UN Secretary-General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, condemning these gross violations of human rights in Iran.

December 2, 1992
Oral Questions
In view of this public information, I call on the immigration minister to intervene in Caroline Teghisa-deh's case, stop her removal and land her in Canada.
I call on Canada's Parliament to protect women who have escaped from harsh discrimination against their sex.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on Sunday I will be attending a candle light vigil at the Markham Peace Garden. I will be joining Jacquie Cushing-Dill and other people who have organized this annual vigil to honour the 14 women who were murdered in Montreal in December 1989.
All levels of government are working to tackle the insidious and widespread problem of abuse of innocent women. There is, however, much more to be done to alleviate the problem of violent and emotional abuse of women.
As a society, we must have zero tolerance for the mistreatment of women. We must eliminate this problem that touches the lives of so many Canadians.
My dream is that our daughters and granddaughters, the children of tomorrow, will be safer than our wives, sisters, mothers and children are today. We must not leave them with a legacy of brutal pain and violence.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, when the Prime Minister first ran for office, he promised Canadians jobs, jobs, jobs. Elowever, it seems that what he really had in mind were lost jobs, lost jobs and more lost jobs.
In a speech two weeks ago the Prime Minister outlined a number of initiatives which he said would contribute to our prosperity. One such initiative would be to increase the budget of the National Research Council's Industrial Research Assistance Program. He said that this program has been judged an unqualified success especially for smaller firms and that it will be expanded.
This decision while welcome is long overdue. In 1985 the Neilsen report concluded that IRAP worked. Yet since then the program's budget has been frozen, its network of technology advisers cut back, and the real value of contributions to the private sector across Canada has declined by 30 per cent.
Seven years have gone by. Jobs, sales and exports have been lost. This is the real legacy of this government: lost jobs, lost sales and lost opportunities.

speakerposition: subtopic
subtopic: SMALL EXPLORERS AND PRODUCERS ASSOCIATION OF CANADA
SMALL EXPLORERS AND PRODUCERS ASSOCIATION OF CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Small Explorers and Producers Association of Canada represents 300 firms involved in oil and gas exploration and development based in Alberta and Saskatchewan.
This group, known as SEPAC, approached the Progressive Conservative Alberta caucus some time ago with a proposal designed to help small operators take advantage of current changes in the upstream energy business. Alberta MPs worked closely with SEPAC to refine these proposals.
We are talking here about firms with from one to ten employees which are part of the entrepreneurial small business backbone of the nation. These are the kinds of businesses led by men and women who are not afraid to take risks which will generate jobs for Canadians, generate wealth for a nation, and help lead this country into a strong and resilient recovery.
My colleagues from Alberta and I call upon the Minister of Finance to respond positively to these proposals in his comments later today.

speakerposition: topic
subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Justice.
As we approach the third anniversary of the Ecole Polytechnique massacre we must recognize that our gun control laws are still seriously inadequate. Last year the number of Canadians killed with hand-guns doubled from the previous year.
December 2, 1992

Last week the mayors of Canada's largest cities recommended that the regulations on hand-guns be substantially tightened. They made specific recommendations including an operational principle that when in doubt officers issuing gun permits should say no.
To respond to the 80 per cent of Canadians who want better protection against firearm violence, will the minister implement the excellent recommendations made by Canadian mayors last week?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think the comments made by the mayors and in fact their ongoing contribution to this file have been very constructive and very helpful.
With respect, I think the measure they are recommending to be put in place can quite properly be put in place by the provinces. It is not something that requires legislative change. In fact it is not something that really lends itself to a legislative or regulatory formulation although I am happy to examine that.
It is my view that it is more properly within the domain of the provinces. I am quite prepared to raise that with my provincial counterparts when I meet with them about a month from now.

Mr. Speaker, the minister is quite correct in that this is a regulatory or administrative matter, and I would appreciate her taking some leadership.
The three handguns used in killing four professors at Concordia University last August demonstrate the continuing weakness of our present laws. Two of those hand-guns belonged to the killer's wife who obtained them for target shooting and then gave them to her husband. The third belonged to the killer who had also been issued a permit, although he had been refused on two previous occasions. Concordia University had warned the police about his threats.
Is the minister satisfied this is the best we can do in preventing violence with guns? There is overwhelming evidence that where guns are less available there is less crime with guns.

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as the hon. member will know, not all of the legislation and regulatory
Oral Questions
measures that this House has worked so hard in creating have been fully implemented.
The provisions with respect to the new firearms acquisition certificate and the capacity for very intense screening there, for example, will come into force on January 1.
What I am trying to do as a first priority is to get all those provisions implemented so that the gun control regime in Canada is what Canadians think it is, so that it corresponds exactly to what they have read about in Bill C-17 and its regulations. At that point I am very happy to look to see if there are other things we might do to make the system work better.
I know the hon. member would agree from his long experience with this file that it is an ongoing issue that has to be dealt with in the light of changing aspects of Canadian society. I will certainly continue to address it as minister.

Mr. Speaker, according to a recent study 47 per cent of women murdered by their husbands were killed with a firearm, and 70 per cent of those firearms were legally obtained by these criminals.
Is the minister satisfied with this intolerable situation? Can she give us one good reason why an ordinary citizen who is not a policeman or a member of the armed forces can legally own and use a revolver? If not, why will the minister not accept the excellent recommendations made by the mayor of Montreal and other Canadian mayors?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if I am not mistaken, the mayors did not recommend an outright ban on hand-guns. I agree that firearms are a problem where family violence is concerned.

In my opinion the provisions we have put into the legislation dealing with peace bonds and bail hearings in order to provide powers for the courts to make prohibitions of the possession of firearms in any circumstance, particularly the circumstance of domestic violence where somebody is seeking a restraining order or peace bond, I

December 2, 1992
Oral Questions
think will go a very long way toward taking firearms out of those very dangerous situations.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is also for the Minister of Justice. The minister will know that youth crime has increased by 20 per cent in the past five years and in fact youth violent crime has doubled in that same period.
The minister has for more than a year been speaking with attorneys general across Canada to develop some changes to the Young Offenders Act. She promised that we would have these changes by September. It is now December and these amendments have not been brought forward. When is the minister going to bring forward much needed amendments to this very important legislation?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a source of regret for me in this file and a number of others that the business of this House and the business of the government were interrupted by the referendum process, a necessary process but one which unfortunately drew attention away from some of the other ongoing files we were dealing with.
Obviously there is very little time left in this sitting to enable us to do this, but I hope in the spring to be able to do this. I will be announcing in coming days a very important national consultative process with respect to community safety and crime prevention that I hope will contribute measurably to the quality of what we bring forward with respect to young offenders and other issues concerning the safety of Canadians in their communities.

Mr. Speaker, with all due respect, we have been waiting two years for these amendments. While we did have the referendum with which to deal the House was not sitting and surely that would have given the department more time to work on this.
Also the important initiative the minister talks about is in March. If that was an excuse, which it is not, then that initiative would certainly be more relevant if they had something to consider.
We should not have to wait till the spring for these important changes. Canadians are concerned that they are losing the fight against crime. They want to be able to protect their homes and their streets. When is the minister going to realize that and do something to bring forward more meaningful legislation to deal with this problem?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I will bring forward measures for this House to consider as soon as I am convinced I have measures that are the best considered and the best reasoned measures that will actually do something to change the situation in Canadian society and not simply satisfy those with an urge to make rhetoric on that subject.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I understand that later this afternoon the Minister of Finance will make an economic statement to this House. Certainly Canada is in great need of hope when we see
1.6	million unemployed, 2.3 million people using food banks, and one in six of Canada's children living in poverty.
There is a tendency to blame the Minister of Finance for this solely, but a disastrous record like this takes a team effort to achieve so I would like to ask the Minister of Transport a question.
He will understand, I am sure, that the economic base of any country is an adequate transportation system to move our goods not just north and south, as his policies seem to indicate, but east and west and to the north.
When is the Minister of Transport prepared to bring forward a policy on transportation for this country not based on the crisis of the day, on the airlines, or on wiping out jobs in the rail sector, but a real transportation policy for this country on which the economic base can be built?

speakerposition: Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I believe our transportation policy does provide that the transportation industry must give Canadians a system that is effective, reliable, competitive and safe.
December 2, 1992

Mr. Speaker, it is clear the Minister of Transport does not have a vision for transportation in this country.
I would like to direct a supplementary question to the minister of trade. There is no doubt about the results of the Canada-U.S. trade deal. The statistics indicate that we have 350,000 more people out of work. There are plants closing and there are many effects of the trade deal on Canada. Yet the minister persists on proceeding with taking Canada into a NAFTA deal, taking the bad Canada-U.S. trade deal and making it worse. This is a strategy which is designed to move jobs out of Canada and to make it more accessible simply for capital.
When is the minister of trade prepared to bring in a trade policy based on job creation, not job loss?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am surprised my hon. friend would ask that question. Yesterday the House in a resounding fashion approved the trade policy of this government which is to bring in the free trade agreement and then the NAFTA.
If my hon. friend would read the speech that I made in the House yesterday she would see that I said the exports to the United States as a result of the free trade agreement had resulted in an increase in exports this year of some 10.5 per cent. I do not know what sort of arithmetic my hon. friend would use if she cannot translate that 10.5 per cent increase in exports this year over last year and the $16 billion plus that we have had since the free trade agreement came in.
Every billion dollars of increased exports represent
15,000	new jobs. That is 225,000 new jobs. That is a job creating trade policy.

Mr. Speaker, I would suggest that Canadians are much less interested in reading the hon. minister's speech than they are in having jobs. If the minister would go across this country he would see the job loss and the devastation being caused in this country because of the trade deal.

I have a supplementary question for the Acting Prime Minister. The Prime Minister told us that the basic
Oral Questions
elements of his economic plan are in place. The Minister of Transport says that deregulation is working. The minister of trade says that free trade is working. My question is: If all these things are working well, where are the jobs?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if the hon. member noticed, there has been growth in job creation in six of the last seven months. Full-time jobs are being created though not at the pace we would like them to grow.
I want to remind the hon. member of a number of things. "Canada is seen leading the G-7 growth" and "Economy starts to speed up", those are the kinds of stories that are happening now as a result of some of the measures we have taken at the federal level.
Later this afternoon the Minister of Finance will deliver an economic statement that I am sure in one hour's time the hon. member will be applauding.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs.
Dr. Stephen Schondelmeyer, a world renowned economist, testified:
The cumulative cost of Bill C-91 from 1993 to year 2000 will be
$4 to $7 billion for each and every penny coming from the taxpayers
and health care systems in Canada.
How can the minister possibly pretend that he is protecting Canadian consumers when he is nothing short of an accomplice in a $7 billion drug heist?

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre Blais (Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is surprising that the opposition parties, which are always against free trade and the North American agreement, have used two Americans, one yesterday and another one today, to give Canadians a lesson.
In fact the Canadian system in place since 1987, with the foundation we put in place, lets Canadians have drugs for a third less than the Americans pay.

December 2, 1992
Oral Questions
What we have maintained with our very strict controls on drug prices will be reinforced as a result of the new powers being given to the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board, which means that from now on controls will be even tighter.
In the United States, the Americans are looking at setting up a system like ours, including a drug prices review board, and appropriate legislation is now being considered. I invite the Americans to keep looking at what we are doing and benefit from our experience.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is for the Minister for International Trade. In exchange for giving $7 billion from the health care system in Canada this government has received only vague and unenforceable promises of some future investment by these multinational companies.
Why has the Minister for International Trade caved in to the multinational drug lobby in Washington, and why is a Canadian minister more concerned about the profits of these companies in Washington than he is with the integrity of the Canadian health care system?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend is wallowing in such an incredible amount of misinformation about this legislation with his use of that $7 billion figure. He knows that the experts from the Department of Industry, Science and Technology have refuted that figure and last night gave the committee point by point reasons why that $7 billion figure is totally out of reality.
My hon. friend has not referred to this, but we also tabled last night a study which stated that the increased cost of the drugs would be $129 million over a five-year period.
Just to give my hon. friend some sense, and you, Mr. Speaker, about some of the-
Oh, oh.

speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
I just wanted to make sure I was addressing the Chair. There is an article in The Toronto Star today by Dalton Camp. He refers to increases in drug prices on about half a dozen drugs. Not
one of the drugs mentioned is subject to patent protection. All of them are off patent protection.
That is the difficulty we have in getting the true message out about why this legislation is good for the country, will create jobs, create research and development and will result in protection on price.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, according to the terms of the loan agreement between the government and Canadian Airlines the government has demanded of Canadian Airlines that it restructure its finances, meet with the government and with Air Canada, and permit a representative of the government to sit in on its board meetings.
My question for the minister is this: What is the government doing to address the structural problems in this industry that prevent the companies from being profitable?

speakerposition: Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we have been very clear on this. A certain number of the problems experienced by our airlines over the past few years are exactly similar to the problems experienced by all airline companies around the world.
I mentioned in my statement last Thursday that we are examining the possibilities to make sure that after Canadian Airlines has restructured we will be in a position to put in place some calibration of the situation so that we can maintain a viable airline industry in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, if the minister thinks that the problems of the airline industry are going to be self-correcting he should not have put taxpayers' money at risk.
The minister talks about-and he used the word again today-recalibrating the regulatory framework. When is he going to stop using this bureaucratic mumbo-jumbo and translate it into plain language and real action?

speakerposition: Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, again the hon. member, I presume not deliberately, is trying to mislead the Canadian taxpayers by saying that we have put money at risk. He pretends that he has seen the loan conditions. If he has seen the loan conditions he
December 2, 1992

should be telling the Canadian taxpayers that their government has taken care of their interests.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Agriculture.
This year a lot of the grain produced on the prairies was frozen. Farmers are having difficulty with crop insurance because the value of that frozen grain is only about 60 per cent of what the coverage level was. The farmers have mostly produced the right volume; it is only a grade loss crop insurance should be paying. Crop insurance is offering 17 cents when the loss is more like 40 cents.
Can the minister report to the House any progress he has made in getting that loss ratio more realistic than what crop insurance is offering.

speakerposition: Minister of Agriculture
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as the hon. member knows, and I agree it was and is a difficult year in grain production, one province removed protection for revenue insurance. Other provinces, Alberta and Manitoba in particular, have that protection. Each province has a contract that has a formula for assessing the quality loss under crop insurance.
The province of Saskatchewan put forward a suggestion that we change that contract retroactively. It would cost the Government of Canada some $60 million and the Government of Saskatchewan, $20 million. Saskatchewan also suggested that we should pass that on to the farmers in the form of higher premiums over a number of years.
I remind my colleague that not all farmers in Saskatchewan have suffered a quality loss. We have attempted to work with the province of Saskatchewan. I will provide $40 million in a yield protection program if the province will join us in making a contribution so that we can assist the producers in Saskatchewan. Alberta and Manitoba producers do not appear to have the same problem.

Mr. Speaker, a short supplementary.
Oral Questions
The minister will know that very little of Manitoba's crop was frozen. Alberta still has the problem. The crop insurance program is what we are talking about. That was not changed by Saskatchewan.
The minister should remember that these farmers, most of them in northern Saskatchewan received the frost but it did go into the south, have been paying their premiums for years and years and watching the benefits of those premiums go south into the drought zone. This is the first year most of these people have had a loss. They will barely collect their premiums back and he is telling us this is fair.
The only loss they have, and it is not going to change the loss register for those farmers a great deal, is on the yield. It is not a huge loss to the whole program but it is about $20 an acre or more to each of them. They have been paying assiduously into the program and never taking anything out of it. The first year they need insurance the minister disappears on them. Why does he not change it and make sure that 100 per cent of coverage is paid when they have 100 per cent loss? He is reducing it by $20.

speakerposition: Minister of Agriculture
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member suggests that there were not any changes in crop insurance from 1991 to 1992.1 would suggest to the hon. member that going from 100 per cent coverage under GRIP down to 80 per cent coverage under crop insurance is a dramatic change.
Contracts were sold with a formula for quality insurance in crop insurance. I have offered, with the province of Saskatchewan, another way of addressing loss. The province of Saskatchewan is suggesting the way to address loss is to have us retroactively change the contract formula again and the federal government provide $60 million and the provincial government provide $20 million.
I am prepared to discuss changes with the provincial government so that the producers in Saskatchewan can have a program that gives them insurance and protection when they need it.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Associate Minister of National Defence.

December 2, 1992
Oral Questions
The minister's advisory board on women in the Canadian Forces reported last week saying: "Harassment has been reported by women everywhere in the Canadian Forces". Is the minister, at the very least, prepared to implement the recommendations of that board today?

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to thank the members of that advisory committee. I specifically asked them to look into the issue of harassment, not just sexual harassment but broader issues relating to personal harassment and abuse of power. Their recommendations are going to be very helpful to us.
We have already put in place a number of changes that respond to those recommendations and over the coming months we will be addressing the majority of them.

Mr. Speaker, the women in the Canadian forces and women across Canada need something a little more concrete than that. To quote from the report itself: "The message that sexual harassment is unacceptable still has not been effectively transmitted to all male personnel after three years of a policy that clearly does not work".
Will the minister tell us what she plans to do? Does she plan to implement these recommendations or does she have another plan of action that will deal this dreadful situation a death blow and stop the at least 40 phone calls a day I have been getting from women in the Canadian Armed Forces?

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I can assure the hon. member that the Chief of the Defence Staff has recently sent out a message to all armed forces personnel dealing with the issue of sexual and personal harassment, indicating this is not acceptable and that we are taking strong measures to deal with it.
Some of those measures include mandatory education for all of our personnel within air command and the establishment of independent assistance, people to whom personnel can go to lay a complaint. It is dealing
with a whole new policy which we are bringing forward in terms of enforcement and monitoring.
There are major changes taking place that are going to ensure that women and all members of the armed forces can operate in an environment that is free from all forms of harassment. Our goal is zero tolerance and we are going to achieve it.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Minister of Public Works.
All traffic lanes over the Lockport, Manitoba, lock and dam will be closed January 4. That closure would mean certain decimation of the business community of Lock-port and threaten over 400 jobs.
To prevent this disaster emergency repairs are needed now. It was understood that repairs could be made immediately if the province of Manitoba committed itself to negotiate with Ottawa on the federal divestiture of the bridge and dam.
I would like to ask the minister whether Manitoba has made this commitment.

speakeroldname: Hon. Elmer M. MacKay (Minister of Public Works):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation; Minister of Public Works
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we had the privilege of meeting with the Minister of Highways for Manitoba, Mr. Driedger, and other important officials from his province. I understand there will be a meeting taking place tomorrow with my colleague the minister of energy and the premier.
I can assure him that ongoing discussions are taking place. The preliminary engineering work is being done and I think we can reach a mutually satisfactory arrangement soon.

Mr. Speaker, a supplementary question. As far as we are concerned, Manitoba has already made its commitment and we are asking the minister to live up to his.
I have a letter which states that Manitoba is willing to consider federal divestiture and that it has promised to enter into meaningful negotiations, as requested by the federal Minister of Public Works. To me, Manitoba has met its commitment and repairs should now proceed. I ask the minister again, will he keep his commitment?
December 2, 1992

speakeroldname: Hon. Elmer M. MacKay (Minister of Public Works):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation; Minister of Public Works
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I do not think there is any question about us keeping our commitment. Of course we will. However, I have just told my colleague that there will be talks going on tomorrow and that preliminary engineering work is going on. I see no basis, frankly, for the tenor of the question at this time.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Justice. Canadians everywhere are constantly sickened by the stories of sexual abuse of children. There is strong evidence all over the place that sexual abusers manifest these deviant tendencies very early in their lives and that most of these behaviour patterns are well set by the time the abusers reach their adolescent years.
It is also very evident that adolescent perverts or deviant sex offenders feed off pornography. I would like to ask the justice minister today just what steps we are taking to completely stop child and kiddy pornography and what has happened to Bill C-51 that was passed a few years ago to deal with pornography.

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am not sure whether the hon. member means Bill C-51 or Bill C-15 relating to the sexual abuse of children.
I think it is Bill C-15, which was legislation proclaimed in 1988 which created new Criminal Code offences relating to the sexual abuse of children. Part of that legislation called for a review five years later. The Standing Committee on Justice and the Solicitor General is reviewing that legislation now. I am looking forward to its report on whether it has been implemented in any province. It may suggest new legislative initiatives.
With respect to child pornography, the hon. member will know that the Butler decision of the Supreme Court of Canada held that even explicit sexual representations that would not normally be considered pornographic would qualify as the undue exploitation of sex if they employ children in their production. That has expanded the scope of the existing law which referred to child
Oral Questions
pornography. I am now examining provisions I would like to go into the Criminal Code to make possession of such pornography an offence in and of itself.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister for International Trade. Regarding the elimination of interprovincial barriers to the free movement of people and goods, despite the failure of the Charlottetown constitutional accord the minister said that he intended to pursue the objectives set out in that accord and to eliminate trade barriers by 1995.
Will the conference this week in Toronto of the minister's provincial counterparts be exploratory or will it make decisions on eliminating certain trade barriers? Also, could the results of this conference have an effect on labour force mobility and therefore influence the conference of employment ministers on labour force training in January?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my colleague is correct. We are going to be having a meeting starting tomorrow with the Federal-Provincial Committee on Internal Trade to study this very issue.
I think the issue has a good deal of support among the provinces as well as many in the private sector. Our approach tomorrow is not necessarily to reach decisions. Where we can I hope that we will, but our approach is to try to see whether there is a way of dealing with the comprehensive nature of these interprovincial barriers and to deal with them within the time frame that the first ministers have indicated this past month that they would like us to.
On the question of labour mobility, my guess is that there would be some limited discussion on this but certainly no decision making and nothing that would conflict with decisions or considerations at the meeting in January.

December 2, 1992
Oral Questions CANADA POST

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister responsible for Canada Post and it is in relation to Canada Post communication plans on regional postal outlets.
The document talks about putting service at risk in rural areas, reducing many small businesses postal revenues by up to 13 per cent and 300 businesses refusing the new arrangements while others will go under.
Why in these tough economic times is Canada Post hurting small businesses and putting service at risk in many rural areas?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am not sure what document the member has but I can assure the House that Canada Post is continuing with its program of opening some 6,000 new retail postal outlets to better serve its customers. Indeed, there is a line-up of applications from small businesses desiring to have a postal outlet in their business because it attracts customers to their store. It is something on which surveys by the post office have indicated a 90 per cent approval rating.
I am not sure why the hon. member would be opposed to something approved by 90 per cent of the users and for which small businesses are literally knocking on the door to have.

Mr. Speaker, it seems to me that the minister is closing his eyes to the reality of the situation.
My question is for the same minister. According to Canada Post's own discussion paper, by making retail postal operators responsible for their own inventories and freight costs this policy will lead to the elimination of up to 300 of these independent retail operators and drastically reduce incomes of the survivors.
Since the government knows that small business creates most of the new jobs in Canada, why is it allowing Canada Post to proceed with a policy that will force retail outlets out of business while increasing the financial
hardships for small businesses, particularly in rural communities where service will be cut?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am sorry, service will not be cut. Obviously, the member had his question prepared before he heard my answer to his colleague.
The post office is opening 6,000 new postal outlets and small businesses are literally knocking on the door asking to be included. There is no question that the nature of some of the operations is being changed. If the hon. member has checked into any of these new franchise operations he will see that they have changed physically. They are much more attractive, and customers to the tune of 90 per cent plus like the new system.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Solicitor General and it concerns RCMP recruitment policies.
In his 1992 report, the Auditor General criticized these policies saying: "We estimate that training and salary costs were almost $2 million for members who left the force during 1989 and 1990 for reasons such as poor interpersonal skills, immaturity, lack of assertiveness and low learning ability".
What specific actions is the RCMP taking to correct these inefficient and costly recruitment procedures?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I am appearing in the House today on behalf of my colleague, the Solicitor General. I think a question of that sort is a question that is more appropriate for me to take on notice on behalf of the Solicitor General who will provide an answer to the hon. member at the earliest convenience.

Mr. Speaker, I thank the hon. minister for her undertaking.
The Auditor General has also recommended that the RCMP require applicants to know first aid, swimming, CPR, computer skills and take some basic college courses before they are accepted for basic training. He has stated that this measure could save Canadians
December 2, 1992

between half a million and one and a half million dollars in training costs.
I would ask the hon. minister to inquire as well whether the RCMP is going to implement these costsaving measures. If so, when, particularly in view of these tough economic times?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, particularly in light of the statement to be made today by the Minister of Finance, I know my colleague the Solicitor General would be grateful for any recommendations to reduce costs in the RCMP.

speakerposition: subtopic
Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Acting Prime Minister.
In the role of the Prime Minister as the minister responsible for the conflict of interest code, the Prime Minister's own appointee in cabinet in the other place has confirmed the hiring of a lobbyist on contract for the government at the same time as the lobbyist in question was lobbying the government on behalf of the communications giant, Unitel.
This is in clear contravention of the conflict of interest rules and the Treasury Board guidelines. I want to ask the Acting Prime Minister: What does the Prime Minister intend to do to ensure that his appointees in cabinet respect his own guidelines?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the conflict of interest code is applicable to public office holders, not to contractors of the government.
However, as a matter of practice, professional service contracts in these circumstances normally contain a clause requiring those engaged in the course of carrying out the contract to conduct themselves in accordance with the principles of the conflict of interest code. Such a clause was included in the contract with N. J. Jamieson Strategic Consulting. There is nothing to suggest any of the code's principles have been breached in this circumstance.
Oral Questions

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I hope the minister will table that document.
I want to ask a supplementary in response to what he has said. I quote here from the contracting manual of Treasury Board: "The particular clause must be included in every contract for the services of an individual 'Personal Services Contract' in regard to conflict of interest". Therefore, the conflict of interest code does apply. It says so in the minister's own rules.
What is this minister and what is this government going to do to ensure that the rules are obeyed for once?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, as I said in my answer to the first question, such a clause was included in the contract. There was no breach of the rules whatever, no breach of the conflict of interest guidelines.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to address my question to the minister responsible for inland waterways and fisheries.
The minister is aware of the proposal by the Government of Ontario to situate a huge mega dump to take all of metro Toronto's garbage in Georgina. The proposed site is located on prime agricultural land less than two kilometres from the shores of Lake Simcoe. Besides its devastating impact on the environment this proposal would also have a very negative effect on tourism in the area.
The underground and surface water from this area flows directly to the delicate, sensitive spawning grounds in the lake. Will the minister assure this House that a federal evaluation will be undertaken and that every possible effort will be made by the federal government to stop this proposal and eliminate the potential risk of destroying the fish habitat in this federally regulated, highly crucial body of water in southern Ontario, Lake Simcoe?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I suppose we will be lucky if, by the time the Government of Ontario is finished, the whole province is not a megadump.

December 2, 1992
Oral Questions
With respect to the hon. member's question, I know the hon. member is very concerned about preserving the purity of the site in question. I am advised that when the final selection of funds is made it is going to be submitted to a full environmental review by the province of Ontario.
As we all know, when the NDP is out of power it is a tremendous exponent of environmental reviews. So I do not see how the Government of Ontario could fail to have an environmental review. When it does, we will be vigilant under the Fisheries Act to ensure that there are no negative impacts on fish or fish habitat.
We will certainly do our duty. I thank the hon. member for keeping us informed of what is happening in his area. We shall certainly do our best to stop Ontario from becoming a mega dump.

speakerposition: subtopic
N.D.P. Caucus Chair
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans.
As the minister knows, the B.C. salmon catch was half the average of the past three years. The canning season was the worst in decades, the pink run came in $13 million below expectations and the Fraser River was closed three weeks early. Some 1,500 fishermen, shore-workers and tendermen do not even qualify for UI.
Elas the minister considered offering for the west coast a program in terms similar to his November 25 Atlantic emergency response for UI qualifications?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as you know, when necessary there is an emergency response failure program that can go into effect to deal with catch failure situations.
There has been no catch failure situation in British Columbia this year, thank heavens. Although this is a low cycle year, I believe it is the best year in 80 years in a low cycle year, particularly with reference to the sockeye salmon.
There has been no fishery failure. There is a problem that certain workers did not get the necessary 17 weeks work which they need to qualify for UI in the lower
mainland because of the lower unemployment rate there.
Since there is no indication of catch failure in any of the four major Pacific fisheries I believe that the conclusion is that there can be no emergency response program. That situation is not comparable at all to the situation on the east coast of Canada where there have not only been catch failures but no fish at all, in connection with the northern cod moratorium.

speakerposition: N.D.P. Caucus Chair
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, with answers like that, they will consign the large portion of the Tory caucus to that mega dump.
The Pearse-Larkin inquiry into the alleged disappearance of up to 1.2 million Fraser River sockeye was due to report to the minister by November 15 last. Can the minister assure the House that the report will be made public and made available to the fisheries committee prior to the proposed rising of the House on December 11?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, with reference to the report of Dr. Pearse and Dr. Larkin, it has been received and is, of course, now being translated.
The report is a first-class piece of work in my opinion. It certainly explains what happened with respect to the Fraser River this summer.
I intend to be in Vancouver on Monday at which time the Pearse-Larkin report will be made public. Dr. Pearse and Dr. Larkin will be available to answer questions, as will I. I will give the reaction of the Government of Canada with respect to their report. I think the hon. member will find it a very interesting report.
The situation, of course, is not nearly as bad as had been painted during the summer. Nevertheless, there are steps to be taken to ensure that nothing of this sort occurs again next year.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Agriculture.
December 2, 1992

The minister knows that tens of thousands of farmers are facing the worst cropping conditions in a generation. For instance, 90 per cent of Ontario's corn crop is still in the fields and this is December.
Is the minister willing to respond to the representations he has received from the Ontario Corn Producers and other groups to provide interest-free cash advances up to 50 per cent for unharvested grain, the same as grain in a bin?
Is the minister willing to provide this assistance to these producers who are facing a most desperate situation this fall?

speakerposition: Minister of Agriculture
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I recognize the difficulties my colleague brings forward. We have had discussions with the Ontario Corn Producers. As my colleague knows, in the prairie cash advance payments program there is recognition for unthrashed grain left in the field after November 15. There is a cash advance that can be made on unthrashed grain.
Unfortunately, we do not have legislation under the Advance Payments for Crops Act for Ontario that is equivalent. I am working to try to have equivalency through the commodity group, the Ontario Corn Producers, that would provide equal opportunity for those producers who have not been able to thrash their grain, but yet still encourage taking grain off if possible.

speakerposition: subtopic

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I would just like to comment on a statement by the New Democratic Party.
It was complaining that a text is not available for the NAFTA. I would like to advise the House that since the House leader of the New Democratic Party raised this point in the House texts are available through Info-Export for anybody in the House or others who wish one.

I thank the minister very much for his action.

speakerposition: subtopic
N.D.P. House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is my pleasure to present a petition on behalf of a number of constituents.
The petitioners point out that agricultural goods are included under the FTA. They also point out that section
22.01	indicates that water is in fact a clear element as part of the FTA agreement on which NAFTA is based. They point out that from their determination NAFTA includes FTA and FTA includes water as part of the trade deal.
Therefore, they are asking the Canadian government to reintroduce legislation that would prohibit the transfer of inner basin water to the United States.

Madam Speaker, I would like to present a petition signed by a number of constituents. They point out that Canada ratified the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and has a moral obligation to seek the elimination of child poverty in Canada.
The petitioners go on to say that the success of political commitment to eliminate child poverty in Canada requires public commitment and initiative among broad sectors of the Canadian population at local and national levels.
They call on the government to take the actions necessary to reaffirm its commitment to seek the elimination of poverty among children in Canada by the year 2000 and to develop a plan for the implementation of this commitment.

Madam Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36, I also have the pleasure of introducing a petition before this House which calls upon Parliament to take the actions necessary to reaffirm its commitment to seek the elimination of poverty among children in Canada by the year 2000 and to develop a plan for the implementation of this commitment.

speakerposition: Liberal Party Caucus Chair
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I have the pleasure to present three additional petitions, three of many that have come from my riding of York West, which address the drug plague that is unfortunately in the middle of communities in Toronto and across the country.
The petitioners call on the government to amend the Narcotics Control Act so that all the assets that are seized from drug seizures not only flow back to general revenues in Ottawa, but are shared with front-line operations like police forces and local organizations which are on the front lines of that battle in the hope that we will win the war.

Madam Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36, I welcome this opportunity to table a petition on behalf of the Armenian community in my riding and also on behalf of other residents of Montreal, Laval and Pointe-Claire. Further to a resolution passed by the Quebec National Assembly to acknowledge the importance of the anniversary of the Armenian genocide, the petitioners humbly pray and call upon Parliament to urge the government to express its sympathy to the Armenian people, and especially to Canadians of Armenian origin who servived the genocide of April 24, 1915, and to support interna-
December 2, 1992

tional pressure on the Turkish government to acknowledge the events of April 24, 1915.

Madam Speaker, I have a petition from a number of constituents.
The petition notes that Bill C-91 seeks to end the licensing of further no name generic drugs in Canada and also will allow brand name drug companies patent protection for up to 20 years. It also notes that Bill C-22 which allows 10 years of patent protection has already driven up prices of drugs to individuals and provincial and private drug plans.
They therefore call upon Parliament not to proceed with Bill C-91 and to repeal Bill C-22 passed in 1987 so that Canadians will have the full benefit of lower priced generic drugs and so that provincial and private drug plans can serve Canadians without being forced to charge higher fees or provide less coverage.

Madam Speaker, a second petition notes that at the present time the Income Tax Act allows self-employed professionals and business people to make deductions for operating expenses and the improvement of their offices or businesses, but unfairly refuses to allow teachers deductions for the expenses which they incur in order to better their teaching abilities.
They therefore call on the Minister of Finance and the Minister of National Revenue to amend the present Income Tax Act to allow teachers and educational institutions to deduct the cost of their expenses in the course of their employment.

Madam Speaker, I would like to table a petition from residents of Val-d'Or, Amos, Vassan, Sullivan, Val-Senneville and Saint-Ed-mond-d'Abitibi, stating that films depicting violence on television are dangerous and unacceptable because they encourage further violence.
Routine Proceedings
They also point out that all toys that are an incentive to violent games are unacceptable and that production of such toys should be banned. Freedom of the press should be restricted when reporting acts of violence. The repeated reporting of acts of violence on all television channels and on radio may encourage similar acts of violence.
Therefore the petitioners humbly pray and call upon Parliament to pass legislation dealing with the above, to wipe out violence in our society, protect our children and guarantee everyone in this country a better quality of life.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: The hon. member for Ottawa Centre.

Madam Speaker, this petition concerns refugees who are suffering from personal economic hardship. Many of these refugees come from unstable Third World countries and they are trapped in the immigration processing backlog.
These petitioners are calling on Parliament to urge the government to exercise compassion and step up its action on refugee cases.

Madam Speaker, I have another in a long series of petitions. This one is signed by residents throughout British Columbia and Alberta who are concerned about the proposal by Multinational Resources to dam a portion of the flow of the North Thompson River and to divert that water through the Columbia River system into the California market.
These petitioners urge the government to state categorically that it will not permit our freshwater rivers to be dammed and diverted into the U.S.A. or into Mexico. It asks the government to state categorically that Canadian waters are not for sale.

Madam Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36, it is my pleasure to present a petition signed by 111 people in the Trinity- Spadina area and nearby who are concerned with many of the proposed amendments to the Immigration Act in Bill C-86. In particular, they strongly oppose the provisions that allow decisions to be made retroactively. This would cause many individuals and families who have already relied on earlier decisions to be affected in a serious manner.

December 2, 1992
Routine Proceedings
Therefore, the petitioners call upon Parliament to urge the government to withdraw these amendments.

Madam Speaker, I have a further petition from 59 people in the Toronto area who are very concerned with some of the decisions being rendered by the refugee board.
The petitioners point to UN decisions and UN guarantees of refugee status determination under the UN Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which requires that their rights be guaranteed without discrimination.
In accordance with UN principles, they call upon Parliament to enact legislation which would provide a meaningful appeal on the merits for refugee claimants whose cases are rejected so that they have appeal rights comparable with everyone else in Canada.

My final petition, Madam Speaker, is from over 30 people who are concerned that there may be too long delays for people who are detained by immigration authorities. The petitioners ask for legislation which would provide for a detention review by an adjudicator within 48 hours, and with two further reviews conducted at least once in each of the next seven day periods and thereafter at least once every 30 days so as to ensure that no one is detained without unequivocal proof that he or she is a danger to the public or would not appear for immigration proceedings.

Madam Speaker, the petition I am presenting today concerns Corrections Canada's announcement that one of four new prisons for women will be in the Kitchener-Waterloo area. I must say thousands of people have signed this petition.
The petitioners protest this decision primarily because of the failure of Corrections Canada to consult with the immediate community where that prison is going to be located.
They call upon Parliament to urge the government to move the proposed women's correctional facility to a location that will provide a more harmonious existence between any community and this particular correction
facility. I will repeat that there are thousands of signatures of people who will be directly affected by the location of this prison.

Madam Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36, it is my duty and pleasure to present a petition from a number of people throughout British Columbia and Alberta, and as a matter of fact from Ottawa, Ontario.
These people have one thing in common. They are all concerned about the intention of diverting waters from Canada into the United States, and particularly the North Thompson River diversion and the U.S. proposal under the North America Water and Power Alliance to divert Canadian waters into the United States and northern Mexico.
The petitioners are asking the government to make very clear its position that it will not allow the diversion of freshwater rivers into the United States or the damming of these rivers for diversion and to indicate to everybody that freshwater rivers are not for sale.

Madam Speaker, I have petitions from the communities of Bruno, Wakaw, Cud-worth and surrounding districts which point out that poverty of Canadian children will yield ever-increasing costs to the administration of health care, justice and social welfare, and poverty among children inhibits learning and preparation for employment constituting a cost to future national productivity.
The petitioners point out that Canada ratified a United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and has a moral obligation to seek the elimination of child poverty in Canada and calls upon the government to develop such a plan for immediate implementation.

Madam Speaker, I have a petition signed by over 600 people from my constituency protesting the introduction of Bill C-91, the drug patent bill.
The petitioners are appalled that this government
would be ramming through a bill which will cost Canadian consumers, particularly the sick, at least $6 billion
December 2, 1992

over the next 10 years in exchange for some vague promises of a few jobs in a few places for a few people.
Therefore, the petitioners call upon parliamentarians to not proceed with Bill C-91 and to repeal Bill C-22 passed in 1987 so that Canadians will have the full benefit of lower-priced generic drugs and so that provincial and private drug plans can serve Canadians without being forced to charge higher fees or provide less coverage.

Madam Speaker, this government likes to brag about what it is doing for rural Canadians with respect to postal service and it is saying that rural Canadians appreciate that service. Well, that is not the case.
Certainly not in the town of Outlook, Saskatchewan, in my riding, where approximately 150 people have signed this petition because they are upset with Canada Post's policy of only providing residents of rural communities free delivery at the post office nearest to their place of residence. They say that this ignores the fact that for many rural residents the nearest post office to where they live may not be the easiest post office to travel to and may not be in the community where they conduct their other business.
They say this is a ludicrous policy. It does not cost Canada Post any extra money to allow people to go to the post office of their choice.

Agreed.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance) moved
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
that Bill C-98, an act to provide additional borrowing authority for the fiscal year beginning April 1, 1992, be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Economics envelope.
He said: Mr. Speaker, this afternoon our country and this Parliament open an important debate on the future course of economic policy. In these times of challenge

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
and opportunity, it is most appropriate that full discussion be undertaken by all members of this House.
Parliament is where the diversity and complexity of Canada are brought together in one place by the representatives of the people from every region. This is where differing political and philosophical approaches can be put forward for public consideration.
Over the next two days I expect all members opposite to state clearly and directly what their proposals for economic policy would be. Canadians expect this of us and they deserve no less.
For my part, I will make it abundantly clear where the government stands. I will provide to the House and to the country an update on Canada's fiscal and economic situation, and I will announce a number of measures to contain the deficit and to enhance economic recovery.
This debate occurs at a time when our economy is undergoing profound change. A new economy is emerging around the world, offering new opportunities that require adjustment and restructuring.
In this environment, Canadians are seeking greater security and greater economic opportunity, for themselves and for their children. That is the overriding goal of our economic policies.
Our economic policy is to build confidence, enhance growth, create jobs, and help Canadians adjust to this period of transition and take advantage of new opportunities.
All of our efforts have been directed at investing in growth through sound monetary and fiscal policies, the opening up of markets, streamlining government, building the skills of Canadians, and encouraging private sector enterprise and initiative as the basis for economic progress.
In response, Canada's economy performed particularly well from 1984 to the onset of the recession in 1990. We led the G-7 in job creation and were second only to Japan in economic growth. However, our most recent economic progress has been slowed by a stubborn worldwide recession, and world recovery has been weakened by economic restructuring, excessive debt, and trade uncertainties.
All this has contributed to a painful adjustment which has slowed world economic growth from 4.3 per cent in 1988 to only 1 per cent this year, the lowest rate of growth the world has seen since 1982.
Canada is not immune to these realities. Next to Germany we are the major industrial country most dependent upon exports. When world growth slows, when commodity prices fall, when world unemployment increases, Canadians cannot escape these consequences.
As a result, far too many Canadians are without work. Far too many others fear for their future as economic restructuring takes place around the world. We need to act to restore confidence and to rekindle hope.
There are those who would have us believe that an economy weakened by too much government debt can be strengthened by creating even more government debt. This approach was wrong in the 1970s. It was wrong in the 1981-1982 recession. It would have been wrong last February. And it would be wrong today.
The simple fact is that large government deficits, federal and provincial, and high foreign debt limit our room to act.
We must act responsibly. That does not mean that we cannot respond. The essence of governing is choosing. There are choices to be made and we are prepared to make them in the best interests of all Canadians.
To make intelligent choices, we must face facts. We must deal with the world as it is, and not as we might wish it to be. We must recognize that globalism is a fact of life. This increases our choices in the goods and services we buy. It increases our opportunities in new markets that we can sell to. But it also increases our interdependence and our competition.
In this increasingly interdependent world countries that turn inward and cling to the old ways of doing business will finally have no future.
The new world economy brings intense pressure to compete. Those who can, will prosper. Those who cannot, will stagnate.
This is not an ideological statement. It is a fact. Some may think that competition is a dirty word, but if we fail
December 2, 1992

to recognize reality we will miss new opportunities. We will sit on the sidelines while the world marches forward.
It is because Canadians can compete and win that we have a duty to encourage that competition. If we face facts, realistically, pull together, and address our challenges head on, we will continue to grow and to prosper.
As I have made clear, this government is not prepared to sacrifice steady, responsible progress for quick fixes that promise relief today at the price of misery tomorrow.
Canada's experience has clearly demonstrated that higher spending and greater deficits will not create lasting jobs. They lead only to higher interest rates in the short term and higher taxes down the road.
Our government will continue to work to put in place a sound fiscal structure and to address the issues of productivity and competitiveness. This is the approach that was recommended by the private sector task force on prosperity.
We will achieve this by continuing to invest in growth on behalf of all Canadians. We will continue to invest in policies to make our economy work better. We will further strengthen our investment in people. We will make additional investments in public infrastructure and we will continue to invest in open trading markets. We will continue to invest in sound monetary and fiscal policies, and we will invest in partnerships for growth with the provinces, with labour and with business.
These kinds of investments take time to bear fruit. They are not easy, change never is. However, there are pay-offs and they are starting to appear. At 1.4 per cent, we have the lowest inflation rate among the G-7 countries this year.
With productivity up by 2.6 per cent so far this year we have made major gains in controlling costs, and this improves our competitiveness. Our trade performance is showing the results. Canada's merchandise trade surplus, one of the keys to reducing our current account deficit, is up by almost $2 billion from last year.
We all recognize that recovery from the 1990-91 recession is painfully slow, not only here in Canada but around the world. Therefore, I expect average growth
Government Orders
this year to be about 1 per cent. We know that we cannot have a powerful recovery when world growth is stagnating, but our investments in growth are positioning Canada for renewed world growth.
Some of the encouraging signs are as follows: real output increased by 1.4 per cent in the third quarter of 1992; domestic demand, including consumer spending, housing and investment in machinery and equipment, has increased by about 5 per cent; the composite leading indicator continues to improve; employment has increased in five of the last six months; consumer confidence is rising-it has now reached its highest level since the fourth quarter of 1989; real exports are up by more than 6 per cent over the first three quarters of this year; and exports to the United States are at record levels, up by 10.5 per cent this year over last.
However, we must interpret these signs cautiously. The world economy is still going through a difficult period. The recent instability in financial markets will hurt Canada's fourth quarter growth numbers. However, as the fundamental strengths of Canada's economy become more apparent the exchange rate should become less at risk and interest rates should come down considerably during the course of 1993, with short-term interest rates averaging about 6 per cent over the year.
