Our improved competitive position, the easing in interest rates that our excellent inflation performance permits, a pickup in the U.S. economy, and the measures that I will announce today will contribute to stronger growth next year. I expect average growth of about 2.5 per cent for 1993.
I expect inflation will remain below 2.5 per cent in
1993.	I expect improved employment prospects with an increase of about 300,000 jobs over the course of the year.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Hear, hear.

speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I now wish to turn to a number of measures that I am proposing to assist economic recovery and invest in economic growth.
One of the things that we will continue to do is to make government leaner and more efficient. We have made government smaller and more supportive of the private sector in a number of important ways. For example, government operating costs after inflation are

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
more than 20 per cent lower than when we came into office.
In the last budget 46 agencies, commissions and boards were eliminated or restructured. The Prime Minister has instructed all ministers to identify further candidates for action by February 1993. Since 1985 we have dissolved 14 Crown corporations and undertaken 23 privatization initiatives, and we intend to proceed with further privatization.
We have deregulated critical economic sectors to increase competition and we are modernizing all federal regulations. We are eliminating those that no longer serve a public policy purpose and we will streamline others so that they will not stifle creativity and efficiency.
Agriculture Canada, Transport Canada and Consumer and Corporate Affairs Canada were directed to review and publicly justify their regulatory regimes in the last budget. All three found ample room for improvement, and as an example Agriculture Canada reviewed 58 sets of regulations. Fifteen were eliminated in whole or in part, four are being sunsetted, and 38 will be modernized. Building on this result the Treasury Board has announced that 19 other departments, along with six agencies, will complete their own reviews by April 1993. What we are seeking in all of these areas is a lower-cost, more efficient government that can work in partnership with the private sector to benefit and serve all Canadians.
I now turn to tax reform. An important part of modernizing and streamlining government has been to modernize our tax system. For the long-run competitive health of our economy our single most important tax reform initiative has been the replacement of the outdated and economically destructive manufacturers' sales tax with the GST. The old tax favoured imports, hurt Canadian exporters and penalized new business investment. The GST has helped our manufacturers and our exporters.
The Canadian Manufacturers' Association reports that the GST has saved its members $3.5 billion. This is important assistance to activity and jobs in difficult times. The Canadian Exporters' Association reports that the tax has improved our competitive position. This has contributed to our strong export position. Major retailers
have confirmed that the prices of the majority of their goods dropped after the introduction of the GST.
The GST is not raising more revenues than the old tax. By law every penny of net GST revenue goes to the Debt Servicing and Reduction Account, where it can be used only to pay the interest on the debt and ultimately to reduce our debt. We are continuing to work to simplify the GST. Last week my colleague, the Minister of National Revenue, announced changes to streamline the administration of the GST. I will soon be announcing further measures to make the tax fairer and easier to comply with.
The government will also act to ensure that those who owe tax-both sales tax and income tax-make their payments, and do so in a timely way. We will give careful consideration to the Auditor General's recent comments in this regard.
Sales tax harmonization represents a major opportunity to reduce the burden of government on the private sector, particularly on small business. I therefore urge my provincial colleagues to join with me in a renewed effort to align our sales taxes, not only with each other but with the reality of the tough, competitive world in which our business people must operate.
I now turn to the small business sector. Small businesses are the primary engine of employment growth. Between 1979 and 1990 small business created more than 2 million full-time jobs. This is more than 80 per cent of the total created during that period. Over-all, Canada's federal tax system for small business is one of the most favourable in the world. Compared to the United States our tax rates are lower, our R and D incentives are more generous, and our taxes on dividends and capital gains on investments in small businesses are much lower.
Yet today the small business community is undergoing serious financial and competitive pressure. Much of this pressure, as I indicated before, comes from the need of the provincial and federal governments to get their act together, whether it is on the GST, other taxes, government spending, or regulation. Some small businesses are finding that the over-all regulatory and tax environment is friendlier south of the border and we must deal with that.
The fact is that much of what needs to be done to address this problem is in the domain of provincial and municipal governments, but the federal government can
December 2, 1992

do something and we will assist small business where we can.
Therefore, I am proposing today a small business employment and investment package to help small businesses across the country modernize, attract financing, grow and create jobs.
For the next year I am proposing that most small businesses increasing employment will be able to do so with no increase in unemployment insurance premiums. New businesses starting up in 1993 will pay no UI premiums in that year. This assistance will reduce the cost of additional employees by up to $1,600 each. It will be delivered in a simple way with a minimum of paperwork. More than 900,000 firms, indeed 95 per cent of all firms in Canada, will be able to benefit from this measure. The government, not the UI fund, will finance this measure.
I am also proposing a new 10 per cent investment tax credit for small business. It will apply to investments in machinery and equipment for small businesses engaged in manufacturing, construction, farming, fishing, mining, oil and gas and long-haul transportation. It will apply to investments made after today and before 1994.
I am also announcing measures to help small businesses secure financing. In the February budget I proposed that the ceiling for loans to individual businesses under the Small Businesses Loans Act be doubled from $100,000 to $200,000. I am announcing today that this ceiling will be further increased to $250,000. As well, the government will work to broaden the application ol the act to include some forms of working capital.
I am also announcing changes to simplify and expand investment in small business by RRSPs and Labour-Sponsored Venture Capital funds.
The Small Business Financing Program announced in my budget last February will be extended for two more years until the end of 1994. This provides low interest commercial financing for viable small businesses in difficulty. I am serving notice to Canada's banks that I expect them to make a special effort to play a constructive role in ensuring the success of this program.
Government Orders
We all know that small and medium-size businesses play an important role in Canada's home building industry. In my last budget I introduced a home buyers' plan to allow Canadians to use RRSP savings to help buy homes. This program has been an unqualified success, generating economic activity in all regions of Canada.
More than 130,000 withdrawals have been made under the plan. I am announcing today that in view of the positive response I am extending the plan for another year.
I am also announcing measures to assist activity in the resource sector. The first $2 million of Canadian development expense by junior oil and gas companies will be treated as Canadian exploration expense for the purpose of flow-through share financing, raising its write-off rate from 30 per cent to 100 per cent. This will be a welcome measure.
Changes will also be introduced to benefit the mining sector. New mines or major expansions of existing mines are now allowed to fully recover their capital investment before paying any federal income tax. The Income Tax Act will be amended to provide more flexibility for mining and oil and gas companies to utilize their noncapital losses. These measures will help to put Canada's small businesses in a better position to meet their competitive challenges, to grow and to create jobs.
I now turn to research and development. The Canadian Manufacturers' Association recently noted: "The next ten years will bring about more changes in the way business is done than we have seen in the past 50 '.
Therefore effective R and D will be a key to successfully meeting the challenges of the next decade and the next century. Canada now has more generous tax incentives for R and D than any other G-7 country. In my last budget I proposed to improve them even further, after consulting with R and D performers.
I am today announcing changes to allow the tax rules to better reflect how R and D is actually performed in the business community. As indicated in the February budget, they will provide additional support of $230 million over the next five years to Canadian companies undertaking research and development.

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
In addition, there are several other areas where the tax system can be modified to help Canadian businesses adapt and grow. Some problem areas have been identified.
The first is the tax treatment of equipment, such as computers, that becomes obsolete quickly due to rapid technological change.
Second, the ability of some firms to use their R and D investment tax credits fully.
Third, the ability of Canadian firms to gain access to new technologies.
Fourth, tax based impediments to growth of small innovative companies.
These concerns have been raised in our discussions with the business community as part of the prosperity consultations. In consultation with industry, we will examine modifications to address these areas in the coming months and actions will be announced in the budget. I have set aside $400 million over the next five years to finance changes to address these issues.
In addition, funding will be increased for the highly successful Industrial Research Assistance Program which provides technology support and financial assistance to businesses. My colleague, the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology, will also be taking steps to streamline delivery and ease of access to federal technology programs and services.
Funding will also be extended for long-term research, building on the best of the results achieved under the networks of the Centres of Excellence Program, a very good program I might add.
We will strengthen our investment in people.
In a world where capital, information, goods and even services flow easily across national borders a nation's competitive advantage is increasingly being found in the skills of its people.
As has been recently noted, nations once competed for control over natural resources. Today they compete to produce the best educated labour force.
Keeping up with this competition is a major challenge. In one generation, Canada's young people have been exposed to more scientific and technological advancement than their parents or grandparents in their entire lifetime.
We have invested in skill development and training by setting up the Canadian Labour Force Development Board and by refocusing the UI system from passive income support to active skill building.
The $3.5 billion we spend on training and adjustment does make a real difference to the lives of hundreds of thousands of individuals across the country.
Our programs have helped individuals cope with change, while assisting the adjustment to new opportunities. A good example of this is the Northern Cod Adjustment and Recovery Program. The collapse of the northern cod stock in Newfoundland required a moratorium on fishing to rebuild the stock for future years. Over 20,000 Newfoundlanders were affected. The government is responding by supporting incomes in the short run, by helping individuals build new skills so that they can become self-reliant, and by helping restructure the fishing industry to put it on a sustainable basis.
As the Prime Minister recently announced, support for the Unemployment Insurance Development Uses Fund will increase to more than $2.2 billion next year from $1.9 billion last year and from a level of $500 million in 1990. This fund invests in people by helping them to upgrade their skills. This program has been a real success story. This year 450,000 people will benefit from the program. This will increase to more than 500,000 next year. The additional funds will be used to provide special services to workers who lose their jobs after a long-term attachment to the labour force.
I am announcing further measures today that will strengthen our investment in people and the future of this country.
To lay the foundation for a stronger training culture in this country we need the joint commitment of employers and workers to develop training strategies. To facilitate this the government will make funding available to help create permanent skill councils in particular sectors of the economy. Priority will be placed on the important task of developing occupational standards so that training will be more relevant to industry's needs. Government funding of $250 million over five years will be used strategically to lever a national private sector driven effort. The government will develop tax incentives to
December 2, 1992

help defray the costs of training workers to meet these occupational standards.
My colleague, the Minister of Employment and Immigration, will be elaborating on the government's labour market initiatives later in this debate.
We will make additional investments in public infrastructure.
The quality of a nation's infrastructure can provide an important competitive advantage in the new global economy. Highways, rail lines, air services, communications and information systems can become critical factors in location decisions.
Further strategic investment will be undertaken in all regions to strengthen our national transportation systems and communications networks. In order to ensure work begins in 1993 the government will commit $500 million over the next two years to a strategic investment program.
Federal assistance will be provided for an immediate start on priority highway projects in New Brunswick and Nova Scotia. With the co-operation of these two provinces we anticipate a significant beginning can be made toward the development of the Atlantic expressway.
Advanced engineering and environmental work on the Prince Edward Island fixed crossing project will be undertaken to allow construction of this $800 million project to begin in the spring. This will directly create an average of almost 1,000 jobs each year over the construction period and will provide enormous spin-off benefits for the economy of Atlantic Canada.

Federal bridges in Montreal will be upgraded. In addition, funding will be made available for co-operation with the Government of Quebec on strategic improvements to the highway system in that province.

Federal roads and roadworks in western Canada's national parks will be upgraded.
Grade separations and other investments will be undertaken to improve the efficiency and safety of our national rail system, particularly in southern Ontario.
Government Orders
Air navigation systems across the country will be improved. The federal government will provide resources for early procurement and the first phase of installation of microwave landing systems in Canadian airports.
Airports in the north will be improved.
The Prime Minister recently announced the government's commitment to developing one of the most exciting and most important infrastructure projects: a high speed national electronic highway. The government will set aside funding for the Canadian Network for the Advancement of Research, Industry and Education project, which will use fibre optics to allow the rapid exchange of vast amounts of information among Canada's scientists, engineers and educators. It will expand Canada's technological capabilities and benefit many sectors in the Canadian economy.
Over the next five years this initiative will result in investments in national infrastructure of more than $2 billion. It will directly generate 4,000 to 5,000 jobs each year.
In addition, we are ready to proceed with a successful proposal to upgrade terminals 1 and 2 in Toronto using private financing. This project will be undertaken at a pace which will not undermine the airlines' effort to return to profitability. This project is expected to create between 2,000 and 3,000 direct jobs each year throughout construction. My colleague, the Minister of Transport, will be providing further details on this important initiative.
We will continue to invest in broadening trade opportunities.
As we in this House all know, trade is our lifeblood. Exports generate 30 per cent of Canada's economic activity and account for one in four jobs. Our ability to trade successfully makes us a wealthier country, with greater choices available to Canadians.
Broadening our trading opportunities requires improved access to markets, under clear and fair rules.
The Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement has proven a success. Canadian exports to the U.S. have increased by $16 billion since the FTA was introduced and are now at record levels. This strong export performance was achieved in spite of slow growth in the U.S. economy and a strong Canadian dollar.

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
The free trade agreement is providing opportunities for the industries of the future.
A recent study by the C. D. Howe Institute showed that Canada's export performance was strongest in those sectors which the FTA has already liberalized, with big gains in high-tech machinery and equipment and other value added products. Exports of manufactured products outpaced exports of resource based products, leading the C. D. Howe study to conclude that "many of Canada's manufacturing sectors seem to have performed remarkably well in the U.S. market under the FTA".
I am reiterating and strengthening our commitment to open trading markets.
The North American free trade agreement improves and strengthens the free trade agreement. It also gives Canadian exporters better access to the important Mexican market of 85 million consumers. We will take early action to introduce implementation legislation for the North American free trade agreement.
The GATT Uruguay round is one of utmost importance to Canada and to the world. The OECD has estimated that the reforms envisaged in the Uruguay round would eventually lead to annual income gains for the world economy of $250 billion. We can share in that economy and so it is important that this be proceeded with.
To protect our competitive position we must seek to lower costs wherever possible. One way we can do this is by lowering tariffs on goods that we import. In response to the recommendations of the Canadian International Trade Tribunal, I am announcing that the government will reduce textile tariffs effective January 1, 1993, bringing them more in line with those of other industrialized countries.
We will continue to invest in sound monetary and fiscal policies as the only basis for sustainable economic growth.
Not so long ago Canada had one of the highest inflation rates among the G-7 countries. This year we have the lowest rate. This means that the prices of goods and services we buy are rising more slowly than in other leading industrial nations. And that is excellent news for the Canadian economy.
Low inflation protects people's purchasing power. Here is an example: Between 1980 and 1984 food prices
rose about 8 per cent per year. This meant that a basket of groceries cost 40 per cent more in 1984 than in 1979. From January to October of this year the price of food has risen by only 0.8 per cent. At this rate it would take 40 years, not 4, for a basket of groceries to increase by 40 per cent.
Another example: Low inflation protects those on fixed incomes. A pension of $10,000 would be worth only $4,420 after 20 years of inflation at 4 per cent. With 1 per cent inflation it would be worth almost $8,200.
It is very clear our own history and experience in other countries demonstrate that there is no lasting trade-off between higher inflation and a strong economy. Nor is there a relationship with lower unemployment. While it takes time to adjust fully to a low inflation economy the continuing benefits make it one of the best possible investments in our economic future.
Our investment in price stability is paying off. Canadian interest rates moved down from a peak of 14 per cent in May 1990 to under 5 per cent in September as inflation and inflation pressures were reduced. These rates were among the lowest in the industrialized countries. Among the G-7 countries only the United States and Japan had lower rates.
Since September uncertainty in markets and downward pressure on our currency have pushed up interest rates, but they remain well below historical peaks. Continued good inflation performance is the clear basis for lower interest rates, and as pressure in the currency market subsides we should be able to achieve these lower rates.
Excessive government deficits, both federal and provincial, have contributed to a level of net foreign debt far higher for Canada than for any other G-7 country. This large net foreign debt, public sector and private sector, means that Canadians paid more than $22 billion in net interest last year to foreign lenders. That is money that Canadians cannot use to develop our own economy. This adds to the economic damage done by the higher interest rates and higher taxes that result from higher government deficits.
Lowering government deficits means that more of Canadians' savings are available for private investment. It means we can invest in our future without mortgaging it to foreign lenders. The way to reduce deficits is by controlling spending, not by raising taxes. Now is not the
December 2, 1992

time for any government to raise taxes. Canadians can make better, more productive use of their money than governments can. The more we can leave in people's pockets, the better it will be for our economy. That is precisely why I cut spending in the February budget to reduce the personal income surtax by 2 per cent: 1 per cent last July, and a further 1 per cent on January 1,
1993.
This measure will add $1.8 billion to Canadians' disposable income this year and next. The January decrease will proceed on schedule, as will the reduction in the manufacturing and processing tax rate, from 23 per cent to 22 per cent. In total, the measures announced in February's budget will provide a timely stimulus of about $2 billion in tax reductions to support economic activity over the coming year.
We also took steps to provide additional assistance to lower and middle-income families with children through the new Child Tax Benefit program. Beginning in January, this initiative will provide $2.1 billion in additional assistance to families over a five-year period. This means, for example, that a working single parent with two children and an income of less than $20,000 will receive about $600 in additional assistance.
Consistent with this over-all approach, I am announcing today that the 1993 unemployment insurance premium rates for employers and for employees will be held to their 1992 levels.
We will manage spending to stay within the Spending Control Act limits. This will allow us to reduce the slippage in the deficit resulting from weaker revenues and to finance the additional investments in growth that I have announced today.
We have to keep our spending in line with our incomes. When our credit card bills get too high we have to cut back on our current spending. For Canada, the objective of this restraint is to preserve for the long term the benefits that we have all gained and continue to gain from this great land.
We are not cutting simply for the sake of cutting or because we think Canadians have not made real sacrifices. We know they have and we know that these cuts will require further sacrifice. We are asking everyone to
Government Orders
do a bit more so that a stronger recovery and sustained growth can be shared by all Canadians.
For the current fiscal year, operating budgets of all departments are being cut by a further 2 per cent. This has resulted in many departments imposing a hiring and discretionary spending freeze.
I am also asking my colleagues to reduce the spending on their grant and contribution programs for the balance of the year where possible. Over the balance of this fiscal year, and the next two fiscal years, almost $8 billion will be cut in a broadly based expenditure restraint program.
Expenditures for a wide range of programs will be either frozen or reduced from planned levels. Let me elaborate.
Salaries will be frozen for the Governor General, the Lieutenant Governors, the Prime Minister, ministers, members of Parliament, senators, the federal judiciary, public servants and the employees of non-commercial Crown corporations for the next two years. Commercial Crown corporations will be asked to keep their wage settlements in line with this policy. In addition, appropriation-dependent corporations will be funded as if their wages were frozen.
Government operating budgets will be reduced by 3 per cent as of 1993-1994. Including the savings from the salary freeze, operating costs will be 5 per cent lower than planned levels in 1993-1994 and 1994-1995. These reductions are on top of the many operating cost reductions implemented over the last eight years.
Average unemployment insurance benefits will also be frozen. To do this, the UI benefit rate will be reduced for new beneficiaries from 60 per cent to 57 per cent in April
1993.	The effect of this reduction will be to freeze the average benefit per recipient.
As well, persons who voluntarily quit their jobs without just cause or lose their jobs because of their own misconduct will no longer receive UI benefits.
Grants and subsidies to most organizations and interest groups will be cut by 10 per cent in each of the next two years.
Some programs will be exempted. These will include programs for the elderly, the guaranteed income supplement, spouse's allowance, programs for the disabled, war veterans' allowance, and veterans' disability pensions.

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
Canada will not reduce its famine relief around the world.
In addition, I wish to inform the House and my provincial colleagues that no further restraint will be imposed upon major federal transfers to the provinces. These programs are already covered by the expenditure control plan introduced in the 1990 budget and extended in the 1991 budget.
The actions I have announced today will bring the estimated deficit down to $34.4 billion this year and $32.6 billion next year. The slippage relative to the February 1992 budget is largely due to the shortfall of revenues caused by a weaker than anticipated economy.
With the actions announced in this statement, program spending over the next two fiscal years will be similar to that projected in the budget. The savings from the expenditure reductions, net of the initiatives for investing in growth, rise substantially each year through 1994-95.
This will mean that spending will continue the pattern since 1991-92 of being well below the limits set out in the Spending Con.trol Act despite the enormous economic pressures.
The expenditure reductions announced in this statement provide a considerable reduction in the structural component of the deficit. As such, the deficit should decline rapidly through the medium term on the basis of the tight control over spending in place and the stronger economic performance and the lower interest rates. It remains the government's objective to attain zero financial requirements over the medium term.
We must and we have to recognize, however, that Canada's deficit problem is a total government problem and not just a federal one. By far the larger share of government operating costs in Canada is provincial and not federal. Therefore, it is vital that all governments review their operations to cut costs, to reduce deficits and to lighten the burden on taxpayers.
Finally, we will invest in partnerships for growth with provincial governments and with the private sector. The recent constitutional discussions diverted attention from what the federal and provincial governments can do together to better co-ordinate economic policy in the interests of growth and jobs.
We will take a leadership role under the existing Constitution and urge better co-ordination of fiscal policies. We are prepared to act with the provinces to develop acceptable frameworks for public sector compensation, to eliminate waste, overlap and duplication, and to harmonize our tax systems and to reduce compliance costs on business and individuals.
The federal government has made specific proposals to achieve this in a much more co-ordinated and open fashion in its document of September 1991. These proposals do not require constitutional amendment and we are prepared to act on them together with the provinces as soon as possible.
As well, it is time-in fact it is long past time-for concrete, comprehensive action to reduce interprovincial trade barriers with a fixed agenda and a timetable.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Hear, hear.

speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the federal government has pressed provinces to remove all barriers and impediments to internal trade by 1995.
I am encouraged by the progress that has been set in place by the Canadian Ministers of Agriculture. Further progress across a range of areas can only strengthen Canada's position at home and abroad.
Our emphasis on a partnership approach with other governments and the private sector reflects the reality of the economic challenges facing Canada, but it also reflects the reality of the federal government's impact on the national economy.
The federal government accounts for less than half of the total government spending in Canada. This fact should be kept in mind by those who continue to pretend that the federal government alone can turn around Canada's economy. Not even a fiscally strong federal government could accomplish that by itself. That is why we must all work together more effectively to get our economy moving strongly forward again.
I am therefore tabling documents, including Notices of Ways and Means Motions. Details of the measures are included in the documents. I have introduced today a bill seeking supplementary borrowing authority for 1992-93.
I am asking that an order of the day be designated for these motions.
December 2, 1992

In conclusion, the question that we must ask ourselves is: How can we best deal with economic change to ensure that Canada can meet the needs and fulfil the hopes of its citizens in the years ahead?
I believe the answer is clear. We must prepare ourselves to take advantage of the opportunities that the new world economy is bringing. That has been the consistent objective of the policies the government has followed in the past eight years. I firmly believe that Canada is now in a strong position to seize those opportunities.
We have all made a considerable investment in making Canada a country that can survive and prosper in a new world economy of the 21st century. This is a country where we can generate the wealth to sustain the social programs and the safety nets that are fundamental to our sense of identity and community.
There are those who would follow policies based on the world as they would like it to be rather than as it exists. But I challenge them to show how an inwardlooking Canada could help Canadians to gain new jobs and opportunities in a new world economy.
There are also those who believe that more government spending and higher government debt can solve any problem, any time, any place. I challenge them to show how deliberately driving up the debt that has weakened us can make us stronger.
Today I have announced actions that will help position Canada for renewed economic success and will assist economic recovery and strengthen the basis for sustained growth and job creation. Through these actions, we are expanding our investment in the growth and vitality of Canada's small businesses in research and development, in training and adjustment for Canadian workers, in improved infrastructure and in a sound fiscal and monetary framework. These actions will help us to deal with global interdependence, but we must also recognize our own interdependence as Canadians in business, labour, government and learning institutions in the continuing effort to modernize our economy.
I appeal to all Canadians for their co-operation as together we pursue the task of securing a positive and vibrant economy for the future for ourselves and for our children. That is, remains and must be our priority as
Government Orders
Canadians and as Canadians' representatives in this House.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in all my years in this House, I have never seen a Minister of Finance who so misunderstands what his job is all about.
At this time this minister's job is to attack unemployment, to attack the lack of economic growth and to attack the recession. Instead, what this minister is doing is attacking the unemployed.

Instead of attacking the recession and unemployment, the minister is attacking the unemployed and the jobless, those who suffer as a result of these policies.

The minister is attacking the jobless by taking $2.4 billion out of the pockets of unemployed Canadians through cuts in their unemployment insurance benefits. This minister is not getting more revenue from closing the tax loopholes identified by the Auditor General. Instead, he is literally reaching into the pockets of unemployed Canadians to try to achieve his budgetary projections which were so wrong in the past so many times.
This is not an act of courage or conviction. It is a vicious attack on those least able to help themselves. The Liberals will not stand for this and certainly Canadians will not stand for this.
What is the net effect of the minister's statement? Over the next two years the Minister of Finance will take some $7 billion out of the Canadian economy, but what is he putting back? He says he will have an infrastructure program of $500 million over two years. He says it will create 4,000 to 5,000 jobs a year. In one day last week we had announcements of losses of three times as many jobs as this minister says he will create with his infrastructure program. In one day. The announcement was a loss of
10,000	jobs at Canadian National, hundreds at Pratt and Whitney, thousands at Dofasco. In one day this minister heard how jobs are going to be wiped out, three times as many as he intends to create over years of his infrastructure program.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Hear, hear.

December 2, 1992
Government Orders

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Even at the minister's best in a previous existence he would have recognized that the latest mini model that he is trying to peddle of his failed economic policies has absolutely no wheels.
Getting back to his infrastructure program, we do not quarrel with the projects mentioned, although I must say they have all been announced before as far as I can recall. However, I ask the minister, where is the municipal infrastructure program that the Canadian Federation of Municipalities and Provinces has been calling for for years? Where is it? There is nothing in this program for municipal infrastructure, nothing for clean water, nothing for sewers. There is nothing to put people back to work almost immediately, using projects that our towns and cities across this country have on the shelf ready to put in place and ready to put people back to work right now.
This budget is so lacking in imagination it does not even present a good attempt at sleight of hand.
The minister talks about the budget and what it does for small business. He talks about creating a higher ceiling for government guaranteed loans to small business. Small business cannot get loans from banks now under the existing ceiling.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
What good will the higher ceiling do? The minister should have listened to the Minister of State for Small Businesses who said just the other day in this House that the banks needed to be kicked in their assets. Is that not what the minister of small business said? I do not know why, if the Minister of Finance wanted to listen to somebody, he did not listen to his Minister of State for Small Businesses who in effect said that the proposal for a higher ceiling for small business loans guaranteed by the government is meaningless because the banks have not been lending the money. His weak-willed pleading today will not make one bit of difference.
Our regions are suffering from the effects of this government's weak and failed policies. Yet the government cuts hundreds of millions of dollars, $350 million, from programs for regional development. There are cuts for ACOA in Atlantic Canada. There are cuts for FEDNOR in northern Ontario. There are cuts for
western diversification in the prairie provinces. What is it doing for regional development? What a failure, what a flop.
There are cuts for farmers. There are cuts for transportation. There are cuts for the native people about whom the Prime Minister said they have such a great need for justice. Where is the justice in this budget for our native people?
There are cuts of $172 million in the green plan. That is the supposed miracle plan to help clean up our environment.
All these cuts mean lost jobs and lost opportunities.
A previous Conservative Minister of Finance promised short-term pain for long-term gain. But all this minister is offering Canadians is long-term pain for more longterm pain.
In this statement, over two years the government is proposing cuts for defence of $1 billion. I searched through the budget papers. I asked the officials in the lock-up and I could not get any details of these cuts. I was wondering if the minister of defence had lost the information about the details in his hotel room in his last trip to Paris, because the details are not there.
This suggests that there will be no cuts in the gold-plated helicopter program, but there could well be cuts in personnel. How can this government maintain its peacekeeping commitments, its current obligations, with these kinds of cuts? If this is not a correct understanding of what is proposed, then why were details not provided in the budget papers?
Two months after forming the government in 1984, the Prime Minister stated: "We have been in power for two months. I can tell you this. Give us 20 years and you will not recognize this country". It took the Prime Minister and his government only 8 years to change the face of Canada and the change has not been for the better.
Let us look at the Canada created by this government:
1.6	million Canadians are out of work; more than 2.3 million Canadians are on welfare; 3.8 million Canadians are living in poverty, over one million of them children; over two million Canadians are forced to rely on food banks.
The eyes and ears of these Canadians are watching and listening to this House on television across this country. They are looking to this government for constructive change. They are looking for constructive change and
December 2, 1992

they are looking for signs of compassion and help and economic growth. What should have been a battle against unemployment and recession has turned into a declaration of war against the unemployed and those suffering the most from these failed Conservative government policies.
I want to ask again, as I asked in this House during Question Period a few days ago, if the Conservative medicine is so good, why is the patient, the Canadian economy, still so sick?
The Minister of Finance told Canadians in his February 1992 budget that real economic growth would be 2.7 per cent, the unemployment rate would be 10.1 per cent and the deficit would be $31.4 billion.
The Minister of Finance has failed to even come close to his projections. He admitted today the economy will grow at a rate of only 1 per cent. That is not enough to even have the economy move barely sideways instead of bringing the growth and jobs Canadians need.
The unemployment rate has surpassed 11 per cent for the last six months while the deficit, as he said today, has gone up to $34.4 billion. Even if his forecasts had been met they still would have painted a sad picture of this government's economic mismanagement and failure.
The minister was wrong. He missed every one of his projections and forecasts. Canadians will ask how the minister can be believed when his forecasts were so wrong last year and in earlier years. How can he be believed when he talks about what his policies will do next year and the year after?
Well, of course, we know that this government will not be here the year after next because Canadians listening to this budget will only be confirmed in their desire to get rid of this government at the first opportunity.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Why wait for spring? Let's do it now.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Conservative policies for economic growth and recovery have failed. The Minister of Finance's statement today is an admission of his failure. At the same time it is a plea for mercy from the Canadian people that will not be accepted by them.
Government Orders
The minister boasts about the success of the trade deal and the GST. Canadians know better from their everyday experience and Canadians will pass a summary judgment on this government in the next election.
Both the United Nations and the OECD have recommended that governments of developed countries break the economic stalemate by loosening their purse strings. Japan, Australia and now the European Community are embarking on major capital and infrastructure programs to stimulate their economies out of recession.
This economic statement is lacking in many things but it is especially lacking in a commitment to strong economic growth and the job creation that goes with it.
The Minister of Finance seems convinced that there are no costs associated with inaction on the economy. But he need only ask himself why the deficit is nearly $7 billion more than he said it would be just last February.
Nobody needs a Ph.D. in economics to know that government expenditures on unemployment insurance have increased and government tax revenues are down because of the recession. Each individual unemployed Canadian is costing taxpayers $15,000 in unemployment benefits and welfare and approximately $7,000 in lost tax revenue. These are only the economic costs. The social costs are much higher in terms of the potential for increased domestic violence, increased crime rates, poor health and loss of individual dignity. The vicious cycle can only be broken by sustained economic growth, strong economic growth and the job creation that it brings.
For Liberals the ultimate objective of economic policy is to build a value-added economy that will create permanent jobs for Canadians and protect and enhance our social fabric.
This Conservative government has spent $500,000 on the Porter study and another $26 million on the prosperity agenda to study our competitiveness problems. Canadians and Canadian companies do not need more studies. They need a government that will act to create an environment that will foster economic growth and strong job creation right now.
This country needs a new economic vision, a vision of change that will create jobs for the future and revitalize our communities all across this country. We need a new economic course for Canada, one this government is incapable of giving, one that is responsive to people and

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
to our environment. We need one that will provide the basis for rebuilding our industrial and resource base.
Top priorities for Liberals are job creation and economic growth with a more balanced approach toward inflation and the other economic variables.
High real interest rates have taken a heavy toll on the Canadian economy in recent years. If Canada is to compete on a global basis we must have monetary policy that puts Canadian firms on a level playing field with our major competitors.
We believe that instead of the limited, incomplete and likely failure of an infrastructure program proposed in this budget we need a real infrastructure program, a national one in partnership with provinces and municipalities, to help revitalize our communities all across this country and create substantial numbers of jobs in the near term.
We believe that the small business sector which is crucial for Canada's long-term economic health must be revitalized. It is the sector that has proven to be the source of most new jobs for Canadians.
We believe governments must assist individuals to deal with the restructuring going on in our economy and the world. This government must come through with its oft-made but oft-broken promises of massive adjustment programs.
We believe there must be a true Canadian economic union eliminating provincial barriers to movements of goods, services, capital and labour.
Liberals believe there must be a full and dynamic research and development strategy that would truly enhance Canada's ability to create and reap the benefits of new technologies.
Liberals believe that Canada must have a global trade strategy to aggressively exploit the potential for export sales to growth areas such as the Pacific Rim and Latin America.
Liberals believe that we must foster economic growth and foster economic growth as a priority. This will help reduce the deficit by creating more government revenues without raising taxes and by saving the government billions through lower unemployment and welfare payments instead of taking them from the pockets of those people who are unemployed.
This government is not up to the challenge of creating the better Canada of tomorrow. It is a government in a state of paralysis. It is a tired government incapable of dealing with the economic problems facing this country.

This government is incapable of preparing Canadians for the challenges awaiting them at the turn of the century.

For months, Liberals have been urging the government to present a new budget, to replace the minister's discredited and failed budget of last February. We wanted a clear signal from the government that rather than stay the course it would change course, but we what got today is nothing more than a rehash of tired old policies from a tired old government.
Now that I have heard this economic statement, I realize this country does not need another economic statement or budget from this government. What this country needs is an election that will allow Canadians to choose a better economic path for their future. They need a path that will bring them hope, confidence and change. They cannot get that hope or confidence or change from this tired and failed government.
Let us respond to what we hear across this country. Let us respond to the calls of Canadians for an election now to get rid of this failed government. Canadians cannot take much more of the damage done to them by the Conservatives. They want to get rid of this government and go on to elect a better one as soon as possible.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if the shouting back and forth between those twin parties would cease we perhaps could offer some comments on this.
This economic statement today is terribly disappointing. It is a classic and complacent trickle-down budget. Its benefits are concentrated on businesses. The victims of this statement are the unemployed and some of
December 2, 1992

Canada's poorest citizens who will be hit by cuts affecting the key programs that assist them.
It is made in the face of immense economic distress. There is 11.3 per cent unemployment across this country. There is long-run joblessness which has doubled in the past two years in this country. There is growing poverty. A report just this week said that 3.8 million Canadians were poverty stricken in 1990. The situation is worse in
1992.
By the government's own statistics income distribution is worsening. There are more than 2.5 million people on welfare in this country. Right across this nation human distress is getting worse and worse, and this government has presented us with a plan that does nothing. It does nothing except make life somewhat tougher for those who are losing their jobs.
By this plan which the government has brought forward today the officials of the government conceded to us that the unemployment rate will still be 11 per cent or higher by the end of the 1993-94 fiscal year. By the end of March 1994 unemployment will still be 11 per cent or higher. It is shameful that a government should bring before this House a plan for economic recovery which would leave us with 11 per cent unemployed in 1994.
This is not a solution. This is an excuse for inaction. This is a cop-out. It does nothing for the people of Canada except create more tears, more pain, and more human damage across this economy. Even in the government's own terms it is a massively irresponsible budget, almost a laughable budget.
The Minister of Finance rose in the House today and talked about the seriousness of the deficit problem. If he had talked about the seriousness of the unemployment problem maybe we would have seen something done about it. However, what he talked about was the seriousness of the deficit problem.
I have the statistics here. They are not from a budget two years ago or from a budget five years ago, they are the projections from the budget which this government brought down in February of this year.
Do you know what that budget said that the deficit would be for 1993-94? It would be $22.5 billion. That is what the deficit would be. Yet, the Minister of Finance
Government Orders
boasted today that he is reducing the deficit to, get this, $32.6 billion for next year.
Perhaps the Minister of Finance missed an arithmetic course somewhere along the line. Perhaps, like Dan Quayle, the Minister of Finance is not very good at arithmetic. In the case of Quayle it was spelling.
The Minister of Finance must be kidding us when he says he has reduced the deficit from what it was supposed to be, $22.5 billion, to what it is now going to be, $32.6 billion. I would laugh except that this is not a laughing matter. This government has been in power since 1984. It cannot blame others for the deficit problem it has created.
At the end of 1992 we are facing a deficit for the next fiscal year as a consequence of this government's action that will be $10.1 billion higher than it projected just nine months ago. This is not a projection from some time in the past. As for five years ago, maybe it would be unfair to take one of the present Minister for International Trade's budgets and look at it. By his projections we were supposed to be down to a deficit of about $6 billion for next year. I am not even going to refer to his budgets.
I am just going to refer to the present Minister of Finance's budget which promised us faithfully in February of this year that we would have a deficit for the next fiscal year of $22.5 billion. In this economic statement that he expects us to endorse, what has he brought in? A deficit of $32.6 billion. Somehow he expects the House to take him seriously when he says that he is committed to reducing the deficit and putting finances on a sound basis. It was as much as his caucus could manage sitting beside him there in self-congratulatory poses not to break up laughing at that point.
It certainly was heard enough for us, with some respect for the truth, not to break down crying as we listened to the minister talk about reducing the deficit when what we saw in front of us was a government which through its own inept economic policies has taken this country to a deficit this year of almost $35 billion and a deficit next year that will be close to $33 billion.
I see the President of the Treasury Board sitting on the front benches and I see the Minister for International Trade who I know is concerned about these deficits. I am surprised that these ministers permitted a budget as

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
irresponsible and laughable as this to get through the cabinet. I am surprised that this government would even be prepared to come before the Canadian people and expect to be taken seriously, having promised us nine months ago that next year's deficit would be $22.5 billion and now expecting us to cheer because that deficit has been brought down to $32.6 billion. This government must be made up of clowns to expect us to accept that kind of faulty arithmetic.
What should we have done? What should this economic statement have presented to the people of Canada? It certainly should not have presented an increase in the deficit.
We have reached a stage under the irresponsible financial management of this Conservative government and the previous Liberal government at which the deficit level in this country is simply impossible to sustain as a nation.
We should not have seen an increase in the deficit. Instead, we should have had a government come before us and say three things. This government should first have said that it recognizes that it has been financially irresponsible and it is going to plug those corporate loopholes, those tax escape hatches that have permitted this deficit to rise to such unsustainable heights. It should have come before us and said it has listened to the report of the Auditor General, who said there was upward of $1 billion in taxes escaping this government because of companies sending money out to tax loophole countries where they could write things off and then send dividends back to be untaxed in this country because of tax agreements we have with these tax loophole countries.
It should have introduced something to stop that from happening. It should have introduced something to deal with the immensely unfair escapes that wealthy people in this country have under the present capital gains tax loopholes which this government put into effect.
Over 60 per cent of the $3 billion in tax relief which is given to people by this capital gains tax loophole goes to people whose individual income, not family income, is over $100,000 a year. These are not exactly hard up farmers, hard-working small business people or people who are selling their only house, all of whom we would want to see continue to get exemptions from capital gains tax.
These are people who are taking advantage of our tax system. As a result we have a deficit in this country which is sky-high and unsustainable. It is causing massive income disparities and massive increases in the interest rates in this country. Frankly, this government looks like a fool when it comes before us to talk about a $32.6 billion deficit for next year when it promised a $22.5 billion deficit.
It should have closed the loophole for entertainment tax deductions. That would have given us another billion dollars in revenues. It should also have looked at the deductions that a Canadian corporation can make for interest payments on a loan it takes out here in Canada and uses to buy up new assets or create new jobs not here in Canada but in Germany, the Caribbean, the United States, or any place except this country.
That interest deduction loophole which exists in the tax system should have been closed. If it had closed these loopholes that in itself would have freed up something like $4 billion to $6 billion in new resources that we could use to get people back to work and to cut taxes, not for corporations but for working people and middle-class people in this country, the people who have been hit so hard by the goods and services tax of which this government boasts.
We could have done something about the family trust loophole about which my colleague, our tax policy critic, has been talking so effectively in the House of Commons. That loophole was supposed to run out as of 1993, but the Conservative government, as usual listening to its rich and wealthy friends, has decided to extend it. The Liberals started it. The Conservatives continued it. Only New Democrats will end it and give us tax fairness.
If we had this kind of tax fairness we would not have the deficit in front of us that we have at the moment. We would not have the number of people out of work that we have at the moment. We would not have the disastrous economic conditions which are damaging people from coast to coast to coast. We could have dealt with tax loopholes. That is one thing the government should have done in this economic statement.
The second thing it should have done was recognize what many countries in the world have come to see. The cold war is over. Having a defence budget for our country that is as large or larger than it was two years ago

December 2, 1992

is simply senseless. We have a defence budget of over $12 billion. There is no way to justify a defence budget that is just as large now as it was when there was a supposed massive military threat from the Warsaw pact and the Soviet Union. The Soviet Union, in case the government has not noticed, has dissolved; the Warsaw pact has broken up. The various countries that we thought of as enemies are now our allies in many cases.
The threat to people in this country is not from the Soviet Union; it is from the government.
We needed to see in this economic statement a cut in defence expenditures which had some seriousness, a cut not of $200 and some million this year and $200 and some million next year but a cut of some $2 billion. That starts to give this country a defence budget of some significance, yes, but of some proportion to our size and what we can contribute in the world. We should have seen that in the economic statement.
We should also have seen a deliberate plan set out to reduce interest rates in Canada. If we had interest rates in Canada which were three percentage points less than they presently are we would free up resources to help with new jobs, to help in tax cuts, of close to $4.5 billion.
If we add these various possibilities-closing tax loophoLes, cutting defence expenditures and reducing interest rates-we would have had savings that could have been announced by this government of something on the order of $11 billion to $12 billion. I hardly need to say that $11 billion to $12 billion could have made some real reductions in the deficit. There would have been some money left over to provide tax breaks for people in Canada, some money left over to provide help for those who are out of work. We should have taken that $11 billion to $12 billion and used some of it for deficit reduction but used much of it for a real program of economic recovery.
It could have been a Canadian economic recovery strategy that stressed environmental upgrading for our cities and that stressed social housing for people who are so poorly housed in many cities throughout Canada. It
Government Orders
could have been an approach that said: "Let us have some tax cuts as the first step to getting rid of the GST".
We do not need a goods and services tax in Canada. It is an unfair tax. It is a tax that hurts small business. It is a tax we can get rid of if we close some of those tax loopholes and get a fair taxation system.
We should have seen a national investment fund launched by the government, a fund which would do something to see to it that money actually got to small businesses that needed it and could not get it from the banks these days. We should have seen to it that money was available for communities to help keep companies operating which were facing problems and being shut down by their foreign parents in the United States. We could have kept those companies going. We could have kept them active and employing Canadians if we would have had in Canada a national investment fund to provide venture capital and to provide real help on an investment basis, combining both government help and private sector help to see to it that companies were kept operating in Canada instead of being shut down by their parent companies.
Instead of boasting about NAFTA and what North American free trade was going to do for us, the Minister of Finance should have stood today and said: "We suspend all further discussion of NAFTA. We are not going to damage the Canadian economy further in 1992". If we had seen that, we would have seen a chance for people, workers and even many small business people in the country to have felt some sense of security, some sense of potential in their businesses and in their jobs in the future. They would therefore have gone out and spent some money. They would have invested some money and we would have had extra jobs in the country.
We also need a new approach to trade that does not just see our role as a country, our future as a country in tying ourselves to the United States and tying ourselves to Mexico but sees ourselves as an internationally competitive country with a strategy to build up Canadian based operations to be able to export successfully throughout the world and be able to build up jobs in the country for Canadians.
We could have had it stressed in the statement by more examples of Canadian content being put into effect in various sectors of the economy.

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
For instance, a group appeared before us this morning from McDonnell-Douglas aircraft in Toronto. It said that the government was prepared to help, if it was prepared to give money to Canadian Airlines to stay aflight then: "We are not going to argue with that, but if the government is prepared to provide money to Canadian Airlines", these people for McDonnell-Douglas Canada said to us, "it should be prepared to require Canadian to buy Canadian in terms of the aircraft it uses".
It could have been part of any loan agreement that was established. There are all sorts of other conditions in that loan agreement. It could have been part of the agreement that there would have to be Canadian content in every future aircraft purchase that Canadian Airlines makes.
I fly back and forth to Windsor every weekend in a Brazilian aircraft. I find it interesting. They make good aircraft. Frankly I would rather that aircraft were Canadian and providing jobs to Canadians than providing jobs to Brazil. If we are providing the money to Canadian Airlines, we should be insisting on conditions that mean jobs for Canada and jobs for Canadians, just as is the case in the present auto pact which has been important for my community and for other communities throughout Ontario.
When government itself makes purchases it should insist on making, wherever it can, its purchases of goods and services from Canadians to provide opportunities for Canada, to provide opportunities for some of those 1.6 million people who are out of work in this country to get back to work.
We must also recognize that many people in this country have been hard hit by this government's economic policies. We must see to it that we maintain the values and commitments to support those people that have always been part of the Canadian heritage. Instead of cutting back benefits to unemployment insurance recipients, we should be extending those benefits in this period of high unemployment so that those people have money and the money can be used to help this economy, to help small businesses and to help the rest of the economy as well.
The government has decided on a whole lot of different approaches. It has some measures to help small business. We support those. It is sensible to assist small
business. We have been calling for that for many years. I have to say it is a bit unfair when small business owners are told that they will get a premium holiday for new people that they hire as far as unemployment insurance premiums are concerned but the workers who will be hired are told that they will have to pay those premiums even though their employers will not. That is not even-handed and fair.
We have some tax changes to the RRSP system which helped the co-operative movement. My friend from Prince Albert will be particularly pleased to see those. I am pleased to see them too because we have long argued that there should be some fairness, some equity for people who are forming co-operatives.
There are as well some initiatives on infrastructure. It is interesting when we look through the initiatives on infrastructure that there are a lot in different parts of the country but it is very hard to find any in Ontario. I wonder if that could have anything to do with the quarrels about the nature of this infrastructure initiative that have been taking place between the provincial Government of Ontario and the federal government. I wonder if this government is not punishing Ontario for insisting on an infrastructure strategy that would be beneficial to the whole country, not just to parts of the country.
Finally, there are two parts of this package which are especially shameful. There is a reduction in unemployment insurance support at a time when there are more people out of work in this country, more people out of work in Ontario, than we have seen since the 1930s. Yet, what does the government do? It reduces the level of support for people receiving unemployment insurance from 60 per cent of their earnings to 57 per cent of their earnings.
It goes further. It says: "If people are dismissed for misconduct". Who decides what misconduct is? If they are dismissed for misconduct they will not get unemployment insurance. I look forward to various unemployed people coming to the Conservative members of this House and their constituency offices and saying: "I am out of work. My boss says that I was somehow guilty of some misconduct and the result is I cannot get any unemployment insurance".

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: After you have paid into it.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
And the boss does not pay.
December 2, 1992

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: After they have paid those insurance premiums for years and years and years.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: That is sickening.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Let these Conservative MPs explain to their constituents why they have put such a vicious, nasty hook into the unemployment insurance system.
What is the consequence of all this? The consequence is, believe it or not, an unemployment rate at the end of the next fiscal year which will still be 11 per cent or higher. That is tragic. The Minister of Finance spoke the other day about how we were in an economic recovery. How could he pretend to the people of Canada that this is an economic recovery if there is still going to be 11 per cent unemployment in March 1994? That is not recovery, that is still economic disaster for far too many people in this country.
The Minister of Finance has talked about a gentle nudge forward for the economy as being what he expected to provide with this statement. What he has done is kicked the people of Canada in the stomach with this economic statement. He has given the people of Canada a series of cutbacks that will cost 3,000 to 4,000 jobs in the Public Service and a series of vicious changes to the unemployment insurance system which will make life much harder for those who are out of work.
On top of all of that, he has given us the laughable arithmetic that tells us he has reduced the deficit from the $22.5 billion he projected in February this year to a remarkably miraculous level of $32.6 billion which he now says will be the deficit for next year.
This is a government that has seen its day. It is a government that has got to go. It is a government which for the sake of this country should be gone. It is a government which clearly, in bringing forth a mini budget, has simply presented us with mini ideas, presented us with no plan for the future, no plan for unemployment, and no plan for economic progress for this country.
There is no plan for a trade strategy that will help us to regain our independence, so much of which we have lost with the free trade agreement. This is a government which has given us nothing but pain in this budget.
Government Orders
It has given us nothing but pain and a kind of tragic comic performance as the Minister of Finance tries to persuade us that he is being fiscally responsible when he has created this intolerable recession, hurt millions of people across this country and will leave Canada in far worse shape economically and financially when this government is defeated, as indeed it must be defeated in
1993.
There is an alternative. I have tried to set it out in some detail. It is an alternative which will work and, more important, it is an alternative which will get Canadians back to work. I urge this government to even today withdraw this laughable economic statement.
Tell us: "We are sorry. We apologize to the House for bringing this joke before Parliament. We will bring a new budget to you in December". In the meantime, let us adjourn this House of Commons. Let us let this government go and think for a while.
If it thinks things through right it may even recognize that the proper course of action for it to take is to stand up today and resign as the Government of Canada.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we have just heard two sorry responses from the NDP and from the Liberals. There has been lots of bluster, lots of rhetoric, and lots of hand wringing but no new ideas. There were no specifics but only a throw back to the policies of the 1960s and 1970s. They were vintage policies that have not improved with age.
The Liberal critic says he would spend. He gave us some ideas about how he would spend. He gave us some ideas about why he disagreed with the reductions in spending that we have brought in. That is the difference. He has opposed every way that we have proposed as to how we would keep this government's spending on track.
It would be folly to follow the approaches that the Liberals have set out because they would lead to an increase in the deficit, an increase in interest rates, a slam on business confidence and they would kill the economy.
He is saying he wants to have some compassion, some help and some hope but is that going to come for an economy that has been killed by high interest rates,

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
because that is precisely the result of the policies that he is putting forward?
What is needed now is a vision of the future, an understanding of the type of world that we are in today. We need a vision of an economy built on greater training, greater research and development, greater investment, stronger small business and a greater opportunity to expand internationally.
This is what the Minister of Finance has put forward today. We have heard words from the Liberals and we have heard wishes, but we have heard no new ideas. This is a government that is dedicated to action. The Official Opposition is tired, it is devoid of ideas and that is a fundamental difference between the message from the Minister of Finance and the tired statement from the Liberal finance critic.
The response of the New Democratic Party is equally unrealistic. It is following the same policies which the New Democratic Party in Ontario foundshell", something we just heard now, "That would be a mistake", it says. "Even in a closed economy, a retreat to high taxes and high inflation would only make matters worse. But the world economy is growing ever more integrated: With capital and skills freer to move, Sweden cannot go back to its old ways without seeing both sorts of assets leak abroad. The third way, if it ever really existed, is no longer there".
We have just heard from the NDP about the third way. Both opposition parties simply do not understand what is happening in the world today. This recovery is slow. The Minister of Finance has acknowledged that. But it is slow because there is a significant amount of restructuring going on in the economy today and it is the same the world over as business changes and adjusts to the challenges of the 1990s and beyond. Stimulating the economy today through more spending is not the answer. Encouraging and assisting the change that must occur is the proper role of government and that is what the Minister of Finance has put before the House and the Canadian people today.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Throw money at it.

speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
My friend opposite does not like me talking about this but the NDP in Ontario found that its policies did not work. Listen to Bob Rae today. He is saying: "I have learned a lot in government. I have learned that we cannot do all the things that maybe we liked to talk about in 15 years in opposition". Now we are seeing the U-turn. We are seeing the NDP in Ontario scrambling to cover its mistakes, cutting hospitals, cutting schools, cutting universities, cutting social programs, having to face reality because it started off on the wrong foot and had a 13 per cent increase in spending in its first year on top of five or six years of 10 per cent increases in spending by the Ontario Liberal Party.
It is no surprise that we are getting these policies from the NDP. They are still living in the past. The Leader of the New Democratic Party has written about this. She has talked in glowing terms about the successes of the Swedish economy, the so-called third way that the New Democratic Party has been championing, but more recently Sweden is coming back to reality as well. It has found that the real world is something that it cannot hide from.
I want to quote from the Economist of November 28: "Many Swedes may now prefer to go back to their old
I am honoured to be a part of this debate to talk about the government's vision for the Canadian economy in the 1990s and beyond and what is needed to get there. It is a vision of a new vibrantly competitive Canadian economy prospering in the new global economy. It is a vision that focuses on investing in growth for the long term as previous generations of Canadians have done for us, but it also takes account of the fiscal realities and the global competitive realities of the world today.
This is a vision that is shared by Canadians throughout this country. We found that in the 186 communities that the Prosperity Initiative visited over the course of the past year, and we listened to these ideas coming forth from Canadians. These ideas are represented in a large fashion in the message that has been delivered by the Minister of Finance today. This dialogue has resulted in a remarkable consensus about Canadians. Read the Prosperity Initiative. Read the steering group report. It sets out clearly the consensus that Canadians put forth to the steering group and that we have listened very carefully to and have reflected in the message today.
Canadians are telling governments to stop trying to direct the private sector and instead do our traditional jobs better by investing in people and making sure that we get it right so that all Canadians can enjoy the benefit of a high skill economy by creating the right investment

December 2, 1992

climate, by building the public infrastructure that only governments can provide, by opening trading markets internationally so that we can compete and win on a global scale, and by investing in sound monetary and fiscal policies, by remembering that governments exist to serve Canadians and hence rediscovering our clients, the taxpayers, and serving them more efficiently.
Finally, we must stop the incessant quarrelling among our stakeholders and start collaborating, building partnerships, and finding the best way of doing things.
The economic statement we just heard today goes directly to the heart of what governments should be doing to improve the long-term climate for growth in this country. It is not enough for the opposition parties to bluster and wring their hands about weak growth and high unemployment. Those are facts of life in many countries of the world today. What we have to do now is find how we move from here in the most effective way possible because all Canadians and all people on both sides of the House are concerned about these problems.
The debate is about the respective visions that we have for the future of our country. Unlike the NDP and the Liberals today ours is not a vision of an economy that is force-fed by the government. It is a vision of an economy of the future where government motivates productive activity by entrepreneurs, innovators and people building their skills and by business people competing internationally.
This is the economy that we will build in the 1990s and beyond. It is an economy that is totally unknown, unfortunately for our friends opposite. They simply do not understand the reality of the world that we live in.
The prosperity consultations hammered home, hopefully in a way that even the opposition could understand, that there is a need to keep our fiscal house in order and to strive for a tax system that contributes to a dynamic and growing economy.
