The statement follows a fiscally responsible course because that is the only way we are going to get interest rates down in a way that can serve the development of this economy.
There are no new taxes in this economic statement and this is not the first time. There were no tax increases in
Government Orders
the 1991 budget. There were tax reductions in the 1992 budget and again in this economic statement so that Canadians could invest in growth and see this country build.
The tax reductions that were announced by the Minister of Finance today will improve the competitiveness of Canadian companies. However, provincial governments have to build on and not offset these measures if Canadian companies are to adequately grow, prosper and create the high paying, quality jobs that we all want to see in this House. The difference on this side, though, is that we put in a statement the specific actions needed to create those high paying jobs.
It is particularly important for provincial governments to follow the same approach because there is only one taxpayer. As the federal government reduces the tax burden it would be particularly counter-productive for any province to raise its taxes in any form. This is a particularly strong recommendation that comes forward from the prosperity action plan.
Investing in growth has to start with small business. This is a vital sector of the Canadian economy. It has created some 80 per cent of the jobs created since 1984.
To encourage new jobs and expansion the government will pay the unemployment insurance premium costs for new employees for the vast majority of small businesses in 1993. That will save employers some $500 million to expand their employment and their production and to encourage investment and machinery and equipment. These are crucial areas for the competitiveness of small businesses.
There will be a 10 per cent tax credit from now until the end of next year. There will be a new small business financing program to help firms reduce their borrowing costs. That will be extended to the end of 1994. The Small Businesses Loans Act has been expanded in a way that will help these small businesses to expand.
The importance of research and development in the prosperity consultations was another thing that we heard about on an ongoing basis. People recognize that Canada has one of the most generous tax systems for research and development in the world today. However, this has to be put in the context of its importance for our future prosperity by shifting rapidly to high valued-added prod-

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
ucts either in traditional industries or in new growth sectors.
In the 1992 budget we improved on this tax regime. However, we found since then, based on our consultations, that we could do better here. This is what the Minister of Finance has proposed by earmarking a further $500 million on top of the $230 million in the last budget. It is to improve the tax treatment of equipment like computers that become obsolete quickly due to rapid technological change and some other initiatives.
Innovation based on research and development and technology adoption needs more than just tax incentives. It needs new forms of infrastructure. Building and maintaining infrastructure is one of the government's most essential roles. Here we have some important announcements again from the Minister of Finance. The infrastructure includes roads, bridges and water treatment plants. It also means the new infrastructure that goes beyond physical capital and hardware and includes soft infrastructure like information and research networks.
Funding for the Canadian network for the advancement of research, industry and education, the CANA-RIE project, will enable the development of a state of the art, high speed, high capacity data communications network to transmit information across this country. It will be a true electronic highway of the future. This is absolutely critical for the research institutions of our country today and one of the recommendations of the prosperity action plan.
In response to the clear message that we heard in the consultations, the adoption and adaptation of technology by Canadian industry has to accelerate. We will extend the Industrial Research Assistance Program, or IRAP, offered by the National Research Council. That currently provides technical advice and counselling to roughly
10,000	firms every year and financial support to about one-third of those firms to introduce technological innovations to their businesses.
This is a particularly important program. We will consolidate the delivery of the government's technology diffusion programs within IRAP. That will go a long way toward the implementation of the vision that we have as a government of a national technology extension system.
This is particularly important for the small business community.
There is a commitment to total quality management here that is also important which I want to mention, because this commitment to quality must go hand in hand with the technologically advanced economy.
The response we have given here is consistent with what the prosperity initiative recommended to us. It is a national quality initiative with a Canadian network of total quality institutions. It brings together those people in the business and educational communities, plus the Conference Board of Canada, in a network to encourage the dissemination of these ideas in helping small business adopt these ideas and bring themselves into the world of quality which is absolutely essential to the competitive position of the Canadian economy.
In terms of regulatory reform, not all taxes are transparent or collected. There are other types of taxes and I am talking about the hidden tax burden of regulation. The Minister of Finance has set out very clearly what we have been doing here since his 1992 budget. Two hundred and fifty regulations have been reviewed and 50 per cent will be amended, sunsetted or eliminated.
The review has now been extended to 17 other departments and six agencies. There will be new rules for federal regulators and this will be done in consultation with the private sector in a way that will result in an effective reduction of this burden of regulation.
I will talk about opening markets for Canadian business. Tomorrow, I will be meeting with the provinces to talk about the reduction and elimination of the interprovincial barriers to trade. This is very consistent with what we have been doing in the NAFTA negotiations and the free trade negotiations as we open up our markets into the United States and into Mexico. We have done well under this.
I spoke in the House on Tuesday about how well we have been doing in increasing our business into that market. As the Minister of Finance has pointed out, it is the combination of access to that market and reduction in the costs to our manufacturers-such as the elimination of the federal sales tax and its replacement by the goods and services tax-that has been a very important part of that 10.5 per cent increase in exports that we have seen this year compared to last year. The C. D. Howe Institute has a very good report that I encourage you to read, Mr. Speaker, that shows how we have improved
December 2, 1992

our performance in high value-added exports to the United States. It is those very exports that have been subject to the reduction in tariffs as a result of the free trade agreement.
We just cannot wish that we had high value-added goods and services produced here in Canada, as the Liberal finance critic said. We have to do things and implement policies to bring this about. This is what the free trade agreement and the goods and services tax have provided for us.
In NAFTA we will be able to extend these opportunities further into the Mexican market. That is a high-value, fast-growing market in the future that is going to be important for us.
Let me close with just a few words about my meeting tomorrow, because I am sure the House will be interested in this. We have committed, as the federal government and provincial governments, to eliminate burdens that are costing $6 billion to the Canadian economy, which is the interprovincial barriers to trade. There have been a number of reports on this, but these are not hypothetical things, these are specific impediments to trade: government procurement preferences, local content rules, restrictive hiring and trade practices, predatory business regulations, liquor regulations and other obstacles that hurt our workers and that hurt our businesses.
When we think of all we are doing internationally to open up markets it is particularly ludicrous that we continue to maintain these barriers within Canada and make it easier for some of our companies to do business into Canada from outside Canada, rather than doing it from other provinces where we can keep those jobs here within Canada.
In conclusion, these last few years have been difficult years, not only for Canada but for most industrialized countries. There are no magic solutions. There are no painless answers. The adjustments to the new global realities have been difficult. They will take time, but they are very necessary.
At the same time, we have to build a stronger, more competitive economy. This is what this statement has proposed for us today. It is a statement that is based in
Government Orders
large part on the consultations that we have carried out this year that have produced many, many good ideas that have been implemented as a result of the statement today.
However, we must never lose sight of one of the most important messages that we obtained from the prosperity consultations. That is the need to work together as a country. If we are really going to create a stronger economic base and growing business confidence all Canadians need to seek out and build these partnerships in collaborative approaches to the problems that we are facing as a country. In a quickly changing world we have to be nimble, not numb. Adapting quickly to the rapidly changing global economy requires that teamwork
Teamwork and a sense of partnership within this House are what we are calling for so we can address these problems and do so in a way, as the Minister of Finance has pointed out, that will bring us into that new economy of the 1990s and beyond in a strong way. It will be in a way that reflects the wishes of Canadians and produces those good jobs and the security, hope and confidence that we can have in the future.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to ask the minister about a very specific matter in this economic statement which I find excessively cruel. It is the proposal that unemployment insurance benefits be cut back for those who are unemployed.
One might understand such a measure if there were a lot of jobs out there and the government was trying to encourage or force lazy unemployed persons to leave the unemployment insurance rolls and go out to seek those jobs. However, that is not the case.
In most parts of the country there are no jobs. The jobs that these Canadians need have been completely eliminated. Factories have closed or cut entire programs, which is also the case with businesses with white collar jobs. In many parts of the country there are no jobs to go to.
There are about 1.5 million Canadians unemployed with double digit unemployment rates in almost every province. Yet the government is cutting back the unemployment benefit which is meant to see people through their period of unemployment, to help them pay their rent, to buy their groceries, to pay for the essentials of life, their children's clothing, transportation and so on.

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
I fail to understand this. Is the government saying that rents will be cut back by a similar percentage and that grocery prices will be cut back, that this cutback on their only income, their unemployment insurance benefit, will be paralleled by cuts in prices in other areas? How does the minister justify this excessively cruel proposal? I guess the other side of it is that the government is going to cut unemployment insurance altogether for those who leave their jobs without just cause or are let go for misconduct.
That would be all right and we would support it if misconduct was so clear or if leaving your job without cause was so clear. However, we all know that because of personality conflicts and all sorts of other reasons people are often forced out of jobs and it is very difficult to decide whether it is just cause or not. The Minister of Employment and Immigration knows that too because he has to deal with that. Who is going to decide what is just cause in leaving employment when a woman is harassed by her boss or when some other similar incident takes place?
I would like the minister to tell us how he, as a long time minister in this government, can justify these two proposals: cutting back on unemployment insurance benefits for people who are unemployed and totally eliminating, without any arbitration or conciliation proposal, unemployment insurance for people who have to leave their jobs?

speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think my hon. friend will be hearing a fuller explanation of this from my colleague, the Minister of Employment and Immigration, in due course.
However, let me just respond directly to the points that my friend has made. We have, over the course of the eight years we have been in government, been fighting to maintain the finances of this government in a way that will get the deficit down, a deficit we inherited that was far too high.
We are not happy to cut these programs but it is a fact of life that if we do not cut them interest rates will go up and that will slow down the growth in the economy. If the economy slows down it is going to make it far harder for the people who are unemployed today to get their jobs back.
The program that we have proposed here is not just a one-sided program. It is a program that maintains the benefit level, the current beneficiaries are grandfathered so they will not be affected by this. The Prime Minister has also announced a $300 million special initiative for displaced workers to help give them the support they need to get back into the work force and get off unemployment insurance.
If my friend looks at the broad motivation here, which is to get the economy moving as quickly as we can through reducing interest rates but also trying to treat unemployed workers fairly by not reducing their benefit but by keeping it level for future years, he will see that this is a balanced approach to a very, very difficult problem.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I was listening with a great deal of interest to the minister's comments. My question is a very simple one. It seems to me that the government is looking for ways that it can cut expenses and at the same time raise revenues. I am just wondering why it did not use the Auditor General's report as a kind of Rand McNally map to economic independence, to gaining revenue and to cutting down a lot of the money that is wasted by this government.
I would just like to ask the minister two questions which are closely related. The first question deals with the GST. Many of my constituents have written to me saying: "Why not simply apply the GST in the financial institutions sector, transactions between stockbrokers and investors and so forth?" I know that the minister comes from that sector. He must have a particularly keen insight into why we do not have GST on those kinds of transactions.
Second, and this comes from the Auditor General's report. Why not look to the creation of 10,000 jobs estimated by the Auditor General through more efficient management of the forest resources on Indian reserves? This is not just speculation. This is what the Auditor General says: "10,000 jobs".
I just asked two specific questions of the minister and I would appreciate two specific answers.
December 2, 1992

speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, a general comment in response to the hon. member. Every time the Auditor General's report comes out we study it from start to finish. Every department that is affected by the report is asked for a response. Many of the responses to the Auditor General's recommendations have been implemented. That is one of the reasons why, as the Minister of Finance pointed out, we have been able to reduce the cost of the operations of government by something like 20 per cent after taking into account the effects of inflation.
As for the two specific points that my hon. friend has made. First he asked: "Why not apply the GST to financial institutions?" In a word, because it is too complex to do it. There is no country in the world that applies a sales tax like the goods and services tax to financial institutions.
When I was Minister of Finance and when we were bringing in the GST we looked at a range of ways to do it and we found that they simply did not work. It is no surprise because no other country has been able to find a way to do it either.
On the second point, concerning the question of management of forest resources. As I said, we will be reviewing this as we review every other recommendation of the Auditor General. Either the Minister of Indian Affairs or the Minister of Forestry will be able to provide my friend with a more specific response in due course.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is to the minister. Again we have a continuing decline in real salary for employees of the government as well as for members of Parliament, ministers and the Prime Minister. It is fairly easy in our salary range to take a salary freeze for three full years. However, it is not so easy for the tens of thousands of Public Service employees who are earning less than $20,000 a year.
I have these questions for the minister in terms of how much ministers and the Prime Minister are co-operating in this effort. Will ministers now be reversing the step they took a couple of years ago of doubling the number of employees they can take out of their departments and cut back from 40 to 20 to assist their departments in these downsizing and cost-cutting measures.
Government Orders
Will minister's and the Prime Minister's operating budgets, expense accounts and various other means of compensating for a freeze in salary be reduced? Will ministers reduce their draw on the resources of their departments to serve the political purposes of the minister's office, such as advertising, polling and so on?

speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, these are obviously very detailed questions. The President of the Treasury Board will be speaking to the House during this debate. At that time I encourage my hon. friend to direct those questions to him.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, since there are so many members of the Liberal party who wish to speak in this debate we will be sharing our time. My time will be shared with the hon. member for Algoma.
The economic statement given to us today by the Minister of Finance was the ultimate in doublespeak and cynicism. On the one hand this Conservative minister speaks of compassion and caring. Great buzz words. The government says it wants to stimulate the economy, create jobs, improve productivity, help research and development, economic growth and so on.
The government says those things on the one hand, but on the other hand it continues with the same failed policy. It continues with the same supply-side, trickle-down policy that was just totally rejected in the United States. The policy that it is following, and unfortunately continues to follow, has been carried on for the past few years in this country, in Great Britain and in the United States. It has left nothing but disaster: the closing of plants and businesses all over the place and high and record levels of unemployment and bankruptcies.
The government speaks about giving assistance to certain sectors and it has. It does give some assistance to certain sectors in this economic statement but it is only token assistance and will not do much at all. When the minister speaks about alternative plans and when the minister for trade who just sat down speaks of alternative plans I would urge them to look at the plans and suggestions put forward by the Clinton-Gore team in the United States, which have been publicized for several years by Robert Reich and other American economists.

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
In fact what it is doing is staying on the same old track when nearly everybody who has something to say about economics has said that it should be on a different track.
I will get to this in a second, but sure, it has said that we are in a recession. However, it blames that recession on everyone else but itself. Instead of adopting policies which would run counter to the recession it is continuing with policies which stimulate and fuel that recession.
In the statement the government blames the recession, the unemployment, the bankruptcies and the terrible economic situation that we are in on world market conditions, on world recessionary trends, and on a whole lot of things except its own policies.
If we look back over the last few years, let us just look at the GST. Economist upon economist and think-tank upon think-tank have said, even those that agreed with the GST, that it was the wrong time to bring in such a massive tax increase and change. These experts said that if the government brought it in at the time it did it would only make any recession that was on the horizon much worse.
In many cases it is the government's policies that have deepened this recession and have made it much worse. Yes, there is a world-wide recession and we would be facing recession in any case. However this government, contrary to the advice that was given to it, not only in this House but from many parts of the country, went ahead with measures which stimulated, deepened and made things even worse than they would otherwise be.
One could say the same thing about the free trade agreement, which is not just a free trade agreement. It is an agreement to export capital and to import investment in this country, to sell out the control of our industry and resources. A real free trade agreement means that we produce goods and services in this country and we sell them to the United States without any tariff or with low tariffs and it does the same with us. It does not mean that we move entire businesses to the United States, that we set up a system in which we move entire businesses to the United States. That is not free trade.
That goes much beyond free trade. A free trade agreement does not mean that we open up our country
so that the United States, in this case, can buy out and take control of many of our major businesses, close them down, consolidate them with businesses in the United States, supply Canada from American factories, and only set up and leave warehouses in this country.
The ills and the problems that we face were to a great extent made by this Tory government since it has been in power.
The government talks about a leaner Public Service. Of course, it does so at the expense of extremely bad service. All of us who are members of Parliament are faced with letters and telephone calls from people who telephone day in and day out, let us say to the unemployment insurance office or to the pension office, but they cannot get someone to answer the line because there are not enough employees or because the lines have been cut back. The service in many departments is terrible. There has been a loss of jobs.
Worse still, what this leaner Public Service means for the government is a greater opportunity to contract out to its friends. It spends money. It shows us the numbers in the Public Service and yes, they have been decreased.
However, the government takes the services previously carried out by public servants on a full-time basis and contracts them out. Those services could be cleaning buildings, accounting or whatever. The government contracts them out to its friends and those companies certainly make good profits out of those contracts. The people working for those companies and performing the services are, for the most part, paid at minimum wage, are without unions, have no pensions and no benefits whatsoever. That is the sort of leaner Public Service the government is talking about.
The most disgraceful part of the economic statement today concerned the provisions with respect to unemployment insurance. When the free trade debate was carried on a few years ago we said on this side of the House that this would lead to a harmonizing of American social programs with Canadian social programs. It would lead to a levelling down to what the American social support system was.
December 2, 1992

In fact, that prediction is taking place in many areas. It is taking place with respect to our pension programs, family support programs and also with respect to unemployment insurance.
The government started on that road when it brought in this massive reform of unemployment insurance a few years ago. It withdrew total government contributions to the fund and put the fund totally on the backs of the workers and employers. It cut back on the benefits and made it more difficult to qualify. It also put a much harsher penalty on those who had quit or those who left for misconduct.
I have no problem with penalizing people who really quit their jobs because they just do not want to work any longer or because they are lazy. I have no problem with penalizing them. I have no problem in penalizing people who truly misbehave. I have no problem when they are truly fired for misconduct.
However, we all know that people quit certain jobs because it is impossible for them to stay in that job. Often it is because of serious personality conflicts with the boss. Sometimes for women it is sexual harassment. Sometimes it is because of other types of harassment and it is the same with misconduct. What one boss will call misconduct an independent arbitration agency may not call misconduct at all.
To leave these people without any unemployment insurance and no improved system to determine whether there is just cause in quitting or whether there was really misconduct or not in being fired is a disgraceful treatment of our unemployed Canadians.
I could talk for a long time about the terrible situation in Montreal but I only have three or four minutes left in this debate. In Canada we face the worst recession since the 1930s with more than 1.5 million Canadians unemployed and 2.3 million on welfare.
Every time the government cuts back on unemployment insurance what does it do? If there were jobs for these people to go to that would be one thing, but when they run out of unemployment insurance and there are no jobs they go on provincial and municipal welfare systems. This government shifts the burden for the unemployed to the provinces and in Ontario and Nova Scotia to the municipalities.
Government Orders
Does that solve the problem? No, it does not. It makes it look good as a government because it says: "We are cutting back programs. We are cutting back staff". In fact the ordinary person in Canada who cannot find a job is shifted from unemployment insurance, which had been in the past a more substantial and a better program, over to provincial welfare schemes.
We still have 2.3 million people on welfare and 3.8 million people living below the poverty line. That includes one million children. We have now in Canada two million people who rely on food banks. Those are the national figures. The figures for Montreal are much worse than the national figures.
In Quebec, for example, the unemployment rate is
11.9	per cent, there are 405,000 people unemployed. Unemployment in Montreal is 11.8 per cent, there are
188,000	people unemployed. Welfare rolls in Quebec are growing at 3,000 persons per month. In Montreal 615,000 people, 15 per cent of the population of greater Montreal, live below the poverty line.
Bankruptcies have hit all-time record highs. The loss of manufacturing jobs and the loss of jobs in transportation and communications, which is a major industry in Montreal, are all at record levels.
I have only a few minutes left and I want to deal with the alternatives. The government asks us: "Well, what are you suggesting in place of what we are doing?" We are saying that we need a mixed economy approach.
This country prospered and the greatest days of prosperity in this country were when we had a wise mix of government action combined with private sector initiative. That was so in the United States.
The philosophy on which this Tory government stands, that the marketplace will take care of everything, has been shown to be a failure. It was shown to be a failure in Britain. It has been a failure in Canada. It has been a failure in the United States. They believe in this trickle-down theory, that if we help the rich, if we help the big businesses, it will trickle down and help the ordinary Canadian. But it has not done that.
The government is cutting jobs right and left, yet it continues on this same track. It will get the same treatment when the election comes that the tired Rea-gan-Bush bunch got in the United States. Government members will be kicked right out on their fannies because the policies they are adopting and continue to follow are wrong. They are wrong. They have been

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
proven wrong on three continents and they had better get the message soon because people are not going to take it any longer.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, when the minister gave his remarks earlier today he said that he wanted to have the differences in philosophy brought out and that is what we certainly just heard.
Now, there clearly is a difference in philosophy between this side of the House and that side. Listening to my hon. friend from Notre-Dame-de-Grace I had difficulty telling the difference between his approach and that of his socialist colleagues a little further down the line. He calls it a mixed economy approach. What he left out was the other part of their economic approach which one might call ahead in the sand approach where they hide from the changes that are taking place in the world.
Now, the approach he advocates, which was the approach taken by the government of which he was a minister, was to drive the deficit as far as possible, drive it right up the line and leave the country burdened with a national debt that we are still trying to cope with.
Now we face a situation where the entire world is in recession. It is interesting to note that in 1988 world economic growth was 4.3 per cent. This year it is down to 1 per cent. Yet, what has been the impact of the approach this government has taken? We are looking at a little bit better growth. The most recent growth in the last quarter was 1.4 per cent. We have the lowest inflation rate of all the G-7 countries. Not bad. I would say he ought to be up commending the minister for that.
Productivity is up 2.6 per cent. That is not bad. Look at trade. They hide from trade policy. What has happened since we brought in the FTA that they so love to disparage?

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Order, please. If the hon. member does not put his question he is not going to get an answer. There is only one minute left.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Very well, Mr. Speaker. The reality is that my friends opposite try to blame the recession on this government and ignore what is going on in the
world. Maybe if I were over there I would too, but I think I have more integrity than that.
One of the things going on in the world is changing trade patterns and globalization. I would like to ask my hon. friend what his solution is for dealing with the new reality, the new globalism that forces countries not to go and hide in the sand, but to get out there and compete? How do we compete if we do not allow businesses to grow so that they can do it?

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, to begin with, of course there is a great difference in philosophy between that side and this side. There is no doubt about that. The minister asked about it this afternoon and there certainly is a difference.
With respect to the recession, yes, I said in my remarks that there is a world recession. But this Tory government did things which deepened the recession and it did them at the wrong time.
I can recall very well when the government brought in the GST. Even those who supported the GST in principle said that it was absolutely the wrong time to bring it in. It would deepen, broaden and stimulate the recession that was on the horizon, but it ignored that advice. I could refer to report after report after report, all of which said not to bring in the GST, not to add to the burden of ordinary consumers and taxpayers at a time when we were going into a recession.
The hon. member boasts about the inflation rate. There is bound to be a low rate of inflation when over 1.5 million Canadians are unemployed and another overwhelming number are on welfare. They do not have any money to buy.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: The hon. member's time has expired. I am going to be very difficult here on time because there are a large number of speakers. The next speaker has 10 minutes, plus five minutes questions and comments. If hon. members hope to get any more than one question they should shorten up their comments and put the question.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am glad to have a chance to speak in this debate on the supplementary borrowing bill that is for some $8 billion. It is interesting that $8 billion is just about exactly the
December 2, 1992

amount by which the Minister of Finance underestimated his deficit.
Having the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology speak tonight was very appropriate because he really is the architect of the recession we have in Canada today.
It is the worst recession since the 1930s and is incredibly much worse than what we suffered in 1981-82. It is a made-in-Canada recession. It is a recession that has been going on now for over 30 months. It is an historic low as far as misery and difficulty for Canadians is concerned.
It was very important to have him here tonight because he went through the same gobbledegook he has been giving us for years with all the placebos the government has been using to talk about the recovery and so on. He described the recovery as being slow. In fact, the recovery is glacial. It really is not occurring at all. Our hope is maybe 1 per cent growth this year. With the growth in the number of people being unemployed it amounts to exactly nothing.
He talks about sound fiscal and monetary policy. Any Minister of Finance who would bring in a free trade deal, then impose the GST, and then hold Canadian interest rates at 4 per cent to 5 per cent above those in the United States and expect Canadian businesses and Canadian manufacturing to be able to cope with that really is living in an Alice in Wonderland world. It is little wonder we have had hundreds and hundreds of thousands of jobs lost during this recessionary period.
It was interesting when the former Minister of Finance spoke about sound fiscal and monetary policy. When this government came to power in the fall of 1984 Canada was launched on the greatest period of expansion in our history with six years of unprecedented growth.
The government loves to talk about deficits and how it has reduced the deficit. In fact, it has brought in 33 new tax measures during the period of 1984 to 1990. That includes the GST which cost almost $2 billion just to implement. Talk about spending money. This government certainly knows how to do it.
In any event, the minister talked about a sound fiscal and monetary policy. Yet during that period 1984 to 1990 the deficit doubled. Of course since 1990 it has been totally downhill. This is the worst recession since the 1930s. Look at the measures the government has put before the House today. Obviously ii these measures
Government Orders
were of any consequence they should have been brought in at least 18 months ago. It is talking about spending $500 million for a capital works program. It estimates it will create some 5,000 jobs over a two-year period.
In one community in my riding, Elliot Lake, we have lost 3,400 heavy industrial mining jobs. We have lost at least another 1,600, perhaps 2,000. This infrastructure program that the government puts before us will create the equivalent of the number of jobs that have been lost in one relatively small city of 13,000, Elliot Lake in my riding, over the next two years.
Can we imagine? The government suggests that program is going to have any economic impact at all on the country is just about zip, just about equivalent to nothing. Granted there are some projects over the course of the five years of the program but clearly the next two years are the most important because we have to get out of this recession.
I do not think anybody will dispute that northern Ontario has had the brunt of this recession. Whether we are talking about the export tax the government imposed on softwood which has lost thousands of jobs, whether we look at the mining industry where we have lost at least 25 per cent of all the mining jobs in northeastern Ontario during the last three or four years or whether we look at the steel industry in Sault Ste. Marie which has gone from about 12,000 jobs 10 years ago to around 5,000 today, northern Ontario has clearly been hit more drastically than any other place.
As we look through this infrastructure program, we see that the only projects in Ontario are two projects at terminal one and terminal two at Pearson International Airport in Toronto. Clearly Ontario is left out of the whole project. It is not even clear from the data that the Minister of Finance made available today whether any of that money is even government money. It talks about paving the runway. It talks about reconstructing terminal one and terminal two but they are doing it in the private sector. It looks like Ontario, and clearly northern Ontario, gets absolutely nothing out of this infrastructure program.
My leader put forward a billion dollar program for municipal infrastructure, for sewer and water and municipal projects which would be shared three ways. The billion dollars that the federal government would put in would be matched by the provincial and municipal

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
governments. There would be projects in every community.
The most important, active and busiest of buildings perhaps in Canada, Pearson International Airport, is where the money is going for this program.
In 1981 and 1982 we had a massive infrastructure program, a lot of airports, marinas, pipelines and projects throughout the country which really jolted the Canadian economy back into the prosperity which we enjoyed from 1984 to 1990. This program is simply too little and certainly too late by at least a year and a half. It should have been brought in a long time ago.
There are a couple of programs for small business which will be useful such as the 10 per cent investment tax credit. Most of the other projects and programs are extensions of existing programs such as the Small Businesses Loans Act and the small business financing program about which the minister of small business has already said the banks are sitting on their assets and are not really doing that much for Canadians.
This program that has been put forward today will have very little impact on the economy. At the same time, those thousands of people who are living on unemployment insurance are facing a drastic cutback of 3 per cent in their benefits. Others will lose out on their benefits.
It is certainly not a statement that is going to pick up the Canadian economy, put many people back to work, and get us out of this recession that we have been suffering from for the last 30 months.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened very carefully to the hon. member's comments and I think he made an unfortunate error. Perhaps it was an oversight, but he did say that our government doubled the deficit since we have been in office. If he thought about that again he would probably want to correct that. That is not correct.
Second, I take it from his comments, and I think I heard him correctly, that he likes the statement but it should have been brought forward earlier. I appreciate
his support in that regard. I suppose it is better late than never.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the statement is so anaemic that the impact in most areas of this country-clearly the infrastructure program will have no effect. There will certainly be no joy in my riding. There will not be one road rebuilt, not be one new sewer line constructed, no town hall built and no people will be put to work there. There is no provision in the program for new direct employment programs such as the massive programs that were provided in the winter of 1982 when we faced the last recession.
Clearly the program is so anaemic that it will have practically no impact, especially in my constituency. We have people who are facing unemployment. We had
1,000	workers laid off last spring. The budget for the employment and immigration department in Elliot Lake in my constituency was cut from $2.5 million last year to some $600,000 this year. The department finally said that it would provide some training for some 75 workers and then it cancelled it and said that the local community had to come up with a quarter of the money, some $200,000, or there would not be any training money.
For the future there are no additional funds. The minister is simply not providing funds that I see will reduce the unemployment in my constituency by any amount this year. When the government was talking about a massive infrastructure program it talked originally of $2 billion and said that this would dip down into every community. In Ontario it is dipping down to provide something, we think, at the Pearson International Airport. For people living in the Algoma riding fixing Pearson International Airport does not have much impact on the unemployed on Manitoulin Island or in the north shore communities.
The recession has been unnecessarily long and deep because the government has had a tight fiscal policy. It has increased taxes with 33 different new taxes, including the GST, during the last eight years. It has kept interest rates so high that we have for the first time a made-in-Canada recession. All economists say that we have borne down so hard on the taxes in this country and the interest rates are so high that although inflation has been lower economic growth is just about zero.
December 2, 1992

At the same time the Minister of Finance brings in a budget only nine or ten months later and he has miscalculated by 25 per cent. He talked about $28 billion last February and today he is talking about $34 billion. It is little wonder that the deficit of $179 billion in 1984 has skyrocketed to over $400 billion today. The minister is right that the deficit has not just doubled, it has more than doubled during that eight-year period.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it gives me a sense of pride and privilege to have the opportunity to participate in this debate.
I think the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance has come into this House today with a great deal of courage and a great sense of responsibility, as is true to his character and his record. He addressed a situation that is extremely difficult. He had to tell this House that the finances of this country have deteriorated from an estimated deficit of $27.5 billion in February of this year to an estimate of close to $35 billion in the coming year and down only slightly in the following year. I wondered how he would do that because it is an extremely difficult task.
The realities are that his estimates in February for
1992-	93 and 1993-94 were based on the best information available at the time, based on a world economy we estimated had recovered from the trough of the recession. However, it has continued to lag and linger to the point that economic growth in this fiscal year will be 1 per cent. As one hon. member said earlier, that basically amounts to moving sideways.
Therefore, the budget deficit of $27.5 billion which had been forecast for 1992-93 is going to come in at $34.4 billion. It has resulted almost entirely from a shortage of anticipated revenue. As a matter of fact, the change in that budget position as a result of policy actions announced in February and today is actually a reduction of $700 million, obviously not nearly sufficient to offset the revenue reduction of $8 billion and the other public charges that accrue from that. The same is true for
1993-	94 when the estimated deficit is now going to be close to $10 billion more than it was estimated to be in February of this year.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Fire your financial analyst.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
It is not as the hon. member says so glibly: "Fire your financial analyst". It is a case of dealing with a
Government Orders
world in which the financial climate has become very stormy and unpredictable and very difficult to deal with.
I would like to use an analogy. I have had some experience in flying aeroplanes. Sometimes there are storms you just cannot predict and it is important to practice the fundamentals. It is important to keep your eyes on the instruments and keep your destination in mind and fly on the fundamentals. The finance minister and this government have flown well on the fundamentals. One great one has been the rate of inflation. The rate of inflation has been brought to 1.5 per cent, the lowest among all industrialized G-7 countries. That is a fundamental that will stand us in great stead as we commence to emerge from this recession. Another fundamental has been the control of government expenditures. This has been a direction which Canadians have prevailed upon us to take for many years now. This is a demand which the government has addressed and to which it has responded.
In the midst of these dramatically large deficits and constantly growing debt it is hard to keep a perspective on the fundamentals. The facts are that this government and this finance minister and his predecessor for the past eight years have kept the rate of growth in government spending at an average of perhaps only 3.9 per cent. I quote from an article in the Fraser Forum of November 1992 in which the author, Ken Gregory, points out that for the 15 years prior to 1984 governments were spending at a rate of growth on programs of close to 14 per cent. That figure has now been reduced to less than 4 per cent in the past eight years.
The result has been another tremendously important move in the fundamentals. The program operating account of the Government of Canada has been turned from a deficit of close to $16 billion in 1983-84 to a surplus of $10 billion in 1991-92. That is a turnaround of $26 billion in the program operating account.
It means that in the area of discretionary spending the government has exercised management of the fundamentals. Unfortunately the areas of debt, debt service costs and economic contribution of our revenues, the areas that are beyond our control, have come to us in unpredictable turbulence as a result of this stormy and

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
difficult economic world climate. We can only deal with them as responsibly and as well as we can.
As I say, to use the flying analogy, we must keep our eyes glued to the instruments. We must stay the course. We must not ever forget the destination which is ultimately and hopefully in this decade a balanced budget and the beginning of the repayment of our national debt.
Canada's economic progress has been slowed by a stubborn world-wide recession. The pressures of the new global economic insecurity marked by restructuring and job dislocation have made recovery and growth painfully slow. The government's priority is to continue to build confidence, to enhance the beginnings and finally the fulfilment of recovery, and to create jobs. Its priority challenge is to help Canadians adjust to economic change and to take advantage of the opportunity which it brings.
That is why the wide-ranging initiatives announced by the finance minister today are designed to bolster public and private investment in economic growth while also reducing the cost of government. These actions build on the policies I have described which are already increasing Canadian productivity and competitiveness and are producing fundamental stability in the areas that are so important.
I would like to highlight some key actions as outlined by the finance minister this afternoon. He talked about support for small business. Canada's federal tax system for small business is one of the most favourable in the world. The small business sector is under serious financial and competitive pressure. To help spur growth in jobs the government is launching a special small business employment and investment package.
There was a publication in Atlantic Canada by ACOA last week that talked about the importance of small business. While it pointed out that most employment still resides with large companies 90 per cent of new jobs come from small business. If we are to achieve growth and if we are to solve our unemployment problems small business is the area of our economic sector that we simply must address. Under this package announced today most small businesses will be able to add new workers without paying additional unemployment insurance employer premiums in 1993. This will reduce the
cost of hiring additional workers by up to $1,600 per worker. Other actions in the small business area include a 10 per cent small business investment tax credit for machinery and eligible equipment purchases.
The rules on investment in small businesses by RRSPs and other funds will be simplified and investment options will be expanded. Programs that provide financial assistance are being expanded or extended.
Second, this afternoon the finance minister has addressed the challenge and the compelling imperative of research and development. Research and development is key to developing the new products and processes that deliver competitive success and growth in a global marketplace. Canada, as a trading nation, must be competitive in that world marketplace.
We offer the most generous tax incentives for business research and development of any major industrialized country and we have now introduced modifications to streamline and improve the system, which were promised in the budget of February 1992. These changes will provide additional support of $230 million over the next five years.
There are still areas where the tax rules could be improved to help business adapt and grow in an era of knowledged-based work and technological change. An example is the tax treatment of equipment such as computers that become obsolete so quickly as new technology emerges.
The government is examining further modifications to the tax system to solve these problems. It has set aside $400 million over the next five years to remove tax-based impediments to innovation and growth. We will also increase funding for the Industrial Research Assistance Program and will extend further the funding for longterm research, which builds on the best of the results achieved under the network of the centres of excellence program.
Another key area addressed by the Minister of Finance this afternoon is that of training and adjustment. It is increasingly necessary in a knowledged-based economy that Canada's economic prospects be bolstered by the skills of our people. The federal government is helping to meet this challenge with its support for worker training and adjustment being increased to $3.8 billion next year. As part of this, funds for developmental
December 2, 1992

training under the UI program will go to $2.2 billion from $1.9 billion last year and just $500 million in 1990.
The government will also help workers and employers make learning and skills upgrading a constant priority. Priority will be placed on developing occupational standards so the training will be relevant to real needs. The government will provide $250 million over five years to help lever a national training effort driven by labour and business. It will develop tax incentives to help defray the costs of training workers to meet these occupational standards.
Another area addressed this afternoon by the finance minister is in the construction and resources sectors. This extends the successful home buyers plan introduced in the February budget where people can use their RRSP savings to help finance a home. This is being extended by another year to end on March 1, 1994.
We have also increased the tax write-off for junior oil and gas companies from 30 per cent to 100 per cent on the first $2 million of Canadian development expenses that are flowed through to investors. The Income Tax Act will be amended to provide more flexibility for oil and gas companies and mining companies to utilize non-capital losses.
One of the most exciting areas announced this afternoon is the new investment in Canada's infrastructure. Certainly for me, and other members of Parliament on both sides of the House from Atlantic Canada, the announcement of direct contributions at the rate of $200 million per year over the next five years to help with Atlantic projects is tremendously encouraging. This will go toward the Atlantic expressway and the completion of engineering and the commencement of construction of the Prince Edward Island fixed link that begins in the spring of next year
The nation's infrastructure, which includes national assets such as our highway system, communications and transportation of all types, can provide an important competitive advantage in the new global economy. Based on savings in other activities the government will commit an additional $500 million to pursue specific strategic investment opportunities across the country over the next five years that will total $2 billion and directly generate 4,000 to 5,000 jobs each year. As well, the
Government Orders
Minister of Finance has addressed government efficiency. The government has worked hard in the past, as I have described already, to reduce the costs of government and to streamline its operations. As a result, the real cost of government after inflation is now 20 per cent less than it was in 1984-85.
The minister has also talked about easing the tax burden. The February budget announced cuts in personal income taxes applying to all Canadians. It also included measures to ease the tax burden on the important manufacturing and processing sectors of our economy.
Despite the pressures of the deficit the government will proceed with the second phase of tax cuts planned for 1993. These and other measures, such as the new child tax benefit, will provide some $2 million in economic stimulus next year. The government will also hold 1993 unemployment insurance premium rates for both employees and employers to 1992 levels.
We will continue with action to control the deficit. The deficit is a remarkable and devastating challenge. The key to deficit reduction is spending control. I have already outlined how, over the past eight years, this government has a record of spending control on programs that is three times, perhaps four times, as effective as the predecessor governments of the previous 15 years.
In this statement today the spending control measures announced will save nearly $8 billion over the balance of this fiscal year and the following two years. Here are some of the measures: For two years salaries will be frozen for public servants and Crown corporations will have proportional reductions made in their operating budgets. Salaries will be frozen for two years for the Governor General, the Prime Minister and all members of Parliament. Operating budgets of government departments will be cut by 3 per cent in 1993-94 and combined with the wage freeze federal operating budgets will be 5 per cent lower than planned levels over the next two fiscal years.
Following on the heels of the record of the past eight years that is a remarkable commitment indeed.
I would like to finish by saying that while these are discouraging times Canada really is not a country to be easily discouraged about.

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
Over the weekend I had the opportunity to take a look at a new book by Peter Newman entitled Canada 1892, Portrait of a Promised Land. In the concluding pages he draws parallels between 1892 and 1992, 100 years later, and they are surprisingly similar. One hundred years ago Canadians felt that the 20th century would belong to them and as we look into the 21st century, despite the difficult challenges we face, I have no doubt that everyone in this Elouse has an even stronger conviction that Canada's time has come.
In 1892, as in 1992, those did not seem like impossible dreams. Yet the country was still very young, as we are now, still very large, still very diverse in both geographic and cultural terms, still an extremely difficult country to govern and still, particularly in current economic times, an extremely difficult country to stimulate economically and to manage financially.
Sir Wilfrid Laurier asked 100 years ago: "How long will the fabric last or will the fabric hold at all?" Yet, as Newman says, in surprising ways Canada has hardly changed in the last 100 years. Most of the concerns animating Canadians in 1892 are still with us and our hope must lie in the fact that however threatening these problems might have been they did not daunt us. We are still here to argue and implement the solutions.
He is right. That is what the finance minister has done with courage and responsibility and foresight this afternoon. He has addressed those problems. They did not daunt our forefathers then. They do not daunt us now. We shall meet the challenges we face. We shall solve the problems that beset us. We shall fulfil the promise that the future offers this great land and we shall do it together.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to start off by saying that I respect the member for Fredericton-York-Sunbury. I listened to his remarks carefully. I do not want to be perceived as being negative in any way, shape or form. We are trying to be responsible here.
I want to focus on that part of his speech that referred to small business. I think that the Minister of Finance did a good thing when he increased the Small Businesses Loans Act from $200,000 to $250,000. I understand that eligibility for this small business loan may go from fixed assets to possibly working capital. That is a gesture of
understanding toward the needs of the million-odd small businesses in this country.
I want to say two things. One, we have taken almost a year to pass the legislation on the Small Businesses Loans Act, which all parties in this House supported. I hope that the amendment from $200,000 to $250,000 does not create further delay.
Having said that, my greater concern is the fact that most of the branch offices of the major financial institutions in this country are not aware of the Small Businesses Loans Act and what it means. I hear from many businesses across the country that when they go to their bank managers they are not aware of this legislation. They are not aware of the program.
I am wondering what the government will do to make sure that the intention of this amendment and the basic loans act that the Minister of Finance presented on the floor of the House today to the people of Canada will actually be implemented for the million-odd small businesses in this country.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, that is an excellent question. I think the Minister of Finance this afternoon addressed that in very profound style. First of all, he called upon the banks of this country to get with it, heed the challenge of small business and to support it. He said it explicitly and clearly and I doubt that call could be ignored.
He also talked in his concluding statement about the need for partnerships, not just with the federal government and the provincial governments, but partnerships with business, labour, financial institutions and all Canadians.
We are in this together. This deficit circumstance in which we find ourselves is as a result, as I said, of turbulent economic times over which the world is having difficulty controlling.
In response to the question raised by the hon. member, it is clear that if we are to use the measure, the Small Businesses Loans Act that was amplified this afternoon, bankers have to start taking it seriously, but well beyond that, they have to start taking small business seriously. They have to start investing in the potential that exists. They have to start sharing the risk more fully than they may be prone to do.
December 2, 1992

I am not in this statement knocking the banks. I am just amplifying the call to partnership that must exist among all Canadians. I think the Minister of Finance has made that call very clearly and very well today.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I hope that the member's statement will come to reality. I am not saying this to be anything other than concerned. So often I have heard the Minister of State for Small Businesses state that this is a problem. I have heard the Minister of Finance state before that he will address this issue.
I hope for the hundreds of thousands of small businesses that really want to use this piece of legislation that his commitment will be lived up to.
My second question concerns that portion of the budget speech that deals with the unemployment insurance amendment. We read in the minister's speech that the unemployment insurance fund is going to be amended so that if someone is fired for what the employer would define as just cause that particular person is not eligible for unemployment insurance, or if someone quits on his or her own volition he or she does not get access to unemployment insurance.
I personally think that is a pretty extreme amendment. I just do not know where the government is coming from on that particular amendment. The member comes from business. I know he is a successful business person. There may be situations that could crop up where people may be put into a position where they either want to leave because they cannot live with the condition or for what is just cause. For these people not to have access to that unemployment insurance fund is a pretty Draconian amendment. I wonder if he could comment on that.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT

Mr. Speaker, I am surprised to hear the hon. member raise this in the context that he does because I share the respect for the hon. member that he has expressed for myself and which I appreciate.
It almost sounds as though he is using this significant element of the minister's statement today as a political crutch. He is talking about the situation as though the glass were half empty instead of half full.
One of the greatest complaints that I hear throughout my constituency and this country is about abuse of the
Government Orders
unemployment insurance program, of people quitting jobs because they do not like them, they do not like to work so hard at them or they want to take a holiday and they want to do it on the basis of the unemployment insurance program.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to join the debate. It comes at a very relevant moment, given the last exchange between the member on our side who well understands the need of the unemployed and the poor in this country and the members on the government side who have been sitting there for just too many months and too many years. They have lost track of what they are supposed to be doing here as a government.

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
I would like to take us back in time just one week.
One week ago in this House we were raising questions on poverty. The National Council on Welfare brought to our attention the extent to which poverty has grown in this country. It noted that in some job areas, such as the service industry, 60 per cent of the people employed are living below the poverty line. It noted that in Manitoba
173,000	people now live in poverty.
These statistics were from before the recession began. It is now estimated that over 200,000 people in Manitoba are living in poverty.
Just take that report of last week, from a government agency, and then look at this budget. It is a budget. It is a pre-election budget. Does this government spend one minute addressing the issue of the poor and the questions raised only a week ago? No. Instead it built a budget around the prejudices of the people who think that there is such a thing as an undeserving poor.
One of the great arguments the opposition has against the child benefit package, and what annoyed us to no end, is that the government built on the assumption that those who are on social assistance, those who are under CAP, are somehow or other not as deserving of support as those who are working.
No one denies that people who work deserve every break. However, to make the other assumption in the depths of a recession, which in some parts of this country is a depression, that there are people who cannot find work and that they should be treated differently than those who can find work is a perversion of our history of being progressive in social policy.
This government and this minister have to be challenged on this statement today of continuing that distinction. This time it has seeped into the UI program. For the first time the government is saying that those who have quit, have severed from a job, are somehow or other to be treated differently even though they paid into the fund for years and even though we do not know why they separated from a company. Members of this House know that there are 101 reasons why people leave a company. These reasons are never stated. The act right now provides for that to happen in a polite fashion.
Now we are opening up a whole series of problems which have no need to be addressed. This government is making a distinction again between the so-called deserving poor and the undeserving poor. It needs to be challenged on this right here, today, and for the next few weeks over this legislation.
This is perhaps one of the most cynical documents that has been presented by a very cynical government. This was its opportunity, again heading in to a very tough winter, of saying to Canadians: We have finally gotten the message about what sort of situation we are in.
There has been all sorts of chatter in the public and it is no secret that there has been discussion of an infrastructure program. People representing municipalities in this country have come forward with ideas, not wild-eyed schemes, that can be implemented in the short term where the regulatory processes are set up so that they can get people to work over the winter. This government looked at them, turned around and walked away.
Take the example of western Canada. We all know that municipalities in western Canada have asked for a number of different ways to rebuild their infrastructure. We also know that across the country there has been a discussion about a roads program. What does this government say? It said it will provide funding for construction in New Brunswick and Nova Scotia for the Atlantic freeway. In western Canada there has been an enhancement of roads in national parks.
What is really meant when we read through all the documents, is that the Alberta members want to make sure that, to fight off the Reform Party, their roads in the national parks are rebuilt. Manitoba is not even mentioned. The commercial highways across western Canada are not mentioned.
Nothing is being done to rebuild the infrastructure. For example, in Winnipeg, where the core initiative has consistently been presented as a continuation of a first class infrastructure program, the government has ignored it and has pretended it did not exist.
Instead of having an attack on the basic questions of this country, the questions of poverty and of finding work, this government has ducked behind the language of its right wing ghost and wants to resurrect in the public's mind that it is concerned about the deficit. It has single-handedly created more debt in this country than
December 2, 1992

we as a government were able to do in over 100 years. It managed to do that in eight years and then turn around after bankrupting the country and say: "We cannot help the poor; we are bankrupt". The guilt of the world is not upon us; it is upon the government. It deserves to pay the price for the hardship, the agony and the disruption of people's lives by continually undermining the confidence of this country.
This document does not rebuild confidence. It digs us into a deeper hole. As Canadians we have to give this government a message. Obviously what we see today is a government spending hundreds of millions of dollars to buy time. The government is going to start it in motion by punishing public servants as soon as possible by maintaining wage caps. It is then going to start with promises of getting involved with an infrastructure. It will probably tell us in the spring that it does not need a budget right away while it buys more time. As it gets more prepared for an election it will try to spring some other programs on us.
The reality is that the government is not going to be successful in an election. Someone else will come in, and instead of having a program that can be built upon we will have to dismantle all the assumptions of this government, dismantle all the destruction, tear apart the way that it has tried to ruin the infrastructure of this country and start rebuilding. It is going to take a long time before Canadians can look at a government and ask: "Are you really going to help us or are you going to continue to stand in the way of our trying to earn an income?"
There are other notes in this document that have not yet been addressed in the debate. The government discusses in a very ominous tone the Canada Student Loans Program and indicates that its revision, its "new financial arrangement", is expected to lower costs. Whenever I hear the government saying that it is to do more for social justice by lowering costs it just makes me shiver. Any time I have heard that before it has meant tougher conditions and that students somehow or another pay the price.
The government uses wonderful language. It is asking financial institutions to share in the burden of student debt. Has anyone ever met a bank manager when he is sharing the burden? They are wonderful sharers of debt. They sometimes open up their doors and talk at great
Government Orders
length but in the end they are not negotiations in the language we have here.
If we look at the details in the economic and fiscal statement on page 15, who is it reducing grants to? In international assistance it is going to claim back $300 million. Does it turn to the richest people in the country, the richest people in the world? No, it turns to the poor people of the world. It is not only the poor in Canada who have to pay the price of this government; it is the poor around the world. Also, through Bill C-91 and what the government is trying to do there it is going to take away their inexpensive drugs and is going to add hundreds of millions of dollars to the world health bill.
What kind of strategy is that? We are almost at the anniversary of that famous day when the Prime Minister went out and patted children on the head and said how concerned he was. Is this the anniversary document? Is this another reference point that he wants to use in his legacy to the country?
It is also cutting back and saving money, $125 million, in regional development. What does that mean for western diversification?
The green plan is going to pay a price. I do not even know whether the green plan has actually ever started, but we know now that the government is going to cut it back. We also know that the government is going to take money away from aboriginal groups. On the one hand, we were congratulating aboriginal leaders in the last year for making such fine progress and being such great builders of the country, and then it turns around and says: "Now that you are not looking we are going to take away $28 million".
The contradictions in this document are endless. It was presented to us in a low key way, pretending that the media would not pay attention to the major changes taking place. But we in this opposition caught on right away. This is a destructive document that we will fight. These last four weeks have seen more destructive pieces of legislation presented to the House of Commons than ever before in our history. If it is a government in preparation for an election, it has a very perverse notion of what this nation is all about, and I can only wish it luck in this presentation.



December 2, 1992
Government Orders
However, there are alternatives. We have consistently said there are ways of approaching the debt and ways of approaching the infrastructure and ways of rebuilding confidence. There are organizations that have long since worked for social justice in this country. For example, just a few minutes ago I heard from the National Anti-Poverty Organization and it can only declare its disappointment and dissatisfaction with the government for not being willing to deal with the questions of how to feed Canadians and house the homeless.
enough income to survive, to pay the rent, to pay their groceries, to-
