I end on this note. If you cannot once a year stand up and acknowledge that as a country we no longer feed people and we no longer house them then what has this Parliament come to?

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: I would like to ask the hon. member for Winnipeg North Centre to expand a little on the welfare aspect because I think this is important, considering the prevailing depression atmosphere as the hon. member said, because this is not just a recession. So could he expand a little on the welfare issue?

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member for Winnipeg North Centre deserves to be commended for his excellent speech, which condemned the government's mini budget. As he pointed out, this budget is a disaster, a perversion and anti-Canadian in every sense of the word. The hon. member, who has always shown a keen interest in social welfare issues, saw today that what we have here is a financial catastrophe for the neediest and poorest members of the community.
Take unemployment insurance, for instance. A few months ago the Liberal Party voted against a bill that was passed by the government. The legislation introduced drastic changes in the benefits the unemployed were receiving from the Unemployment Insurance Commission. The government changed the legislation, so that from now on, unemployment insurance premiums will be paid only by the employer and the employee. This means the government is no longer contributing to unemployment insurance benefits.
Today, the government announced that even if employees were now contributing more, without the government's assistance, the UI benefit rate for new beneficiaries would be reduced from 60 per cent to 57 per cent. And we all know that in Canada the number of unemployed is now 1.5 million, and I am referring to those who are receiving unemployment insurance benefits. We also know that 2.3 million Canadians are on welfare. This means that 3.8 million adults in this country, at least most of them, have no jobs and not

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I wish to thank the hon. member for Carleton-Gloucester for his comments and his question.

The reality is that if one looks at the change in the level that a person on unemployment is able to receive, the reduction from 60 per cent to 57 per cent, is a decrease of 3 per cent on paper, but in reality a 5 per cent decrease. We take the poorest people, give them a 5 per cent pay cut and say: "To what extent does that contribute to the stability of a family? How does that make people feel, after working and getting into unusual circumstances they now get a 5 per cent cut?"
The reason we have unemployment insurance is that we make the assumption in this country that most people want to work. I was very interested in the commentary by the member from New Brunswick who made the insinuation that the rules had to be changed because people were quitting UI. It was a very unusual comment he made. I see my time is up.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise this evening to speak against the Minister of Finance's mini budget. Yes, I am against this government's budget, and that is what it is. It is a budget put together in a panic when the Minister of Finance realized his earlier projections were way off base.
December 2, 1992

Regrettably, the actions he proposes in this flawed document today will not position our country for the future. I fear it will continue to lead us further down the path to fiscal disaster. This government has been leading us down that road ever since it decided to stay the course.
Canadians will not be fooled any more by this government. Canadians, including those in my region, have learned that this government cannot be trusted to manage its economic affairs. It certainly is not the government to lead us through the rest of the 1990s.
As an Atlantic Canadian I know the impact this government has had in my own province of Prince Edward Island. I know the people of that province reject out of hand this government's whole economic program.
The tax increases have been unprecedented in magnitude since 1984. The increase in the tax burden in Canada was by far the largest among the G-7 countries, yet our deficit continues to rise. This is a government which took great pride in being competent managers, yet the decline in the economy has meant that despite the massive tax increases the deficit is now out of control.
The only way the government can fight the deficit and bring Canada back to its foremost place among the world economies is to finally set about creating those jobs, jobs, jobs that it has long promised.
Encouraging new jobs through small business is unreal. The cap the minister has just announced on UI premiums will not foster these jobs. The ceiling for loans to small firms under the Small Businesses Loans Act will not help small businesses.
Investing in people is a familiar buzz phrase to all Canadians. Canada's economic prospects depend more and more on the skills of its people and the government should pay heed to that. Where is the retraining, the educational development, the research, the development that has long been promised by this government? Why do we not have a long-term plan to help Canadians gain the competitive edge that this government has long been talking about?
In the interim, what about the long awaited infrastructure program that, while creating much needed jobs in
Government Orders
the short term, would give Canada its much needed infrastructure improvement in the long term?
What we received from the government today was another half measure, point one-tenth of a per cent in our Canadian economy. Shame. Shame. The government is not even replacing one-half of the jobs cut at CN Rail with this feeble effort.
Today we hear more political platitudes. We hear again how well the government is doing in fighting the deficit. Today we hear again all those tired old phrases which are designed to convince the people of Canada that the Minister of Finance knows what he is doing.
The people in my part of the country know better. The people in Atlantic Canada have not done well under this government. I stated many times that the deficit cannot be fought on the backs of the poorest regions and the poorest people of this country. We deserve the same access to government programs and services as the rest of Canada and it is time for this government to realize that.
I hope the people of Atlantic Canada realize that all of the good things promised to them have evaporated during the depths of this recession. There seems little in the minister's statement which would give us further hope.
I do congratulate the minister on his announcement concerning engineering and environmental work on the Prince Edward Island fixed-link crossing which is to be undertaken so that the project can go ahead in the spring of 1993. However, the government is still not saying it is definitely a go. One of the bidders was asked tonight on television if they were drinking champagne. They said that no they were not. They do not know yet.
However, I am pleased that the federal government has removed some of the uncertainty which has long surrounded this project. We will now have to carefully examine the details announced by the minister in order to determine that all of the environmental and financial conditions have been met. I am also anxious to see if the conditions outlined by Premier Ghiz have been met.
I caution the minister not to think that if this project goes ahead it will cure all of the ills of that part of the country. We will still be looking for strong government support as we attempt to bring our area up to the economic standards of the rest of Canada.

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
It is obvious that the favourite whipping boys of this government are the Public Service and public programs. Over the years this government has distinguished itself by beating Canadians over the head with more and more radical spending cuts.
Let me give some of those cuts. The green plan is cut by $172 million, regional and industrial programs are cut by $346 million, native programs are cut by $135 million, and there are cuts in grants and subsidies to most non-profit organizations. There are cuts totalling $1.8 billion.
It seems ironic that this minister is still at war with the government he and his party have led for the last eight years. Ever since this government was elected it has talked about its managerial abilities and the need to reduce the deficit.
Well, the deficit the government inherited has much more than doubled despite dozens of tax increases, including the GST. The deficit projections for the coming year show that its level of management is appalling. Its eight years in power have been marked by an ever decreasing economic performance in this country and its attempts to blame someone else are shameful.
The Minister of Finance and the other members of this government seem to believe that they can somehow convince the Canadian people that prosperity will flow only if they can attack and lay off a few more civil servants and assault the unemployed.
The Minister of Finance has decided that Canadians who lose their jobs will now get reduced unemployment benefits and Canadians who quit their jobs will no longer get unemployment benefits. This is not the answer.
People in all parts of Canada deserve the support that and can only come from a competent, well-trained, dedicated civil service. The people who work for the Government of Canada are second to none. I know that the people of Canada do not find these recurring attacks on our public servants a very suitable way to address the economic problems.
I look upon this financial statement, this mini budget in reality, this budget of my good friend the Minister of Finance with utter and sheer contempt. He comes before this House in a panic because he has been unable
to project within $7 billion how much the deficit of this country is going to be.
He, the Prime Minister, and the former Minister of Finance have staked a great deal of their reputations and the reputation of this government on their expertise. The economy of this country is in a shambles. The reputation of the government is in tatters.
I would hope that this government will soon have the courage to face the Canadian people and allow them to pass judgment on this terrible economic record.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask the member across the way if he understands that with the operating costs of running this government in 1984 when we came into power we inherited $16 billion in the red. That is, we are overpaying by that much. The $16 billion was added onto the debt every year.
Since we have been in power we have reduced that $16 billion. We are down now. We are not in the red; we are in the black. Those are the operating costs of running this government. We are down now to between $6 billion and $8 billion below the line. So we have decreased the cost.
If people running a household are over budget they have to cut their costs. They just do not have that much money to spend, so they cut. It has been done, but every year anything over that which is the interest, compound interest is added to that rising debt which we inherited. It is a devil of a thing to stop its growth. Unfortunately, we have had a bad couple of years of recession, high unemployment and other costs which have added to that. Normally, had it gone on in the way we had anticipated, we would have been able to have stopped the growth of the debt. We are now in a position to do this with this new budget.
I would like to ask the member across the way, because I think this was the first statement today by the Minister of Finance, what would the opposition do in order to help this situation?

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank my hon. colleague for expressing her concerns and asking me my opinion.
The Conservatives inherited a debt, a debt which has continued to increase over the last eight years. We have seen several tax increases that were supposedly going to
December 2, 1992

reduce this deficit. The debt and the deficit have not been reduced. However, we cannot use this old cliche of reducing the deficit at the cost of the poorer people of this country. I believe and I know this is what has gone on and on and on.
There have been tax increases. There has been the GST. Yet the debt and the deficit continue to rise. Yes, we have to get it under control. There is the financial deficit out there that we need to get under control. But I have heard people say that there is also a moral deficit out there. We have to bring that under control too.
There are more than 1.5 million people unemployed and there are people on welfare. We have to put the country back to work. We as members of Parliament have to give the people of this country the confidence that the government across the way will start this economy rolling again. The infrastructure program that was announced today is not enough.
I assume the government is waiting for the new President of the United States to start its economy rolling and hopefully this one will tag along behind it.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to repeat the question that my colleague has asked him and ask specifically what would he do?
I am very surprised to hear an hon. member and a colleague I respect from Prince Edward Island damn a project of $800 million with faint praise such as he speaks of the fixed-link crossing. Frankly, I thought he would have regarded that as almost a miracle in this budget. There is almost nothing to match it in the way of a financial commitment right across the country. I cannot imagine anything that will have a more profound effect on the economy of the Atlantic region than that project and the similar commitment to the Trans-Canada Highway and the Atlantic expressway.
I heard the hon. member list the expenditure cuts in the Public Service. Most of the constituents I serve, and I am sure most of the constituents that he serves, constantly urge that government be reduced in size and that the federal government particularly gain control of its operations. He has criticized that. He has not proposed new revenue measures that would offset expenditure cuts.
Government Orders
I just have to ask the member and his party what they would do if they would not cut expenditures. They are not really very happy with $800 million capital works projects in their own ridings. They do not have any other revenue areas of contribution to offer. What would they do except wring their hands and criticize?

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to join in the debate on the economic and financial statement made by the Minister of Finance today, in economic circumstances that are extremely trying for Canadians.
The Liberal member who just spoke told us that we were doing very little and that this was not the way to deal with Canada's economic problems. However, these problems are due to the fact that we are in a world-wide recession and have only limited resources to fight off its effects. I say limited because Canada has gone into debt, especially since the seventies and the early eighties, to a rather irresponsible extent. Today, they tell us we often use this excuse. Unfortunately we do not have more room to manoeuvre because we spent too much. We have been spending irresponsibly for years, and today, with what resources we have, we are trying to turn around a situation that has gotten out of hand. We have a very high unemployment rate and, I repeat, very little room to manoeuvre.
In his statement, however, the Minister of Finance has offered a way to help Canadians and to restore their confidence in our economy by investing in growth. Of course, our economic progress has been slowed by a stubborn, world-wide recession. Tensions typical of a new world economy weakened by economic restructuring and job displacement have considerably weakened recovery and growth.
The government's priority is to build confidence, enhance recovery, create jobs and help Canadians adjust through this period of transition and take advantage of new opportunities. That is why we have announced a broad range of measures to stimulate public and private investment and economic growth, while cutting back on the cost of government activities. If we want to invest in economic recovery for the sake of growth we cannot afford to raise taxes because we are already overtaxed, and we cannot afford to increase the deficit because it is already far too high. These measures are supported by

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
policies that are already helping to enhance productivity and Canada's ability to compete.
I would also like to emphasize some of the main initiatives described in the minister's economic and financial statement. First of all, support for small business, which is the primary engine of our economy. Canada's federal tax system for small business is one of the most favourable in the world. Compared to the United States, our tax rates are lower. Canadian small businesses enjoy a special deduction that reduces their federal income tax rate to 12.8 per cent, including the 3 per cent surtax, on the first $200,000 of business income. In the United States, federal tax rates for small business range from 15 to 39 per cent in the same bracket.
Canadian small businesses which are incorporated also qualify for the most generous incentives for research and development in the G-7 countries. In particular, let us mention a 35 per cent refundable federal income tax credit, replacing a general 20 per cent credit, that enables small businesses to receive funds directly.
The cumulative capital gains exemption encourages individuals to invest in small businesses. Capital gains of up to $500,000 made when shares in eligible small businesses are sold are exempt. Moreover, only 75 per cent of capital gains above this amount are subject to income tax.
So these are some examples of benefits for our small businesses in Canada. Nevertheless, small business is subject to major financial and competitive pressures. To help promote growth and employment the government is launching a program to stimulate employment and investment in small business. Under this program most companies can hire new workers without paying more employer premiums for unemployment insurance in 1993.
I think that is a considerable help, knowing the needs of small businesses and how little they can afford to hire personnel. This measure will reduce the cost of hiring additional employees by up to $1,600 each.
The other measures include a 10 per cent investment tax credit for small businesses that buy machinery and
equipment. We are aware of companies' needs to renew and update their equipment as a result of new technology; the tax measures will give them 10 per cent more purchasing power.
The rules for investments in RRSPs and other funds in small businesses will be simplified and the opportunities for financing expanded. Finally, the financial assistance programs for small business will be enhanced or extended.
We know how important it is to go further in research and development because our small businesses need to discover and develop new products in order to be more competitive. R and D is essential, so the government will help them compete and grow on the world market. Canada is the industrialized country that offers business the most generous R and D tax incentives. We have proposed changes to rationalize and improve the system.
As promised in the February 1992 budget these changes will result in $230 million more aid over the next five years. Nevertheless, the tax rules could be improved in some areas to help companies adapt and grow in this era dominated by knowledge and technological change. For example, the tax system as it applies to computer equipment, in particular, is rapidly becoming obsolete because of technical change.
The government is considering other changes that could be made to the tax system to solve these problems. It has set aside $400 million over five years to eliminate tax obstacles to innovation and growth. We will increase funding for IRAP, the Industrial Research Assistance Program. We will also extend funding for long-term research, based on the best results from the centres of excellence network program.
Of course, there is also labour force training and adjustment. In an increasingly knowledge-based economy Canada's economic prospects depend more and more on the skills of its work force. The federal government is helping to meet this challenge. Its assistance for worker training and adjustment will increase to $3.8 billion next year. As part of this effort, unemployment insurance funds for training and other productive purposes will rise to $2.2 billion. This will help meet the special needs of long-time workers who lose their jobs.
December 2, 1992

Many other measures have been proposed in the economic statement made by our Minister of Finance but I think that the measures I just listed concerning research and development, training, and small-business assistance will enable our companies to make a greater commitment in those areas, and help reduce unemployment in our country, for the benefit of all Canadians.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Madam Speaker, to my colleague, the member for Joliette, I understand that the minister mentioned some changes today in unemployment insurance. I wonder if this is going to pose any particular problem in the member's area? I believe the minister had said this was in order to reduce fraud in that particular branch. Could the member please answer that for me?

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my colleague wonders about the impact of these measures on unemployment insurance, since the Minister of Finance indicated, if I understood correctly, that in the future those who quit their job or who lose it almost voluntarily will not be eligible for unemployment insurance benefits.
In the last few years unemployment insurance has almost become a minimum income for some people. I believe it is absolutely normal in the present context that we make UI what it was meant to be: a plan to help workers who for one reason or another lose their job unexpectedly. The purpose of unemployment insurance, like any other insurance, is to provide reasonable conditions for these people and give them time to find another job.
Therefore, it is quite normal, as I think Canadians will agree, that unemployment insurance revert to its original role, which is to help those who lose their job unexpectedly and not to help those who leave their job or who lose it deliberately.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, there seems to be a misunderstanding developing here. No one in this House condones abuse. We on this side of the House certainly do not condone the abuse of any part of the taxpayer's money.
Government Orders
Our responsibility is not to speak for the advantaged. We are here to speak for the disadvantaged. In a situation such as this, where this act is amended in this way, there is going to be a potential for serious abuse of the person, but not the actual institution. It is our responsibility to point that out. It seems that when we try to be constructive and point out some of the good things in this budget they seem to have a thin skin over there. Is it not our job to point out flaws or mistakes that may be part of this package?
I have to repeat that we are not here to speak for the advantaged people in our country. There are a lot of disadvantaged people and we have to make sure we represent their views.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
It is a pleasure, Madam Speaker, to make
the following comment. My colleague says that we should help the disadvantaged and this is precisely what we are doing. These measures are taken precisely to help people get back to work.
As I said at the beginning of my speech, in the past large amounts of money were spent to keep people unemployed. We just kept improving our Unemployment Insurance Program without dealing with the training issue, putting us into debt irresponsibly. Now, some would want us to continue in this way. That is not the way to go. We are acting in the most responsible way, to allow those who want to work to do so. We will take money away from those who do not want to work, those who quit their jobs-when they have a job and decide to quit it is reasonable to assume that they do not want to work-and we will use this money to train those who do want to work. The small businesses will benefit from the actions we are taking. This money will create jobs. We are not abandoning Canadians. Quite the contrary, we are helping the most disadvantaged members of our society.

speakeroldname: Mr. Patrick Boyer (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Defence):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Defence
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the Minister of Finance today did not have an easy task to perform. No Minister of Finance in any jurisdiction these days does. The task was to try to crash through that invisible wall that confronts all governments, a wall that is made

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
up of the fiscal realities that have imposed themselves on us. the burden of debt that has been accumulated over a number of years, the programs that exist and are committed to have expenditure under them, and the public expectation that all of this can somehow continue even in the face of the need to have spending restraint.
To begin in commenting briefly on a number of the points in his statement this afternoon that caught my eye in particular, I would like to emphasize the important reality that there are no new taxes. That is a fundamental beginning point because this country has had it, Canadians have had it, with being overtaxed. The burden of responsibility has been squarely shouldered today by the Minister of Finance in looking inward to the operations of government to find a way of dealing with the problem and not extending it further on to the taxpayers of the country.
In concert with that, many expenditures have been frozen, from the salary of the Governor General right down through all members of the House, ministers, parliamentarians, judges and the Public Service as well. That principle of freezing has even been continued in the provisions relating to unemployment insurance. The benefits there are frozen as well.
In addition there have been many other areas where spending has been reduced, generally by at least 10 per cent. That would apply to grants or subsidies to organizations and interests groups. They will be cut by 10 per cent in each of the next two years.
That is another point that is very important as we try to ensure in this society that we get a direct link between the people and their elected representatives. Many special interest groups and organizations that have come forward and positioned themselves around the government should find a way of financing themselves rather than look to the government for funding. That is a point of great importance.

I cannot even hear what is being said by the member who has the floor. It must be difficult for other people. I am sure the hon. member for
Kingston and the Islands will make sure he asks his question then.

speakerposition: Liberal Party Deputy House Leader

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: I wish a nice evening to the hon. member.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Defence
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I was just emphasizing the importance of this reduction of 10 per cent in grants and subsidies this year and the coming year. I wanted to emphasize a further point, that those reductions have important exemptions to them.
I was quite disturbed to hear in almost a cliche fashion some of the criticism from the Liberal Party spokesmen in the House. They talked about these measures being carried out on the backs of the poor, as if the government was trying to squeeze blood from a stone.
It is very important to recognize that exempted from this is the Old Age Security program. That is very important for seniors in our country. Also exempted are the guaranteed income supplement, the spouses' allowance, programs for the disabled, war veterans' allowances and veterans' disability pensions.
The Government of Canada today made the commitment that we will not be reducing any of our efforts in famine relief around the world. I think that is a real tribute to the Minister of Finance, who in the face of the tremendous difficulties he is facing with the finances of our country still shows that compassion. We can seek efficiency in public funding and public financing but not lose the compassion for the people in our society who do need assistance, who do need some help and support. We have not seen a single cent of that reduced today and I want to pay a special compliment to the Minister of Finance for that.
Just three or four other quick points that are very important. The measures dealing with housing and the stimulus that we have already seen from the last budget relating to both the RRSP possibility for first home buyers and the reduction from 10 per cent to 5 per cent for the down payment have been working successfully. It is important that today that has been continued in terms of the RRSP for home buyers.
December 2, 1992

Small business, which has been responsible for creating over two million jobs in the Canadian economy within the last decade, also finds new possibilities for higher levels of loans and working capital in today's financial policies announced by the Minister of Finance. This is going to be very important, particularly in areas like my constituency of Etobicoke-Lakeshore where there are a lot of small businesses in manufacturing and service which need that kind of financial assistance now that they are working their way out of the recession.
Another very specific measure that will apply also in our area is the grade separation program with relation to railways. That is something for which we have been looking for a long time and will have direct safety and employment benefit in our community, as will the efforts to upgrade the two terminals at Pearson International Airport.
I single that one out again to make tribute here to the Minister of Finance. What has to be appreciated is the change in the approach to government funding. This upgrading will be done using private financing. In short, we have come to the day where government does not have to row the boat and do everything, as long as government is steering the boat. We can now look for a more intelligent way of using limited dollars to accomplish public work in this country, such as this.
Finally, the point that I wanted to conclude with is on quite a different dimension. It concerns the electronic highway and the measures that were announced today for further funding for this new age. We are now in, the future that is already with us that relates to the information centres being established because of the fact that, computers, faxes, electronic transmission of data, satellites and all the rest of it together make up this electronic highway through which information is transmitted and received and analysed in our new world society. This is something tremendously exciting for a country like Canada, a country that has so much distance that separates us. This will be a great new unifying bond for the country. Again, I am happy to be supporting this measure because that is the way of the future. It is also a way to a far more effective and unified country through the new methods that we are living with currently.
In all these areas, right down to the provisions that have in so much detail been described by other members,
Government Orders
this reordering this afternoon by the Minister of Finance of the nation's financial house, putting it in order in these very difficult circumstances, is something that warrants support. I am glad to rise and give my support to it.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I was listening to my colleague talk about the electronic highway.

I have a real problem trying to understand how we can have an electronic highway when our government does not seem to have enough money to pay its electric bill. We are practically bankrupt. We are talking about the future. At the same time we are bringing forth a kind of mini budget that targets the most vulnerable people in our society, the unemployed. We are actually right now dealing with the unemployed in a way which is most cruel. Before they had certain benefits under the unemployment insurance scheme, but now they do not have those benefits. They have less.
Also, we have entered into a situation where they will be punished. They will lose the benefits that they have actually paid for if they quit their job or if they are fired or let go for whatever is defined as misconduct.
How can this kind of cruelty to the people who are most vulnerable be defended by a government which says that it is looking forward to the future, a government which says it cares about its citizens? I would especially like to attract my colleagues' attention to the fact that this could be used as a tool against whistle-blowers, people who are not in agreement with their company's policies which may be against the public health or the public good. It could be used as a tool to silence these people and they would never have unemployment insurance.
I am just wondering where is the compassion of this government. While we are talking about an electronic highway why do we not talk about what is real to most Canadians, and that is their unemployment insurance benefits.

December 2, 1992
Government Orders

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Defence
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would like to take a minute to reply to my colleague who was inquiring about unemployment and unemployment insurance.
First of all, let me tell him that in my riding it is a real problem for small businesses when employees quit their jobs for the sake of taking advantage of a government program. Small businesses are hit hard by this kind of abuse of the system. Today, we are trying to address this problem.

He puts this also in connection with what I was saying about the electronic highway, as if to compare these two is somehow to deny the reality that we are already existing in a world where information is being transmitted this way. Whether they are changes to the telephone as we have come to know it, and all the transformation about that, through to the new ability to simply scan books and put that right on to computer or what is now being developed with fibre optics which will go straight from the publishing house to the data base in libraries and so on which will completely bypass the printers, the books, the book sellers and all those things that we know. That is not something of the future. That is something that we are currently living in.
It has been a rare day to see it even raised on the floor of the House of Commons. For the past two days there has been a conference going on here in Ottawa at the Congress Centre. I was the only MP who was there. It was on electronic democracy. It was talking about the whole new world that we are living in. It is fundamentally important to see this $600 million project get under way.
The same point I was making about the upgrading of the Pearson airport applies here. This is being done in a partnership with private business. It is not looking to just take public money to put into this.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: How about whistle-blowers?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Defence
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
The hon. member is commenting about whistle-blowers. I do not know what the context of that is. I do want to say again that I support the changes relating to unemployment insurance. They are overdue. I support the approaches being taken with respect to the new world of our electronics society-past the industrial society into the electronics society-that we are living in
so much now because it is very forward looking, and many of the other temporal measures that we find in here will fade away over time.
This provision relating to the new age of communication is so far-reaching and fundamental for Canada, a country that because of our distances has always been at the pioneering edge of developing new methods of communication and transportation. We can be proud of that as Canadians because it is an area in which we have excelled. That is why all members on all sides of the House should be looking at that measure with a lot of support and encouragement.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am going to share my time with the member for Nickel Belt. We are true socialists, we share everything.
There might have been a time, and there probably was, when governments on one side of the aisle would say: "We will just help our friends in big business and somehow they will, on the supply side, solve all of the economic problems of the nation". On the other side of the aisle somebody else would find the phrase: "We are going to kick start the economy". Maybe at some point in our history things were that simple. I do not really believe they are any more.
I regret some of what I have seen and heard in here today because it seems to me to be far too simplistic. I recognize that someone has gone to a great deal of effort to integrate all the politically correct buzzwords into the statements that were made in this Chamber today. All of the genuflexions at the altar of high technology have certainly been acknowledged.
I understand, having been in politics at just about every level there is now, that somehow if we can get somebody to put it on a piece of paper, and certainly if we can put a little logo at the bottom that says "Canada", then it gives it validity no matter what it is. If we can get somebody to draw a chart and put some numbers together, then it simply must be true.
However, I am still struggling with some fundamentals on this. I come from the old school where if we take a deficit from $27.5 billion and get it up to $34.4 billion, then we have not reduced it, you have increased it. I am sorry, but I have been struggling all afternoon with how that reduction occurred and how dramatically it has impacted on us.
December 2, 1992

I admit that we are talking about billions of dollars. I do not usually deal in billions of dollars. Most Canadians do not have a real good understanding of how high they would have to pile that amount of money on the kitchen floor to get to a billion. I admit that we are into an area of the economy where the amounts we are talking about are staggering to most people. Still I am waiting for someone to explain to me how that could be portrayed as a reduction. Even if it is printed up in a little book, and if the little book is not good enough then it is printed up in another little booklet, and if that little booklet is not good enough then it is printed as a graph.
I admit it has got it all. The government has managed to get it on paper, it has the stamp of the Government of Canada on it and has a graph to boot.
Here are some premises that are important for Canadians to note, just to see at their kitchen table whether there is any truth in this kind of statement at all. It says here that the government is making government leaner and more efficient. Pause on that one for a while. Have we seen that lately?
I just walked in the front door and the leaner and more efficient limousines are circling out there, and if they are not circling the drivers are leaning against them. Where I come from that does not constitute lean and efficient. Where I come from if people are broke and you are out of a job, they are not real worried about how lean and efficient the chauffeur of their limousine really is, and they really do not care people whether he polishes the limo either, because the truth is they have not got a limo to bother about.
It says here that there is tax reform under way in this country. Tax reform. Hold on a minute. Where? For whom? For the vast majority of Canadians who pay the tax when they went to the corner store last night to buy something did someone say: "Tax reform under way here, there is no GST tonight''? When they put gas in their car this morning did somebody say: "Wait a minute, tax reform under way. Governments aren't going to tax gasoline any more"? When it comes to doing their income tax, does that mean there is somebody in this Chamber who actually understands the income tax form?
What I do not fathom at all about this is that when people do not need money everybody wants to lend them
Government Orders
money. When they are wealthy, they can use all the investment incentives, those are the polite words, that this government provides to prevent them from having to pay income tax. But if they are poor, if they are struggling with their pay cheque each week just to meet all the obligations that they have as a family there are not any incentives for them.
I come from a part of Canada that was once considered to be the industrial heartland. We are changing our definitions about that these days. People used to refer to the area that I live in as the Golden Horseshoe. There is a lot of rust in the Golden Horseshoe these days. A lot of plants used to be there. It says in these documents that free trade is wonderful. Not where I come from, not in the plants that have closed in my area, not in the incentives that are present in any part of our economy. Our people are struggling very hard to try to turn that around.
It says in these documents that many people are being asked to take no increase. That is tough for all of us, all those in the cabinet, all those in the Senate, all those judges. I am asked to stand pat on $90,000 a year or a pensioner to stand pat on $25,000 a year, let me explain to who got the best of that deal. Not the pensioner. The fact that nothing was taken away from those who do not have anything in the first place is not exactly a noble act in my book. To try to portray that as something wonderful is not exactly fair where I come from.
I find there is a world here on the Hill that never meets the other world in which I live. I know that tonight the television cameras are out front of the doors of this Chamber and the Minister of Finance is out there giving an interview; Mike Duffy is holding forth on the bench on the stairs; and everything is going along pretty normally here.
Where I come from things are not normal and I had anticipated-wrongly again, I should have learned this by now-when I saw the municipalities struggle to get together and identify some things which could be done and should be done, would be productive in municipalities across Canada, that after that much effort this government would respond. It did not.
I saw a provincial government negotiating over the last six months or so with this government to identify things which could be done and should be done, which would be

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
productive. I went through this booklet to find out what is happening in Ontario. Nada.
I phoned my friend Pink Floyd-of course I cannot get through to Pink Floyd anymore-and got through to one of his staff members I know and asked what was going on. He said they were still negotiating but were not sure they had been shut out completely. They were going to give the federal government the benefit of the doubt and see what happens.
It is certainly a strange economic statement, never mind budget, that attempts to do something about Canada's economy. It looks the heartland of our economic structure in the eyeball and says: "I'll tell you what we are doing for you. We are going to redecorate the airport in Toronto".
The Tories missed something there. They really did, especially when one of the three terminals at the airport may not have much business in the near future.
There is a change in this country that defies the old economic rules of what school people went to and what text book they read about economics. The change is that governments are more complicated now than they ever were. It is hard to imagine that governments once functioned in Canada without consultants. Not cutting back, not leaner and meaner-they did not have them. Government once went about its business in Canada without a big advertising campaign to tell everybody it was doing what it was paid to do in the first place.
Imagine my auto workers if they were given the kind of budget the Minister of Finance had. Here is my friend Derek Gandy making trucks today at GM. Look at Derek make trucks. We always felt that was why General Motors always paid Derek. Go down to the south plant and make the trucks, Derek. It does not need an advertising campaign to do that. Just go do it.
There are some remarkable things that have happened in government in Canada in the last little while, not all of which were helpful.
I read the Auditor General's report. I loved the one about the golden handshake where the gold transpired and sometimes the handshake transpired, but the job continued. It seems to me that governments at all levels really ought to take the Auditor General's report and not study it, just do it, without question.
It has already been studied. That is how it got in the Auditor General's report. The Auditor General even sends me a video. I cannot tell my personal reaction to getting a video cassette from the Auditor General of Canada. There are other video cassettes I would rather get than that one. He sends me the book. I can read the book. I really do not need a video.
Somehow in the process of governing this country we have patterns that I find strange and indefensible, particularly when I go home and sit down with some little old lady or some little old guy who is on a fixed income and try to explain at the kitchen table what life is like in Ottawa. It is like an alien planet plunked down here in the Gatineau. They have no concept of what it is like.
None of them have staff people saying: "Boy, you really did a great job today. What a snappy question. Could I write a speech for you?" They can all speak. They certainly do that to me. Somebody was here the other day prattling on about lobbyists' fees and how individuals would have to pay a fee to come to see the local member. Not where I come from. Nobody would have the stupidity to try that one there. They have a right to stop me in the middle of the Miracle Mart or the A & P Store and tell me their economic theories. They do that right by the kettles every time I am fool enough to go in there. They stop me whenever I go to the Canadian Tire and they tell me about the GST. They do not have charts. They do not have videos. They have empty wallets. Those are the facts as they see them.
What saddens me about this statement is that it was an opportunity for governments, instead of having a conference, instead of having a first ministers' meeting, to pick up that magic machine called the telephone without creating an electronic highway to do so, push some buttons and listen to what other people had to say. Governments should work together instead of working in splendid isolation.
I see a missed opportunity here. I do not care how nicely they dress it up, how many new global economies they bring into play, how many wonderful charts they have or how many videos they have. The opportunity was missed. Where I come from we are suffering and this ignores us completely.
I want to close by saying something that I kind of regret but I think should be said. This is all complicated stuff. Sometimes it comes down to something which is simple, a little vignette. I sat in this Chamber this
December 2, 1992

afternoon when the minister announced the change to UI that had people losing their UI benefits if they were fired or if they quit without just cause.
I know how tough it is to establish what is meant by just cause, who is right and who is wrong. That is a tough thing to do. I remember thinking at the moment he announced that change: What difference does that make? Is that not a mean little vindictive thing to do to somebody? It is not going to save the national debt. That is for sure. Beside the Minister of Finance was the Prime Minister himself. He led the applause on that.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: I must interrupt the hon. member. I know he said he was sharing with his colleague from Nickel Belt. I can tell his colleague from Nickel Belt that even though I did try, he will have eight minutes remaining after the five minutes of questions and comments.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am almost tempted to ask unanimous consent of the House for the hon. member to carry on for another 10 minutes. It was not just eloquent; it was kitchen table-ish. It sounded like sitting down with somebody at the kitchen table and actually getting the goods straight from the individual sitting across the way.
I will relate a story for the hon. member for Oshawa in the simplest of terms. There is someone in my riding who owns a restaurant and is doing pretty well. He wants to expand that restaurant. He wants to make sure the opportunity is there to double the space in his restaurant. He is pretty darn sure he can get a lot more people to come to that restaurant. He went to the bank and asked for the money to expand his business and the bank said: "Sorry, Charlie".
In the document today the Minister of Finance announced measures to help small businesses secure financing. He doubled the ceiling of small business loans from $100,000 to $200,000 and today he added another $50,000 to raise the ceiling to $250,000 on small business loans. What good is it if they cannot get the money even at $100,000?
Does the hon. member for Oshawa have that kind of an experience in his riding?

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Yes.
Government Orders

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I want to congratulate the hon. member for Oshawa on his excellent speech. He mentioned that if a person left his job voluntarily he would not be entitled to unemployment insurance benefits. I think some people leave their jobs for very good reasons. I imagine there usually is a good reason, and they do not leave because all of a sudden they feel lazy or they want to stop working. Some people leave their jobs because of sexual harassment. Take the woman who is harassed by her boss, has no way to defend herself and does not know where to turn. She has no choice but to: leave her job. Perhaps the hon. member for Oshawa would care to comment on the case of a woman who was a victim of sexual harassment, and had to leave her job but would not be entitled to unemployment insurance benefits.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I would tell her simply that she has become a victim of this government. She ought to get herself into a good union or get a good lawyer really quickly.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I sat here and listened with more than just a casual amount of interest to what I refer to as Brooklyn banter. It was fairly basic kitchen talk. It was so basic that the last question I heard in relation to the last answer I heard obviously told me that neither the questioner, with all due respect, nor the answerer had the essence of the bill that the Minister of Finance related to us today.
Quite simply put, if a person does leave their job because they feel that there was sexual harassment, that does not include them in this measure. They are exempted and as a result would continue to receive their unemployment insurance.
Therefore, there is a lot of misinformation that floats around this Chamber. I simply wanted to bring that to the attention of hon. members. There is a list of excuses or reasons that people can use legitimately to leave their place of employment which does not render them victims of society or, for that matter, victims of this bill. It is a logical bill and I would just hope that the hon. member

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
for Oshawa would apprise himself of that. I just wonder if he has.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I do not mean to try to straighten anybody out on that side but there is no bill before us. What we had was called a statement.
We will take the member's veritable words and the wonderful advice that he just gave. For the person who comes into my office who has been fired and is not a member of a union or another bargaining unit and who has to go through the federal or provincial labour code to try to determine whether the hiring or the firing was justified it will be some comfort for them for the six months it takes to determine whether it was justifiable or not. The hon. member said that I do not understand what is going on here. At the end of the six months he or she will understand, I will understand and I hope the member does.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am glad my hon. colleague from Oshawa is not the finance minister. The way he just nickled and dimed me out of two minutes I would hate to see what wonders he would have brought on the economy of Canada today.
Prior to the statement today, the press was carrying a statement that the Minister of Finance was going to give the economy a gentle nudge, a coup de pouce, a petit coup de pouce. I want to say that he looked the economy right in the eye and he did not give it a gentle nudge, he gave it the back of his hand. That is what he did today.
I want to make that point and I want to show how he does that. I looked at page 30 in his paper Investing in Growth. Listen to this. The minister asks this question:
Are Canadians getting less service for their tax dollars?
Here is the answer. Imagine that the Tories put this answer down:
Some feel that they are now getting less service for their tax dollar
than in the past. They are right.
There is such honesty. He then goes on to say:
But there is no choice.
This is what he says in the statement on page two under the heading of maintaining responsible, balanced policies:
The essence of governing is choosing. There are choices to be
made
That is right. This minister had choices. He could have made choices. He had to make choices. Unfortunately, he chose his friends. He chose to slap in the face the people who can least defend themselves in this economy.
He cut back the unemployment insurance program. Imagine next year taking $550 million out of the pockets of beneficiaries and in the year after that, $1 billion. Everybody was looking to the consumer to rescue this economy. What kind of cockamamie politics and economics is this? One takes money out of the pockets of the people who are supposed to rescue the economy by opening their wallets and spending. The ones who are least able to defend themselves are the victims of the economic policies of this government.
About four years ago we were running at an inflation rate of about 6 per cent. The governor of the Bank of Canada, John Crow, is cruel and hard-hearted. He embarked on a policy of fighting inflation and wrestling it to zero. He did not care who the victims were. The unemployment went up and up and the the inflation, of course, came down. It did not affect his salary or the salaries of his friends over at the bank. It is easy to fight inflation on the backs of workers by slowing the economy down and turning up the unemployment rate.
What did this government cut back? It cut programs that service the victims. We are talking about the rape crisis centres getting cut back 10 per cent in each year for the next two years. We are talking about all of those centres that service people who have some kind of drug dependency or need co-operative housing. There is a whole host of services cut back, which will mean reduced services to people. The minister says they will get less service for the buck it collects from them. He is absolutely correct. Then he also cut back the spending programs.
I know he is saying: "Well, we have to get this deficit under control, so where were we going to get the money? How could we leave them alone?" I have some suggestions for the minister.
It always makes me wonder what is going on. When Standard Trust went down the tubes the government did not have a billion dollars but it sure as hell got the billion dollars and bailed out the depositors of Standard Trust. It put the taxpayers of Canada on the hook for Central Guaranty Trust to the tune of about $4 billion. If any of them went down the tubes at the Toronto Dominion
December 2, 1992

Bank where is the government going to get the money to bail them out? It has guaranteed them.
It guaranteed the Westray Mine and the Bank of Nova Scotia collected its $80 million today. If CPA goes down tomorrow, where is it going to get the money to bail it out? Yes, it has choices to make and it has made those choices. Stomp on the families of Canada. Stomp on the unemployed. However, it bailed out its friends in the financial sector. It bails them out all the time. Standard Trust cost us a billion bucks.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: It did?

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
It certainly did: $1 billion. There is more to come and it is going to find the money for that.
I could have told him where he could get money. For starters, he could look at the Auditor General's report. Why not close the loopholes he pointed out. Look at the setting up of those offshore shelters for wealthy corporations that make money in this country and do not pay their fair share of taxes. Why do we not start with the family trusts that are worth $70 billion? Since the Liberals set up the shelter for them they have not paid one penny of tax. This government is going to bring in a bill that extends it another 20 years, so that they will never pay one penny of tax. Who pays?
Its friends do not pay, but ordinary Canadians pay. The unemployed pay and the poor pay. Look at that. It is nickel and diming $300 million out of people who quit their jobs. There are some jobs that have to be quit. It then reduces the limit. I have no problem with absorbing the premiums for UI for small businesses for a year. That is a good idea. I think it is also equally a good idea to absorb the premiums for the employees for a year.
It seems to me that we must be even-handed. It does not absorb the premiums for 1993 for the employees. It absorbs it for small businesses, which is a good idea. How about giving the workers a break for a year? They create jobs too when they spend the money they earn. Maybe it is not through the heads of the Conservatives yet but they are probably the best investment, instead of pouring money into all kinds of shysters. In fact, when Northland
Government Orders
Bank went down it not only bailed out the insured depositors, but it bailed out everybody, for God's sake.
There are other places the government could find money. I have more suggestions for the government. What about the helicopters? There is $4.4 billion. Put the $4.4 billion off and forget that. Look at interest rates. Most of national debt that we have accumulated is a result of the compound interest. Most of that is compound interest. We are running about 4 per cent higher, in real interest rate terms, than our competitors in the United States. We are double the normal difference. Why would we not lower the interest rates? Why did this government allow the interest rates to rise? Why? It is because it has to keep its international banquiers, or casino players, happy.
You have to feed the lion. When the lion is hungry you have to keep stuffing American dollars into his mouth. I am sorry but I have to stop.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: I thought the hon. member was going to thank me for giving him the extra two minutes. Questions or comments. The hon. member for Joliette.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the hon. member for Nickel Belt is very colourful and puts a lot of passion into what he says, and he is even funny. However, I am concerned because we are talking about unemployment and other problems we are experiencing in Canada and he is proposing solutions that would be hard to implement.
He would like to see us beef up our unemployment insurance programs. He would like us to give the unemployed who do not have jobs, for obvious reasons, more generous unemployment insurance benefits. He suggests that the government get the money by taking steps against the industries that are taking advantage of the situation. He never said that industries create jobs. He never said that industries give Canadians a chance to work. No, industries are taking advantage of the situation, and he would like to see us introduce measures to make these industries get up and leave the country and go to places where conditions are more favourable. On the other hand, and this is typical of the New Democrats, they say that we should protect our borders and not have an agreement with our neighbours. It does not make

Government Orders
sense, all these contradictions. Today, the Minister of Finance proposed a number of measures to help businesses create jobs and all I have heard from the hon. member is that we should not encourage businesses and we should beef up our unemployment insurance programs.
Does the hon. member for Nickel Belt not have any suggestions for creating jobs at the same time, since that seems to be his main argument, to protect the little guy, with a lot of grand gestures? He says we are crushing the little guy, but we want to create jobs for people who are on unemployment insurance. I would like to know whether he has a more acceptable method for correcting our unemployment problems.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I welcome the opportunity to respond. First of all let us get something clear. These UI programs-let us understand very clearly, let us put the deck on the table.
The employers and the employees pay for the unemployment insurance program. This government removed itself from participating in the unemployment insurance program so that any benefits which are in the program are paid for by the employers and the employees.
I have no problem at all with industries and with putting a climate in place that encourages industries to invest and expand. However, if I were the finance minister I would not allow industries to take advantage of scams and loopholes in the income tax system to avoid paying their fair share of taxes.
If the hon. member is suggesting to me that because some other country allows its industries to do that sort of thing we should get into the mug's game then where will it end? The looser its tax system becomes with respect to its taxpayers the looser ours should become?
That is reducing the economy to the lowest common denominator not raising it to the highest common factor, if that is the kind of mug's game we want to get into.
Creating jobs, yes. If this document that was read today made creating jobs the focus I would have taken off my hat to the minister. I would have kissed his hand. I would have kissed his knee. I would have stopped there. If it did that I would have applauded him.
In the statement he took great pride in saying we brought inflation down to less than 2 per cent. We never heard in great detail the projections about unemployment. After all of this pain the unemployment rate will be 11 per cent or more; 11 per cent. Imagine the productivity that is lost with over 1.5 million unemployed in our country.
There are things we can do that are investments in the country, such things as an infrastructure and renovations. The best way to go is to train and educate. These are investments. They are expenditures but they mean jobs for the future.

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to speak during this debate on the actions the government has announced to improve the state of public finances and to restore our economy. In doing so I would like to indicate what the government sees as the future of the Public Service in supporting Canada's economic competitiveness.
This government has attempted in each year since 1985 to reduce the cost and increase the efficiency of service delivery. In budget after budget, and often in between, reductions have been imposed on the planned operating expenditures of departments. Today's measures affect programs delivered by public servants as well as transfers to individuals and grants and contributions to organizations and business.
I want to underline the fact that the government could not have made the reductions that were necessary and continued to serve Canadians adequately were it not for the professionalism and dedication of the employees of the Public Service of Canada.
The cost reduction measures outlined in today's economic statement are substantial and, given the cumulative effect of the cuts over the past eight years, represent a major challenge for those who deliver the services.
The 2 per cent reduction in operating budgets for 1992-1993 has been introduced two-thirds of the way through the fiscal year. Many departments are having to impose their own freeze on hiring and virtually all discretionary expenditures to achieve the required savings. The cuts in 1993-1994 and future years amount to
December 2, 1992

approximately 5 per cent of planned expenditures on operations and require even more severe measures.
The economic situation that led to these measures is not unique to the Canadian federal government. The world economy has been weaker than expected and growth projections for most countries have been revised downward. This in turn has reduced revenues and increased pressures on public expenditures.
Fiscal responses have varied but in all cases they took the form of severe expenditure reductions. For example the Governments of Italy, Sweden, and Great Britain have in the past few months all announced fiscal restraint packages, some of which include wage freezes and all of which include program reductions and increased delivery of services by the private sector.
In Canada provinces are also feeling the pressure on their deficits owing mainly to revenue shortfalls. Five provincial governments have announced expenditure reduction measures in the last month alone.
What are the fiscal requirements for limiting wages? The Canadian government program expenditures, other than those for unemployment insurance and transfers to the provinces, have remained well within planned levels. Flowever, the revenues available to the government have declined relative to the projections in the 1992 budget by about 6 per cent in 1992-1993 and 7 per cent in 1993-1994.
The economic statement calls for reductions in the operating costs of government from the levels announced in the last budget of $1 billion in 1993-1994 and $1.4 billion in 1994-1995, exclusive of the special reduction of $250 million in defence spending in 1994-1995.
This requires on average a reduction of about 5 per cent of the operating costs of government below the planned level; about 4.3 per cent in 1993-1994 and 5.5 per cent in 1994-1995.
Approximately two-thirds of operating budgets are devoted to personnel costs. Since in most departments operations and maintenance expenditures have not been increased for inflation since 1985 these non-salary components offer limited scope for further reductions without serious impact on service delivery.
Government Orders
This means that in 1993-94 the over-all wage bill will have to be brought down from planned levels by approximately $800 million on total personnel costs of $19 billion.

The question then becomes that of the best way to achieve the approximately $800 million reduction in the wage bill with the minimum effect on delivery of services and minimal layoffs of public servants.
In weighing the options the government decided that the most effective way of achieving this result would be a combination of a wage freeze and a reduction in planned Public Service employment to a degree that could be achieved mostly through attrition.
Legislation will be introduce to freeze federal public sector wages for some 390,000 persons in total, including all cabinet ministers, MPs, senators and their staffs, employees of the House of Commons, Senate and Library of Parliament, employees of the Public Service, Order in Council appointees and members of Canadian Forces and the RCMP.
Employees of Crown corporations that are dependent on appropriations and that are not in competition with the private sector, such as the museums corporations, will have their wages frozen. Crown corporations that are dependent on appropriations but are in competition with the private sector, such as VIA Rail, will be funded as if their wages were frozen. All other Crown corporations are being asked to keep their wage settlements in line with the wage policy.
One can ask how many jobs will have to be cut. As all departments will be managing under the new operating budget regime next year each will be able to determine the mix of savings between salary and non-salary dollars to best meet their requirements. It is, therefore, not possible to forecast with precision the over-all employment implications. However, some rough estimates can be made at this time.
For the 235,000 employees in the Public Service for whom Treasury Board is the employer, which does not include the military and uniformed RCMP, the required reduction from planned levels in the wage bill is about two-thirds of the $800 million, or just over $500 million. The government had planned for an increase of up to one per cent in employment in each of the next two years

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
so the net reduction in the wage bill for 1993-94 is just over $400 million from the 1992-93 levels.
The savings from the wage freeze on these employees will look after all but about $190 million, which must be found through reductions of 3,000 to 4,000 in employment levels. We believe that most of this can be achieved through attrition. The current rate of attrition, mainly through retirements and resignations, in the Public Service is four per cent, or 8,000 to 9,000 people per year. Most departments were planning for roughly stable employment levels for the next two years but some were already planning for decreases, and a very few were planning for increases to meet significantly greater demands.
Arrangements will be made through the Public Service Commission to facilitate the retraining and transfer of employees to departments that would otherwise be hiring from outside the Public Service. If an over-all reduction of 3,000 to 4,000 in employment levels can be achieved next year then further employment reductions would not be necessary in the second year to reach the target reductions in operating budgets.

The government recognizes that in freezing salaries it is asking its employees to take a reduction in their real salaries. This creates a reduction in living standards for loyal employees who have no control over declining revenues during a period in which they are continually asked to perform their duties with fewer resources. The government recognizes this and asks Canadians in turn to recognize the contribution its employees are making to help get the country's public finances in order.
Over the next five years, the government will be introducing, in phases, a new job classification system with a gender-neutral evaluation plan. This plan is being designed with extensive input from Public Service unions, the Canadian Human Rights Commission and outside experts to ensure it respects the principles of equal pay for work of equal value.
Once this is completed it will be necessary to find the best way simultaneously to satisfy the equal pay provisions of the Canadian Human Rights Act and to negotiate collective agreements that are sensitive to Canadian labour markets.
The Human Rights Commission's equal wages guidelines allow for wage differentials that respond to labour shortages in particular occupations or geographical areas. The government will consult unions and other employers on the fairest and most effective way to meet both objectives during the next round of collective bargaining.
The measures set out in the economic statement were not discussed with the Public Service unions before they were announced. The government carefully considered whether it would be in the public interest to try to negotiate wage levels that were affordable. In light of the experience in the last round of bargaining, which culminated in the strike by the largest Public Service union in September 1991, it was decided that it was not in the interest of the public nor of employees to enter into negotiations facing a fiscal situation that virtually guaranteed the government would be unable to meet union demands. This decision, was not taken lightly.
The government hopes that at the end of the period of extreme fiscal stringency covered by the proposed legislation collective bargaining could resume in a normal way. In the meantime, consultations can continue through the national joint council on non-compensation issues during the period of the wage freeze. As well, I have established a joint committee to undertake a full review of the management of Public Service pensions.

Reductions of 5 per cent in planned operating costs of government will inevitably have an impact on the level of services that the government can provide to Canadians from their tax dollars. In the short run, it will simply not be possible to do more with less. The Public Service has been successful in achieving effective productivity improvements each year as increasing demands have had to be met with ever more constrained resources.
Since 1985 the government has been providing services to a more diverse population that has grown by 8 per cent with 2.3 per cent fewer employees and operating and maintenance expenditures that, for most departments, have not been increased to take account of inflation. Although there have been some reductions in certain service areas there has been growth in such areas as
December 2, 1992

native programs, the green plan, the drug strategy, AIDS research and immigration. In broad terms, the Public Service has been achieving productivity increases of at least the rate of general productivity growth in the economy. This is an achievement for which Canadians and their Public Service employees can be proud.
While the growth in demand anticipated for the next year will vary from program to program the growth in population is probably the best comprehensive indicator of the change in demand for services. It is projected to be 1.2 per cent annually over the next few years. This increase in demand has to be addressed with fewer employees and reduced operations and maintenance expenditures. Of necessity, some services will suffer. Departments are being asked to find as much as possible of the cost reduction through streamlining of internal administrative processes and to maintain essential services, particularly those pertaining directly to the health and safety of Canadians. However, many departments will have to reduce levels of service in areas that are important but not absolutely essential.
Some rationalization of the delivery systems will be required. This may involve consolidation of offices and alternative forms of delivery, such as greater use of telephone services and new forms of automation.
There will be administrative innovation to achieve the saving in administration processes and support and the government has undertaken a series of initiatives. The operational review of the five government departments and agencies concerned with internal administration have now been completed and savings of at least 5 per cent will be achieved without noticeable effect on service to the public.
The Council on Administrative Renewal, led by the Comptroller General of Canada, is reducing the cost of government administration. It is looking at alternative methods of delivering administrative services, at re-engineering current processes and at possibilities for sharing systems government-wide. This applies to areas such as financial management, materiel and property management, human resources and information management.
There will be some consolidation of administrative support functions between departments. A substantial portion of the federal government's operating costs are devoted to regulatory and enforcement activities. Some
Government Orders
savings are anticipated from the extensive regulatory reviews launched in the last budget.

Investing in people and technology, the government believes that to ensure a healthy economy it must maintain an innovative and professional Public Service. While the government has been forced to make hard decisions on wages and operating budgets it will continue to promote improvements to the way in which the Public Service is managed, and encourage innovations in the work place. As an example, the Treasury Board recently announced a pilot policy on telework that will help some employees better balance their work and personal demands. Through Public Service 2000, departments are fostering creative approaches to management that empower employees and create a more open and participative work environment.
