As I said in my opening remarks, the expenditure reduction measures announced by the Minister of Finance are very severe and far-reaching. The government is calling on federal employees to make greater sacrifices in their standard of living than at any time in recent memory. Similarly, we are calling on the Canadian public to understand why there may be reductions in some of the services they have grown accustomed to receiving. The service level may not be all we would like to provide but it will be the best the country can afford.
We will continue to work with our employees and their bargaining agents and consult with client groups to modernize government operations and to provide cost effective service to Canadians. I am confident that we can achieve the changes in government operations required to meet these spending reductions.
As President of the Treasury Board I have been exposed on a daily basis to the ways in which employees have vigorously met the challenges of restraint. I am certain that we can continue to pursue new ways to deliver programs and enable the Public Service of Canada to remain a vital national institution.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I rise to indicate that today's economic and fiscal statement by the hon. Minister of Finance earlier this afternoon lacks a plan of action to eliminate poverty and to attain full employment. In fact, it lacks social con-

Government Orders
science. It is a blueprint to penalize the unemployed, the poor on social assistance and the small businesses facing the credit crunch. I again remind this government of the stark social realities: 1.5 million unemployed, 2.3 million on social assistance, 3.8 million are poor, of whom 1 million are children, and 2 million rely on the food banks. Does this government care about them?
I ask the minister to explain how his government can indicate that the average benefits will be frozen and yet the only thing that will happen will be a reduction in benefits. Where is the arithmetic? How can an average figure be frozen when the only thing that will happen is a reduction and there is no suggestion of any increased benefits in any arm of the program? I cannot follow the arithmetic.
Will the minister, who has said public sector employees will be asked to accept a reduction in real take-home pay, not admit that it would be more compassionate and fair to reduce the size of cabinet today?
Would it not be better management to stop the illegal awarding of contracts to political friends to the tune of millions of dollars? As recently reported by the Auditor General, in the health and welfare department alone, 22 out of 23 contracts to the tune of millions of dollars were illegally awarded. Why does the minister not have a budgetary projection of savings by avoidance and cessation of illegal mismanagement by this government?

speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the hon. member says that this government lacks a plan of action to eliminate poverty. Then he states the numbers that are indeed very worrying: The number of unemployed, the number of people who are in difficult straits. My answer is that we have to provide real solutions for these people. It is very easy to say that there are problems and then to run away from solutions.
The reality is that unless the government puts order in the fiscal situation of Canada, which is threatened by the lack of revenue because of the recession and the slow recovery, all these programs are threatened.
It is not running away from these problems when we deal with that. This is more difficult than being easy and throwing money that we do not have, borrowing more which would cause the debt and the cost of the debt servicing to go up again and prevent us from having the money to help these people. It is precisely because we want to protect these programs that we are taking these very difficult measures.
The hon. member says he does not understand the freezing of UI. He has to understand that UI benefits are given based on the income of the people who lose their employment. The projections are that these incomes will indeed grow and the benefits will be frozen. Therefore, there will be a difference between the two.
He also talked about the size of cabinet. One could discuss this at length. It is possibly an illusion to believe by removing some ministers or many ministers-I will give him his choice-we would have huge savings. There are maybe many ministers to manage an administration which provides air traffic controllers, which provides health inspectors, and we hear the opposition saying there are not enough of them. The number of people will be the same with fewer ministers but we have a saving of a few million dollars and we have billions of dollars of problems. This is an illusion of a solution again.
He talks about contracts referred to by the Auditor General not being given in the proper way. The Auditor General has reported on a budget of $160 billion and he refers to some questions on $5 million. This is again an illusion that the hon. member thinks that these are the solutions to the real problem.
The Canadian government has to manage the economy at a difficult juncture. We have been very proud to be in government during the seven years of highest growth in the history of Canada. There is a difficult world-wide environment.
We are dealing with it by making the necessary adjustment. The government is not the solution to all the problems. It takes money and then redistributes it. We can take more but the member does not want us to raise the taxes so we have to borrow it. We pay our bankers. It costs more money which is not available for the poor people. We have to strike a balance. This is what we are trying to do and it is not easy.
December 2, 1992

speakerposition: N.D.P. Caucus Chair
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my question is for the President of the Treasury Board.
I believe it was two weeks ago yesterday that the United Nations International Labour Organization criticized the Canadian government for having abandoned true collective bargaining with its employees and urged the Canadian government to get back to the bargaining table with its employees. They were further asking the Canadian government to keep the ILO informed of progress toward the resumption of true collective bargaining.
I wonder if the minister would like to comment on that.

speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, a sub-committee of the ILO did consider that legislating wages as we have done is not the proper way to function in a normal environment. I do not disagree with that at all.
We are taking this difficult measure and we are doing it again, but not because this is the way we would like to do it. It is because we have to solve a problem. If it is not solved it will be our work force that will suffer from it.
The government can let things go until such time as we have to pay $50 billion instead of $41 billion in interest on our debt next year.
Listening to only those proposals made in the last few days on that side of the House, municipal infrastructure for this or for that, I counted about $25 billion. I do not mind spending it. We would be very popular.
However, what would happen? The rate of interest would go up. The government would not be able to find money to finance it. It would be a total disaster. Then we would have to fire hundreds of thousands of civil servants. This is not what the government wants to do. It wants to protect them by managing the affairs of the country in the best possible way.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, there is a lack of measures that I think would reduce government spending, but which have been discussed or debated. I am thinking for example of the administrative agreement with Quebec on manpower
Government Orders
which would save between $250 million and $300 million.
I also wonder whether we should not implement many of the recommendations made by the Auditor General, who says some practically scandalous things about the way this government manages the taxpayers' money.
I am also thinking about the paid trips for immigration officers to take people who have been denied admission by the immigration department back to their country. Remember that these officers have no jurisdiction outside Canada airspace. Their trip is paid, two per refugee, and I submit that very few refugees think of leaving the plane between take-off and landing. Nevertheless, two people are regularly paid to spend three or four days in Paris, New Delhi and so on.
I am especially thinking of the De Cotret Report which proposed reducing the number of departments and therefore the number of ministers. If I understand correctly, the minister said his colleague's report was an illusion. I would like him to explain his colleague is the victim of an illusion.

speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I did not say that my colleague's report was an illusion. I said that it is illusory to think that doing away with 10, 15 or 20 ministers will solve Canada's financial problem. It would save several million dollars, but the deficit is $32.6 billion. So it is a useful exercise and I agree with everything that can improve the way the country is run. I will always agree to support such measures but that is not a solution.
Of course the people who are deported cannot leave the plane but they can cause problems on board and that has happened very often. Airlines require that they be accompanied.
Third, on the administrative measures, the hon. member thinks that simplifying the management of manpower programs would save $250 million. That is totally absurd. Do we pay $250 million for administration? No, we give it to the beneficiaries. In any case, it is spent for their benefit. So how could we go about it? By taking it from the beneficiaries? This money certainly does not go to the officials but to the beneficiaries.
Treasury Board did a study of duplication in all governments in Canada, and I suggest that the hon. member read it. There are many examples.

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
Of course we could combine those programs under one roof. There are some savings to be made. But on the whole, it is like the parks service. The National Parks Service provides some programs and the provincial parks provide other types of programs. They can indeed be combined under one administration and we would save a little, but we still need wardens and people to receive the public. It does nothing to change the costs. Detailed studies have been done with the provinces. I would ask my friend to read them. There are savings, but it is illusory to think that would solve the multi-billion-dollar problems we have. We must not look for solutions in the wrong place. That is what is so tremendously frustrating. We could well cut 20 ministers, but it would do nothing to change Canada's deficit.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the minister in his speech used the words "illusion" and "illusory" at least six times.
What is illusory is the government poor attempt to try to create an image of credibility, of being able to manage this economy and this country responsibly. I say it presents an illusion because its credibility is much it at slake.
headed in the right direction and even makes some grandiose claims about the value of the GST. Good Lord, I did not know whether I was in the same place or whether the minister had just fallen from the clouds.
If there is a tax that is hated by Canadians everywhere, it is the GSt. It would not be that bad if the government would at least admit that even on its predictions with the GST it made enormous miscalculations.
The government thought it was going to produce in its first year $25.5 billion in revenues to replace the $18.5 billion normally collected by the manufacturers' sales tax. What was collected? This year it was $15.5 billion.
This is a tax that the minister in a bold-faced approach today says is satisfactory to manufacturers. Retailers are vaunting the fact that it has led to a depreciation in prices. I do not know whether the guy ever gets out of his chair. The reason there is a depreciation in prices is because there are no buyers. The buyers that do exist are going across the border to pick up their goods.
The GST has depressed consumer confidence. It has made the government much more intrusive in the affairs of small businesses and the lives of Canadians everywhere. Worse, it has driven a substantial portion of our economy underground.
What is illusory is its ability to predict, its ability to perform, and its ability to fashion out a vision for this country.
If we can take a look for a moment at its ability to predict, just from February to December of this year, in 10 months the Minister of Finance has indicated that he was off on his predictions of revenue.
First he predicts $132.1 billion but now it is $124 billion. He is off by 7 per cent. He is off on his predictions on the deficit, which he claimed would be only $27.5 billion, but in fact today is $34.4 billion. He is off by 25 per cent. He is wrong on the debt, which is $10 billion more than he predicted it would just last February.
I am limiting myself to just this year because the record of the finance ministers who preceded him over the course of the last seven years has been even worse. Yet he comes to us with a claim that the government is
Yet the minister talks in favourable terms about the direction he is taking this country. He says we are still going to lower the deficit and we do not do that by raising taxes but by controlling spending.
Let us judge the government according to its performance. We do not need to raise taxes. Personal income taxes between 1984 and 1988, in four years and arguably four of the best years from an economic point of view in Canada, went up by 59 per cent. There was a 59 per cent increase in personal income taxes. They went up a further 22.6 per cent between 1988 and 1992.
He talks about easing the tax burden in order to generate some positive confidence in the economy. Hie man has to be telling an untruth-I was going to say a bold-faced lie, but I cannot say that-of the greatest variety. Total direct taxes were increased between 1984 and 1988 by 46.2 per cent. They went from $49.9 billion to $73,097 billion. In the following two years, 1988 to 1990, they went up an additional 17.5 per cent.
December 2, 1992

We cannot believe these people any more. They do not even read their own statistics. We are going to judge them on their performance because these are great managers, as the minister just said, and they have to manage the economy in this country responsibly.
Let us take a look at what the Minister for International Trade said with great pride, almost with a sneering condescending attitude, when somebody dared to criticize what he had to say. Let us take a look at the performance of our export market, our international trade, under the great managers opposite.
Between 1984 and 1988 our merchandise trade balance went from $19.8 billion to $10.1 billion. That is a drop of 96 per cent. Great guys. Give them your investment portfolio. You will be penniless before the day is out. From 1988 to 1991, the period following that great advancement on free trade with the United States, what happened to that merchandise trade balance? It went from $10.1 billion to $7.4 billion. Thank the Lord it is still positive. However, the drop is a further 27 per cent. I am being kind.
I could have started with the current account balance. The current account balance under these great directors of the economy went from a plus $3,437 billion in 1984 to, in 1988, after their first term in office, a negative of $13,883 billion. We went into a deficit in four years when this economy was booming by everybody's standards.
What happened after 1988 to that current account balance? We have free trade when the government sold us another bill of goods. In three short years that current account balance went down a further 92.9 per cent to a negative $26,789 billion. Does the Minister for International Trade ever read his own statistics? Or does he just look in the mirror and say he is right and everybody else is wrong?
We are judging them on the basis of their performance in good times. Let us take a look at what they do in bad times because they are fond of comparing a program and performance of the previous government in 1982 in the recession. Yes, in 1982, the worst year of the recession, there were 10,265 bankruptcies in Canada.
In 1991, not yet the worst, there were 12,952 bankruptcies. This under the direction of those who know business like nobody else knows business.
Government Orders
The Minister for International Trade said we do not live in the real world. They do. We saw an increase under their great management in poor times of 26.2 per cent in bankruptcies.
Let us translate that into dollars. In 1982 those bankruptcies represented a loss of $1.9 billion, not an insignificant amount of money. In 1991 the value of those bankruptcies was $4.9 billion, an increase of 257.9 per cent in value to the Canadian economy.
The Minister of Finance, now that he is before us, says the government is going to do great things. His buddy, the guy who sits right beside him, says they know the marketplace, that we do not have a clue. They do not believe in an economy that is force fed by the government-I think I quote him correctly-but they believe in one that is driven by Canadian entrepreneurs free of government interference.
Let us take a look at what they are doing. They have a bill before the House, Bill C-91. What they are going to do with this bill is kill Canadian entrepreneurs dead in their tracks. The generic drug industry, according to government statistics, has 10 per cent of sales in drugs.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Legitimate ones.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
The generic drug industry has 25 per cent of the assets. It has built a critical mass of Canadian expertise and Canadian investment opportunities. It is going to advance in the world, but the government says: "No, no, no. We cannot have that. We do not want to interfere in the marketplace so we are going to bring forward legislation that will stop you dead in your tracks and transfer that money that would normally come into the Canadian economy to those who have the patents".
The predictions of these people cannot be believed. On the basis of their performance, these people cannot be believed, and they cannot be believed on the basis of the legislation they put in this House that kills Canadian businesses. Instead of accepting this kind of legislation that is force fed to us we have to defeat it, and if it passes we should rescind it the moment that we throw this bunch out.

December 2, 1992
Government Orders

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is with great interest that I listened to this speaker. He spoke with such eloquence.
I wonder whether it is really the Minister of Finance who is responsible for the predictions. If we look back in history we see that the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans had predicted Canada's deficit in 1985 would be $2.1 billion. In reality it turned out to be $34 billion.
Mr. MacEachen had said, for instance, that by 1983-84 the deficit would be $7.5 billion and in reality it was $32 billion.
Mr. Lalonde had another prediction. In 1983 Mr. Lalonde predicted that the deficit in 1986-87 would be $17.2 billion. In reality it was $30 billion.
Now we know what the Minister for International Trade said because I sat with him for quite awhile on the other side of the House and he was predicting as well that he would balance the budget, he would reduce the debt of Canada. What happened? We see in this year, for instance, the prediction was that the deficit would be $27.5 billion. In reality it is $34.6 billion.
I wonder whether the ministers, when they make those predictions, look back on the former statements and say it does make sense or it does not make sense because they have a very poor record of predicting budgets.
I think what really happens is the department does the predicting and the minister is that just a trained seal.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Is the word you are looking for a figurehead?

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
A figurehead. He just reads the speech in the House and everybody seems to be very impressed because he reads a nice speech. He does not address the fundamental problems. The fundamental problem is that Canada is today in a very sad situation.
Canadian Airlines and Air Canada are on the verge of bankruptcy. Air Canada's asset to debt ratio is one to nine. It is a bankrupt company and this government had appointed all the directors of that company. I wonder what the directors were doing? Were they checking whether the company was prospering, were they checking to see whether the company made right decisions, or they were just travelling around the world because they could travel with a pass.
Those directors were appointed by this government and they were friends of the government. The minister should be addressing those problems. He should address the problems with the Royal Bank that tells us today that 67 per cent of its outstanding loans are not being paid; $3.5 billion. Does he address that problem? No. Maybe the hon. member could comment?

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: I am sorry for the hon. member, but surely he expects the answer from the hon. member for Eglinton-Lawrence.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, you know that what I would do is give an answer that would only be complimentary to the government's record. I am glad he gave me the opportunity to compliment him on having the wisdom to change his position from that taken by that side of the House to that taken by this side of the House. By so doing he recognized the error of the government's ways.
Does the minister and do his other colleagues in cabinet ever take a look at the performance of their predecessors, the predictions of their predecessors, the state of the economy? Do they read the reports of their advisers, their bureaucracy, or even casual historians who have taken the trouble to research the performance of the economy in our country? I guess the answer is no. It is that simple. There is nothing in today's statement that would address the issues concerning the residents of my own city, which pays about 44 per cent of all federal and provincial taxes collected in this country.
Mr. Speaker, do you know what has happened to the economy of my city of Toronto? We can see it in the
240,000	unemployed. Nothing is going to be done in this economic statement for the welfare of those 240,000. That is the size of most major cities in this country. It is not going to do anything for the livelihood of the 680,000 people on welfare rolls in the great engine of Canada's economy.
The hon. member for Calgary asks if the government does its homework. The answer is obvious from its performance and its inability to predict. It is a resounding no.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate this opportunity to respond to the supply bill before us today in the amount of approximately $8 billion, an amount that just by chance is the amount of the additional deficit first reported in February of this
December 2, 1992

year and reported by the Minister of Finance as being almost $34.5 billion this afternoon.
The message that this report gave today is that we are having difficulty controlling our spending, that the economy is beyond our control and that as a government we cannot create the wealth that is so necessary in order to pay for the programs we need.
In addition, it is obvious that the government is having great difficulty creating jobs. That is the main issue. I would like to use the little time I have to speak on this bill to discuss the creation of jobs as it relates to the small business enterprise system.
I would like to say to the Minister of Finance that this is not a partisan issue. This is an issue that is on the minds of the 295 members of this House of Commons. It is an issue on which we should all put our minds together to try to address and combine our efforts to try to come up with a satisfactory solution. Everyone in this House must work toward a solution.
The creation of jobs by small businesses in Canada is a necessity. The Minister of Finance today in his opening remarks, and several times throughout his address, said he was going to be seeking the co-operation and assistance of all members of the House to devote ourselves to this very important function.
He outlined some of the plans he has for small business. I will restrict my remarks to that area. I compliment the minister for starting the thought processes going on that small business area. I must say that I do not think the plans went far enough and that I do not believe they will come close to fulfilling the responsibility we all have.
The facts are simply that we have 1.6 million people unemployed in this country. That number is growing. We take it as a given that large business is creating the problem today rather than helping us solve the problem. [DOT]
Tike a look at CN and its announcement of 10,000 lay-offs. We do not know how many people will be unemployed in the airline industry. Who knows how many people will be lost in the GM empire in the
Government Orders
Oshawa area. Take a look at Abitibi, where thousands of people are unemployed and there are more to come.
We also take it as a given that those in governments, quasi-governments, hospitals and educational institutions can no longer afford to create the jobs that are necessary. Therefore, the only prospect for job creation in this country is through the small business enterprise system. If we agree with this premise, and I do not think anyone can disagree with this premise, the question simply is: "What do we do to create a climate for business to help the small businessman and to hire some of those thousands of people who are on the unemployment rolls in Canada today?"
We all know the grease that makes a small business enterprise grow is money. Some of us who were small business before we got to this House know that it is called working capital. The Small Businesses Loans Act that was referred to today by the Minister of Finance is not an operative document. With respect, I say that the increase from $100,000 to $200,000 and now to $250,000 might as well be $5 million because I know very few businessmen in this country who know anything about the Small Businesses Loans Act.
Second, I do not think banks are interested. I think the Minister of Finance alluded to it today. Banks are not interested in advising their clients that small business loans are available for their enterprise. Why do we say this? We say it because in section 15 it spells out that the rate of interest that can be charged under this plan is the prime rate plus 1 per cent. We all know that banks are not interested in granting loans at prime plus 1 per cent, especially to the small business enterprise.
Therefore, that is not a very operative document. Unless this government and this House can get this message out most small business people in Canada will not have any knowledge of this particular plan.
Today the Minister of Finance referred to the regulations and said that the government was embarking on a program to make the regulations more simple and more easily understood. I happen to have all of the regulations relating to small business loans today. There are some 35 to 38 pages here. There are regulations 140, 151, 396, 369, 591, 891 and so on. I agree with the minister when he says that the government must clarify the regulatory system with respect to the small business person and

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
make things understandable for people in that enterprise.
I am a lawyer and I defy anyone to understand all of those regulations and make any sense of them. Therefore, I applaud the effort to make small business loans and all of the regulations pertaining to small business understandable to those who need it, namely the small business people in our community.
After we talked about the small business loan then we got to address the other problem that we are having, which is that we do not have a financial institution in this country that is interested in doing business with the small business person and yet we have the institution in place. We presently call it the Federal Business Development Bank. I am suggesting to the minister that we take this Federal Business Development Bank and rename it the Small Business Bank of Canada. Then as the Small Business Bank of Canada we change its terms of reference and let all small businessmen in this country know that they have a bank they can go to that is willing to support them. The Small Business Bank of Canada will be a bank of first resort for the small business community in this country rather than a bank of last resort, which is what we have today.
I am sure with that added competition within our community and with the chartered banks knowing that there is some competition out there they may open their doors and be more receptive to assisting the small business communities in our country.
Once we have established a climate to make capital available to the small business community, and once we have established that it is profitable, then we can get down to the essence of what we want the small business community in this country to do, which is to hire people.
When we ask the small business community in this country to hire people we are saying in essence: ''If you hire someone from the unemployment rolls we understand that naturally you have to train these people and retrain them". Rather than sending them through the formal retraining process at the colleges and universities we will have on the job skill development in the small business he is hired by. He will learn that particular skill in that small business.
In order to do that we have to assist the small business enterprise, either through tax incentives or some other
way that says: "We will pay for the skills development". That goes along with the UI benefits that were announced today.
Now we have a small business community that is willing to rehire and hire those people off the unemployment rolls and retrain those people. We all know, those of us who have ever been in small business, that the most valuable thing in small business today is a good faithful employee. There is not a small business person in this country who is willing to give up that valuable asset.
Once we have trained that person-let me just put the numbers together. There are 1.6 million people unemployed. There are 900,000 small businesses in this country. If we could get each small business to hire two people, on average, off the unemployment rolls then we will have not only solved the problem of unemployment but we will be looking for 200,000 more people to fill the job spaces. That would be creating wealth. That is what this government should do.
I know my time is running short but I-

speechtext: Order, please. Your time has now expired.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I was really interested in hearing my colleague from Thunder Bay speak about the effects of this kind of mini budget on small and medium-size companies.
One of the comments I have, which is going to be followed by a question, is that one of the major complaints of small business has been the GST. This government has said it would try to make it easy for small business to live with the GST. I know it has not.
The comment I have about the whole question of small business and the GST is that that there are several things that small businesses have complained about. One is that they have to pay GST but financial institutions, stockbrokers, banks and so forth pay nothing. It is perhaps just a coincidence that the Minister of Finance comes from the financial institution sector. It does not pay anything. Small business people, those 900,000 businesses that my hon. colleague was talking about, pay but others do not. That is one thing.
I would like to know how he sees this. Earlier I asked the former Minister of Finance why he did not tax these financial institutions and he said: "I cannot do it. It is too
December 2, 1992

complicated". I have never seen anything too complicated for this government, but that is beside the point.
The other question I would like to raise with my hon. colleague is that his party says that it would renegotiate, that it would rearrange or do something with the GST. Would that something be, or at least would he want that something to be, an imposition of a tax on these financial institutions to make it a fairer tax?

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank my colleague for that question. Concerning the first issue about the GST, as a result of the imposition of the GST we have 900,000 tax collectors in our country. It is a terrible expense on behalf of the small business community to collect this tax and it is very expensive. What I am suggesting and what I would hope our party would suggest-I am sure we would get a lot of support-is that if you are going to have someone working for you, you should pay them. If you are going to collect the GST, let us reimburse those who are responsible for collecting the GST and let us pay those who are responsible for keeping the GST in a trust account in order that those funds are available whenever they are required by the government.
The banks, stockbrokers, everybody should be paying the GST.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I know that my colleague was interrupted right in the middle of a suggestion with respect to a positive approach to small businesses.
Coming as he does from that great metropolis in northern Ontario, Thunder Bay, that has a history of producing gentlemen and other members who are very proactive when it comes to creating jobs, managing the economy and doing things that are appropriate from the government management point of view, I wonder if my colleague could share with the House some of those suggestions.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank my colleague from Eglinton-Lawrence. I just wanted to say we had a member of this House who could be used as a model that worked. I happened today to be involved in something else that was very important but I wanted to refer to him. It may answer my colleague's question.
Government Orders
He entered politics from Thunder Bay in 1935 and became a minister of transport and started Trans-Canada Airlines, which became Air Canada. He became the minister of munitions and supplies and took on the task of running Canada's war production. After the war he succeeded brilliantly in working beside a group of businessmen who came to appreciate his efficient and daring conduct on economic affairs. He returned the Canadian economy to a free enterprise system with minimal government controls.
The example the House should follow is that of the great Liberal C. D. Howe who brought this country to its highest point of employment and its highest point of producing wealth. That is the kind of leadership we need. That is the kind of leadership that the Liberal Party has given to this country over many years.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, there are parts of the statement I might agree with and parts I might disagree with. However I would like to repeat at the beginning a couple of the strongest parts of this particular economic statement that need to be heard certainly in my riding of Fraser Valley West and throughout Canada.
"Trade is our lifeblood". It is a generality but it is the truth: 30 per cent of Canada's economic activity and one job in four. My constituents are concerned about jobs. If trade is the place to find those jobs, we want to see that continue to expand and grow.
"The Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement has proved a success", $16 billion. Now $16 billion is a lot of jobs, a lot of taxes and is a lot of hope for Canada. That bears repeating at this time when Canadians are looking for hope.
North American free trade will give us 85 million new consumers, whose lifestyle and life quality are going up already, even without the agreement, and provide more opportunities for Canadians. There are hopes from the GATT and other opportunities.
It is very important that we should see Canada in its global context and its global interconnection around the world as a major issue of this Parliament and the next Parliament of Canada. In particular I would like to see a new Canada in a newly urbanizing global world. The pace of change continues to accelerate exponentially. Canada must see itself and find its place in this new globe. Among the global megatrends that are of concern

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
are population growth, rapid industrialization and urbanization.
It took the world over 2,000 years to get to 1650 and a population of about 500 million people, over 2,000 years from the beginning of our history. But it only took 200 years to double that population, from 1650 to 1850. It took only 100 years to double that, population again, from 1850 to 1950. It took only 40 years, from 1950 to 1990, to double that population again. The next doubling of the world's population of 5.3 billion people may be in 20 years. That is a new world. It is a new world for Canada to find its place and its opportunities in.
However there is another amazing trend. Within the massive population explosion of the world, another major trend is that in 1980, 1.8 billion of the world's people lived in major cities of the world, but by the year 2000 that will have increased from 1.8 billion to 3.2 billion. Over 60 per cent of the world's population is going to live in the large cities of the world.
Canada is no exception. Back in 1851 only 13 per cent of Canadians lived in cities. In 1981 76 per cent, and now over 80 per cent of Canada's population is living in cities. What does this 80 per cent of the population mean? It means that 80 per cent of the people we represent are living in cities. I am wondering if we are giving them 50 per cent, 40 per cent or even 20 per cent of the attention that the rapid growth of cities needs, not just in Canada but throughout the world.
I know what it means to people in the Fraser Valley where I live. It means that 30 years ago when I settled in the Fraser Valley every morning I would get up and see Mount Baker glistening in the sun or across it Golden Ears. If I was driving into town I could drive into Vancouver comfortably in half an hour. Vancouver did not get farther away, but now it is an hour and a half away. It is getting worse and worse.
This means that people who dreamed of this higher quality of life in our cities moved there, as I did and as most people in this Parliament did. They hoped for this better way of life. For the average commuter from my area-the average person commutes into Vancouver and out each day-it is getting longer and it is getting harder. Every time he commutes back and forth he is driving in his car and his car is pumping carbon monoxide into the
air. Now by noon we often cannot even see the mountains. It is another kind of Los Angeles.
Our air is getting harder and harder to breathe. The quality of our water and water supplies is threatened. I am embarrassed to say that Victoria is still dumping raw sewage into Puget Sound that floats down to Seattle, the other part of our megacity of 4.5 million people. Whether it is the disposal of waste, the quality of air or the lack of rapid transit, these kinds of things are taking the choice of Canadians for lifestyle and denigrating it.
Have we seen any kind of an emphasis from senior governments in this area? I regret to say in most cases it is a matter of downloading. I am not just speaking about Canada. I am talking about the world. The mayors of the cities of the world met in Curitiba and agreed it was a problem all over. They are getting all the population, all the people, all the growth, without the tax base to improve the infrastructure.
I am very pleased to see in this speech the issue of infrastructure. As a Canadian I certainly want to support infrastructure building wherever it can be done in Canada. I am very pleased to support Prince Edward Island for $800 million where we will connect 130,000 people to the mainland, connect an island to the mainland or an island province to the mainland of Canada.
When we look at priorities there are more people travelling in the morning to work over the Port Mann Bridge than there are in all of P.E.I. There are 1.7 million people on the lower mainland and another
400,000	in the Victoria area. We would like to have a land bridge to connect that too but we do not even ask for it because we see other priorities.
I am pleased that there is a thought of infrastructure here, but I wonder if it might better be spent, or some of it might be better spent, on infrastructure like rapid transit in our cities. That is the kind of thing we have to think about.
I was talking to the Minister of Finance the other day. He grew up in Vegreville, Alberta, and I grew up down the road in Maidstone on the Yellowhead Highway. They were wonderful places to grow up, great towns, great cities-Vegreville is a small city-and good places to live. I have not seen any traffic jams there for a long time, but
December 2, 1992

I live in one every day in my riding and so does everybody else. We need a little help.
The Port Mann Bridge is across the Fraser River. Maybe we need another bridge across there too. There is so much need that I am not even sure that is the correct need. Rapid transit is probably a more important need and a more important use than another bridge because we need to get people out of their cars to sustain the quality of life that we choose in Vancouver and to make sure that pollution does not just keep roaring out the valley. Not only is it coming from that valley but now it is coming from Seattle. It is all one big city. We must work and plan. That area is the fastest growing area of North America, in both Canada and the United States.
We need to work to accept that we cannot stop the doubling of the population over the next 20 years or 30 years. I do not know where it is going to go because we have mountains on one side and the ocean on the other. We have to plan how to sustain that city and that city will be sustained through improvements in infrastructure, communications, transportation, light rapid transit and these kinds of things. But how will it be financed?
We cannot finance every city in Canada but we have to recognize that most people in Canada live in Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver. These issues are big issues there and we cannot just keep downloading on those systems as do both levels of government not only in Canada but throughout the world.
We will need to find in the Speech from the Throne following this economic statement new ideas and thinking in new ways. We have this fuzzy warm feeling that Canada is a rural nation. Yes, agriculture is terribly important and some people in Canada still live in the rural areas but 80 per cent live in the cities. If we want to keep this warm fuzzy image of rural Canada with rural values which are great values and my values, that is fine; but let us live with the reality that 80 per cent of our people live in cities and let us get on with developing sustainable city programs.
Our Prime Minister and Minister of the Environment showed great leadership at the earth summit in Rio. They recognized in agenda 21 the human settlement problem of cities. They had ideas. They said: "Let us establish a sustainable development commission". While
Government Orders
the rest of the world is going to proceed with these kinds of things, where will Canada be in the follow-up to Rio, in the follow-up to how we will sustain these megacities because the world is becoming a series of city states? Just as we must connect the cities of Canada we must connect the city states of the world.
How do we change this thought from rural Canada to urban Canada and then how do we help our Minister of Finance see those needs, recognize them and turn them into programs? I think Canada should demonstrate this to the world. If we have the highest quality of life in the world, and that highest quality of life is found for our people who are living in cities, obviously, then how do we sustain that high quality of life? Can we lead and show the world that Canada knows how to sustain its cities?
Our cities are among the most magnificent. Mayor Dore of Montreal showed great leadership at the United Nations and had a great world conference in his city. Toronto had a similar conference and showed the way. Vancouver had the global parliamentarians conference that so many of us attended, and where a resolution was passed that said: "Urbanization is a world problem. Let us do something about it".
In British Columbia Mike Harcourt talks about his Georgia Basin project. He saw this coming for a long time. We have to take the city in the context of its bioregion. They are working together with Seattle and with the U.S. Congress.
These are the kinds of visionary programs where we look to the way we are and almost all of us are urban dwellers-and then we try to find ways to sustain and improve that quality of life.
I appreciate this economic statement and the need, as I have said, to connect to the world through GATT. We are having successes there. I applaud the government on those things. I applaud it on Rio and the earth summit on the environment.
However, if we cannot breathe the air, drink the water and dispose of wastes in these types of megalopolises and if we cannot move comfortably around them then what are we working for? We need to hold new values and bring them forward as we work toward the Speech from the Throne and toward the next generation of urbanizing ideas.

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
In addition, we also need to recognize that the power of the world and the power of the world's relationship with Canada is where the power is. The power is in Pacific Asia. In 1984 we looked at Pacific Asia and we gave it a good push. We are developing economic relationships. Japan is the number two trading partner for Canada now. If we look at the top five or six we will find China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Korea and the ASEAN groups. This is the future of Canada. That future is building upon the ideas that are in this statement.
We have a North American free trade agreement. Through APEC this can be expanded to cover the entire Pacific region. It is important that we should not see another bloc in the Pacific, as is being proposed by Malaysia. It would be an Asia-only trade bloc, similar to an Europe only trade bloc. I hope our minister will take the innovations of the North American free trade agreement and expand very soon, perhaps, to South America. However, let us keep going around the rim and keep this concept of one free-trading world.
I quoted the minister's 30 per cent figure, which means one in four jobs and $16 billion in the free trade agreement already. This is where our future lies. Let us not run from crisis to crisis. Let us help in Europe and Somalia. Let us help build the critical, tough areas of the world. I have always supported that and participated in that. Let us not be diverted from the future of Canada in the Pacific Asia region.
I have my concerns that this has diminished in its importance. I urge members to think, between now and the throne speech, once again about the Pacific and the reality of Canada as an urban nation.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I enjoyed very much the hon. member's address. I noted his comments about the infrastructure issue and how he would foresee that some of these funds would be directed toward mass transit.
The objective here is to essentially invest in strategic infrastructure development that would improve competitiveness and improve the productivity of the Canadian economy.
We have a number of specific proposals or projects in mind, particularly those that fall within federal government ownership. We will be sitting down with the provinces to determine what their priorities are and to try to work out the appropriate sharing arrangements so that we can move ahead on these projects.
While it is not clearly defined in the background documents or in the speech itself, there is provision to ensure that we will open that dialogue with all the provinces to try to see if we can work toward fulfilling some of their goals and objectives that would enhance the economy and productivity and therefore the competitiveness of our country.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to thank the minister for those comments very sincerely. I sense that the minister heard what I said.
I know that the Government of British Columbia is very anxious to talk about their needs on infrastructure. They are not mentioned here in particular, but remember that you said they should be focused on something that relates to making us more competitive.
I am an advocate for parks and tourism and so forth. It is very important, but really we might look at the airport system in Vancouver. That is going to increase our competitiveness. The bridge in P.E.I. is important politically and I am sure it is economical. I am not sure how it will improve our competitiveness, but I can think of three or four other bridges in three major cities of Canada with which we might improve competitiveness.
I certainly want to be for the maritimes and for all of Canada, so wherever we are spending this money on infrastructure, I am in favour of it. I am just saying that we have to watch the priorities.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened with interest to the member for Fraser Valley West. I know that he is concerned about the environment and about developing Canada to be a prosperous country.
I wonder what his opinion is about transportation somewhat. I see this government has abandoned railways. It has abandoned air traffic because our companies, such as Air Canada and Canadian Airlines, are going bankrupt.
Does he believe that our country should have a railway system. It is efficient and less polluting than cars and trucks, especially since we have a very bad climate. I
December 2, 1992

Mr. Speaker, the first question is whether this is an economic statement, a mini budget or a maxi budget? What is it?
I suppose one could go to maxi skirts and mini skirts for the parallel. We must ask ourselves what this budget is trying to cover up or reveal. If it is in that particular context, then I would submit that it is a full-blown budget and probably a maxi budget.
We cannot see an awful lot of the government's over-all strategy. Yet we can see a little. We can see some. We can get a glimpse of what the government is up to. I submit to the Minister of Finance who I am delighted to see in the House this evening, that the underlying and double-barrelled premise here, cynical as this sounds and cynical as I believe it is, is that the government has taken a couple of basic political decisions.
First, the poor and the unemployed are never going to vote for this government again. That is not just me saying this as a statement of fact. It is me pretending to be the government coming to that conclusion. The government has said: "We know one thing for sure. The poor and the unemployed are never going to vote for us again, so we need not worry about them".

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
The second part of the double-barrelled premise concerns the business community that came to the rescue of the Tories in other elections. Given the right circumstances, it can be depended on to vote for this government. That is the double-barrelled premise. First, the poor and unemployed will never, ever again vote for this crowd. If the government came to that conclusion, it is absolutely right. The second part of the premise is that given the right circumstances, some people in the business community with enough plums and incentives and things dangled in front of them could be induced to vote for this government again.
Accept for the moment, at least for the purpose of debate, that those are a couple of parts of a double-barrelled premise on which to build a budget. Just follow through on what this government and the Minister of Finance have done today. He has socked it to the unemployed, to the low-paid worker and the poor and he has dangled a few plums in front of the business community. That is the basic strategy. Everything flows from that. Everything in the budget flows from that basic premise, as cynical as it is.
One of my big disappointments about this budget-I am not completely surprised by it but I am certainly disappointed by it-is the double-talk, the untruth. Listen to this statement on page 12 of the minister's statement today. It states:
The actions I have announced today will bring the estimated
deficit down to $34.4 billion this year.
Bring the deficit down to $34.4 billion. I suppose there is a way in math to state that as a downward trend. What would it be, a minus reduction? We could call it a minus reduction. He has gone all the way down from $27.5 billion to $34.4 billion. That is a drop, a real precipice, an absolute 90 degree cliff. Bang, straight down from $27 billion to $34 billion.

I know the argument that things have changed. I guess they have changed. One of the things that caused them to change was the interest rate policy of this government. He happens now to be the Minister of Justice. I used to be in his caucus when he was leader of the party in Newfoundland, Ed Roberts. Ed was known and is known-

The minister by his policies and the policies of his administration having perpetrated the deed he now comes to this House looking for mercy. I got your signal, Mr. Speaker, and I realize that my time has almost run out but I hope not before I get a chance to address one other issue on this same page, page 12 of the minister's statement.
I would submit to him, to this House and to the people of Canada that by far the most cowardly and at the same time the most dastardly statement ever to appear in a budget speech anywhere at any time has to be the following:
Persons who voluntarily quit their jobs without just cause, or who lose their jobs because of their own misconduct, will no longer receive UI benefits.
Follow it through. Put aside for the moment that some people quit without cause. They quit because they figured out how to milk the system. I understand one of the things the minister is alluding to. But he uses a sledgehammer to get at a mosquito here, a very terrible sledgehammer. He must understand it. This is something in his budget that he has to go back on. He has to take that statement out in the interest of basic human rights and basic decency. What he has here is hearkening back to the sweat house days of pre-industrial England.
This is what William Booth who started the Salvation Army was talking about in darkest England. This is the kind of thing where the employer was in the driver's seat, where he called all the shots. With this document, this statement, he knows that the employee is not going to quit because he or she will be afraid they will not qualify for UI. He knows that he can ride that employee right into the ground and when he gets them into the ground, he can then fire the employee.
He knows the employee can be fired for misconduct because the minister has said so. Apparently he has intentions to legislate that. The employer knows that employee is already on his knees economically. While he might pursue the question of whether there was cause to

charge misconduct he has nobody to buy the groceries in the 12 or 15 months it takes to prove that particular charge. It is a dastardly thing. I see your signal, Mr. Speaker. My time is up.

speechtext:
that in the opinion of this House, third party advertising during elections should be restricted to individual Canadians and limits on the amount each person can spend should be established.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I raised this motion which is very important to democracy in this country. In the 1988 election many Canadians were concerned about the amount of money that was spent, especially by those who supported the free trade agreement. There was a feeling in many ridings by many Canadians that the money that was spent by those advocates of the free trade agreement helped to have an undue influence during the election period.
Of course, the problem is that we take away the fairness in our system. In 1975 we had four basic fundamentals about our elections in this country. We required parties and candidates to provide full disclosure of election expenses and full disclosure of income sources. We put limits on total expenses and we required black-out provisions to restrict and limit the influence of paid advertising. Those were requirements that were put in place for all parties and all candidates. It came out of a sense of election fairness to make sure we did not go the route of other countries, notably the United States.
In the United States, it is interesting to note that in the last election many American congressmen and senators and their staff talked about the amount of time they spent raising money for elections. Those of us who pick up a lot of the American channels in our ridings also noticed the types of advertising, the vehemence, the hatred and the anger that was put out by various groups in their paid advertising.
Canadians have been well served by our different approach of disclosure and our approach of limitations. Part and parcel of the limits we put on candidates and political parties is a restriction in the act that has limits on third party advertising.
In 1984 in a lower court in Alberta this provision was struck down on the basis of the charter. Here we are many years later and this Parliament has not introduced new measures in this very important area. As I mentioned earlier, without any real restrictions, we run the risk of another election very similar to what we had in 1988. We do not want to see that happen. We do not want to see completely unlimited spending by special interest groups while at the same time we have severe limits on what political parties and political candidates can spend.
With the types of groups that are forming in various parts of this country that have a lot of money, it is quite possible that the candidate for Thunder Bay-Atikokan or Prince Albert-Churchill River could find out that they are entitled to spend less money in their whole campaign in providing literature, in dealing with all the issues, in making contact with the voters, paid advertisements or whatever other means they have to use to campaign in their ridings. For all of those purposes they could end up being able to spend less money than one single issue group that wants to campaign against it. That is the problem with what is happening in this country at the present time.
We need a strong law that does not completely prevent third party advertising, does not take away the right of freedom of expression, but which puts reasonable limits on money spent in the exercise of those rights. Politicians, political parties and candidates have respected those same limitations on themselves since 1975. What we are saying is that the same thing should apply to other Canadians.
The Lortie royal commission came down with a figure of $1,000 that could be spent by individuals or groups. To make sure that there was no collusion, it also recommended that groups could not combine to make sure that if one person spends $1,000, and somebody else spends $1,000, all of a sudden you find you have $50,000, $60,000, or $80,000 being spent in one riding by what in essence is one special interest group.
December 2, 1992

We have a law based on fairness but we have a glaring loophole in that law at the present time, a loophole which was, as I said, exercised by those who defended the free trade agreement, those in this country with lots of money. We cannot afford to allow that to happen in the future.
I call upon this government and all parties in this House to ensure that before we have the next election, which must occur within a one-year period, we have reasonable restrictions. We are not asking for a complete outlawing of third party advertising but reasonable limits to make sure that our system is fair, to make sure that those Canadians who are out there working in an election, trying to explain their political philosophy, their dream of where this country should be going and how it should be governed, do not find themselves swamped by those people who have large contributions from all sorts of sources which under the present law are basically secret sources.
We do not know who contributes to the National Citizens' Coalition. We do not know who has contributed to some of the large corporations and some of the front groups that will exist during a federal election campaign. Parties have to list their donors. They have to give the addresses of their donors. They have to make that information public. We should insist that all those who wish to participate in a campaign period should have restrictions in terms of public disclosure as well.
If somebody contributes to the New Democratic Party and it is over a certain amount of money, whether it is $100 or perhaps $250 in the future, we have to make that information public. If someone is campaigning in a riding, or in a province, or in this whole nation on a certain issue, they also should have to make public the sources of their income. We must make our system fair.
We must avoid the excesses of the United States. The only way we can do so is to make sure that we keep restrictions on candidates and parties. If we take that away then we have lost any sense of fairness. We will all end up with the dollar buys the election system of the United States. We also must make sure that for those others who have a legitimate point of view and who choose to work outside of the political parties, there are
Private Members' Business
reasonable limits and that they account publicly for where they raise their money.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have the opportunity to discuss the motion that has been sponsored by my colleague, the member for Churchill.
His motion is to the effect that third party advertising during elections should be restricted to individual Canadians, and limits on the amount each person can spend should be established. This question of spending limits is an important one and is subject to the entire range of public opinion.
As a matter of background the Lortie royal commission on electoral reform was created back in November 1989. It held extensive public hearings across the country and heard hundreds of suggestions for improvements in the electoral process. Indeed, its final report was more than 1,500 pages and contained 267 recommendations.
The research studies produced during the course of the royal commission, which will be assiduously studied by my friend from Kingston and the Islands, and will comprise some 23 volumes at the end of the day.
The job of the parliamentary committee on electoral reform, of which the hon. member for Churchill is a member, as I am, is to review the findings of that royal commission and report to Parliament.
In regard to the question of spending limits, let me mention that there were amendments to the Canada Elections Act in 1974 which prohibited spending during an election campaign by third parties that favoured or opposed a political party or candidate. However, exempt from this prohibition was spending relating to an issue.
In 1983 Bill C-169 removed that exemption and created the current prohibition which prevents any election expense that is not channelled through a candidate or through a registered political party.
However, as things stand today under the Canada Elections Act, as a practical matter there is no limit on third party spending. That is because back in 1984 the Court of Queen's Bench in Alberta rendered a decision called the National Citizens' Coalition case, in which the court struck down the then spending limits on third

December 2, 1992
Private Members' Business
parties. The court ruled that the provisions of the act prohibiting third party spending were on their face a restriction on freedom of expression. Indeed, the judge stated, and I quote: "Care must be taken to ensure that the freedom of expression as guaranteed by section 2 of the charter is not arbitrarily or unjustifiably limited. Fears or concerns of mischief that may occur are not adequate reasons for imposing a limitation. There should be actual demonstration of harm or a real likelihood of harm to a society value before a limitation can be said to be justified."
The court then went on to conclude that the limitations on freedom of expression were not reasonably justified in a free and democratic society.
In the last federal election in 1988 no spending limit existed to restrict the expenses of individuals or groups other than candidates or registered political parties.
The situation today is this: During an election campaign, while spending limits exist in so far as candidates and political parties are concerned, there is no limit imposed on third parties. Outside of the writ period, there are no limits on anyone, any individual, political party or single or special interest group, to promote any or all issues.
The Royal Commission on Electoral Reform and Party Financing did hear representations from different interveners on this specific issue, as it did on many others. A number of the interventions reflected dissatisfaction about the involvement of third parties in the 1988 campaign, or concern about the impact of third parties in the democratic process. On the other side, there were substantial arguments about maintaining individual rights and the rights of free speech.
There was substantial support both from those who supported and those who opposed restrictions on third party activities for requiring or reporting of third party spending and disclosure of the source of their contributions. The Canadian Bar Association made a presentation in favour of a principal balance between the rights of free expression and the need for some measure of equality.
The royal commission in the report provided in February of this year recommended that election expenses incurred by any group or individual independent from registered parties and candidates not exceed $1,000. It further recommended that the sponsor be identified on
all advertising or distributed promotional material and that there be no pooling of funds.
In coming to this recommendation, the commission stated and I would like to again quote from the royal commission report: "A regulatory approach that seeks to promote the fundamental value of fairness in securing the right of individuals and groups to participate in an election campaign by incurring election expenses must acknowledge that individuals and groups cannot be equated with candidates and political parties in the design of spending limits.
"The regulatory treatment of independent expenditures must respect the essential and primary role of candidates and political parties in elections by recognizing the nature and potential impact of independent expenditures".
The royal commission attempted to strike a balance between the individual freedom of expression and the need for a fair process in so far as the parties and candidates for which spending limits exist. As colleagues know, the four volume report of the royal commission is now in the hands of the parliamentary committee for study. Hearings are going on at the present time and third party spending limits, one of the important and difficult issues that the committee will have to consider as part of the bigger picture, are being considered.
I do not believe it would be advisable for us to deal with this issue in isolation from the other issues raised and dealt with in the report of the royal commission. The Canada Elections Act is a comprehensive piece of legislation, its provisions are interdependent, and there is a danger in dealing with financial provisions of the act in isolation.
Frankly, my personal point of view on this matter at the present time is that the individual's right to free expression, his or her freedom of speech must remain paramount. I have rather an aversion to regulation and am not convinced that there is a legitimate argument for spending limits; notwithstanding the report of the royal commission and the viewpoint of my colleague who posed this motion here this evening.
I remain unconvinced. There were substantial expenditures in the recent election and it is quite evident that money did not rule there. Until I could be satisfied that money and money only is the governing principle in these matters I guess I would want to be on the side of
December 2, 1992

the individual's right to spend as he or she sees fit for whatever cause he or she may choose.
I respect the point of view that my colleague from Churchill has put forward in moving this motion. We have I think an honest and legitimate variation. There are lots of differences of opinion on this particular issue, but above all else it is part and parcel of a number of measures that are presently being dealt with by the special committee on electoral reform, which is holding many hours of discussion and examining in detail the many proposals put forward by the Royal Commission on Electoral Reform and Party Financing.
The special committee was tasked to study the royal commission's report and to make recommendations to the government. In my view it would be appropriate to let this committee carefully study this issue of third party spending in the context of the entire recommendations of the royal commission report and ultimately allow the parliamentary committee to make the appropriate recommendations.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speakerposition: Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be able to participate in this debate this evening on this very interesting motion put forward by my colleague the hon. member for Churchill.
Like the hon. member for Swift Current-Maple Creek-Assiniboia, I have been involved in the work in the committee on electoral reform which has been considering this very question. I am concerned that the progress we are making on this particular issue is not entirely in accordance with the report of the royal commission. Nor is it in accordance with the wishes of many of us in this party who believe that third party advertising has been a problem in this country. It is one that should have been dealt with some time ago. It certainly constituted a particular problem during the course of the last election campaign.
The recent American experience indicates that the electorate cannot be bought by fancy, glitzy advertising campaigns. Indeed I am sure many of my friends opposite remember the leadership convention they had in, I believe it was 1976, when the Minister Responsible for
Private Members' Business
Constitutional Affairs was chosen to be the leader of their party. I think I have got the year correct on that.
They will recall that the present Prime Minister engaged in a very glitzy and very expensive advertising campaign. Many commentators suggest the reason he lost the leadership race in 1976 to the Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs was because of this very glitzy campaign that he mounted for that particular leadership campaign.
I was not at that convention, so far be it for me to say what it was he did wrong. I have only read about it. I would not have been caught dead at such a convention.
Nevertheless, the convention went ahead. The current Prime Minister was defeated in his bid for the leadership of the Tory party. They ended up with the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs who was Prime Minister briefly and then of course got appropriately knifed in the back by the current Prime Minister in a subsequent leadership campaign.
In that campaign he deliberately spent on a less glitzy scale. We suspect that perhaps less money was spent, but of course we do not know that.
Money does not buy everything in politics. Perhaps you, Sir, were at one of those conventions and can tell us a little more about it later. In any event, it does not buy everything in elections. But the fact is that it is perceived by the public to be an indication of tremendous electoral power. It is certainly considered that if the party with the substantial amount of money is able to get its message out more effectively and communicate with more people it is more likely to win the election.
I can say that in my own experience, clearly I won in spite of the expenditures that were made by the other candidates, as well as third parties. My own electoral experience was that the other candidates for the other two major parties in Kingston and the Islands both spent more than I did in the election in 1988.
The fact is there was a substantial amount of advertising by other persons who were not registered parties, who particularly in the last few weeks of the campaign advertised extensively in favour of free trade which was favoured by only one of the candidates in that election. She was the candidate for the governing party and was

December 2, 1992
Private Members' Business
not successful in spite of this massive expenditure of funds by these third parties.
I cannot help but feel that it is unfair that those parties should participate in the electoral process without any restraint when those of us who are candidates in the election are restricted in what we are allowed to spend.
I know that the Reform Party in its public statements says that it is against any restriction on campaign spending. The wealthiest takes all in the view of the Reform Party. That is not surprising because one has to be well to do to be successful in the Reform Party.
I am sure my friend from Saint-Denis would say it is the same for the Conservative Party. If one is not well to do, one will not be successful in the Conservative Party. I would not want to be so unkind.
There are a few perhaps who have been successful in that party who do not have buckets of cash, but I do not know who they are and I would not want to speculate. I see some hon. members pointing to themselves. That may be accurate, I do not know. It is not for me to judge. Perhaps they can stand up and file a statement of net worth later on.
It is a problem that some people are able to mount extensive campaigns based on the money their friends have available and thereby influence the outcome of the election. It is that third party advertising that this motion is intended to end.
I fully support the motion. I believe that the limits proposed in the motion are fair and reasonable, that there should be limits. It does not say what the figure should be.
The royal commission recommended a limit of $1,000 per person, but it defined persons to include more than individuals. I am surprised that the hon. member for Churchill, a member of the New Democratic Party, is not agreeing with the proposal put forward by the royal commission. It allowed unions and corporations to communicate with their members or shareholders, as the case may be, and that would be exempt from the $1,000 restriction.
A union could send out a mailing to all its members and it would not have to worry about the $1,000 ceiling and similarly a corporation could do the same to its
shareholders. Perhaps the fact that shareholders were included scared the hon. member off and he decided that he could do without the limitation for unions. I am sure Bob White would not agree with his position, but who knows because he is not here. I guess he is busy running the province of Ontario, running it into the ground.
What the royal commission recommended is reasonable. In my own view the $1,000 limit is overly generous and should be restricted to something more like $500 which would be plenty. However, I may not reflect the view of all members of the House when I say that a restriction like that is fair and reasonable.
My concern is that we try to get a restriction in place before the next election so that we are not left with a free-for-all on election spending by non-political parties. If there is going to be a fair restriction in place, and I think there is, on the spending by political parties in this country, there has to be a restriction on spending at least during some period during the campaign on the expenditures of other non-political party groups who are involved or wish to participate in the advertising and dissemination of literature in the campaign.
The proposal put forward by the royal commission is generally fair, as is the proposal put forward by the hon. member for Churchill. I hope the chief government Whip who I see is here tonight and of course is in the anomalous position of being chairman of the Special Committee on Electoral Reform will agree to allow for this motion to pass tonight by unanimous consent.
