of the word "advertising". Current Canadian election
December 2, 1992

law limits candidates in its written form, individuals and third parties to spending money during a period of time.
That money could be spent on the rental of a building or rental of a pair of ice skates or buying Chinese meals or some other kind of meals for people. We say that in our wisdom we must restrict the spending of money during an election period, not money specifically for the purpose of advertising.
What the member is trying to do with his motion is put some kind of limitation on the system as he talks about equity and fairness, but that limitation is on spending money directly for the purpose of influence.
We can have a more intelligent discussion and resolution of some of the issues on the table if he means it. If he thinks the evil is advertising then let us talk about advertising and get rid of all the other things that in committee he is constantly telling us should be limited.
That we should limit the capacity to paint the wall, to put something on the floor, to clean the sidewalk, to clean the snow off in the winter lime and to spend money on all of these purposes is the view he advances consistently in committee. Yet in public in the House he talks about advertising.
It is like a conversion on the road to Damascus, and most of us who serve on the committee find it to be a welcome relief from past practices. If he means it boy, we are going to have some good discussions in the next 10 days as we work on our draft report. We may be able to break some of the log-jams that have been around for quite awhile.
Let us also examine the issue of the principle of limitations. Let me state clearly and for the record that my personal instincts based on my own experience are that more problems than solutions are created through limitations.
I recognize that is a minority view for most people who are connected to electoral processes. We are all stuck with the notion that to amend the election act, we certainly must have the support of half of the people in this Chamber. It would move forward more smoothly with a better sense for Canadian people if it moves forward unanimously.
Private Members' Business
We are all stuck in the business of making reasonable compromises that will still respect the integrity of the system. I fully expect that regardless of my attempts to be persuasive to my colleagues I am not going to be able to get the majority of members of this House to say that the best policy position is an unlimited expenditure position, that the truest way and the best way to run a democracy is to let people try to influence each other.
When we look at the system which is in current law there is a limit on expenses that do not really relate in a very direct way to influencing people, but they are in there. The taxpayers are charged with the responsibility of a rebate. People are charged with breaking the law and threatened with losing their seat or having to go to jail or something for breaking them. You begin to see what I mean when I talk about the problems with limits.
If we could talk about a simpler, smaller basket of limits, then the problems are less complex. There are fewer dividing lines or border lines. The resolution at least can be better. That is the compromise I would suggest from my position of no limits and his position of a lot of limits. Can we agree on reasonable limits?
There should be agreement on a smaller basket of things so that there are fewer problems and they are more directly related to the notion of influence. That is really what people who talk about fairness are trying to do something about.
I was interested in listening to my colleague across the way from the Liberal Party pointing out that when there is unlimited spending authority, we can spend ourselves right out of voter approval.
History is full of voting situations where the electorate comes to the conclusion that this particular persuasion, this particular person, this particular group spent too much. They make the judgment that the particular person or group is not the right one to run things because they do not exercise a sense of responsibility adequately. Therefore, they would not be good managers of the country or the economy or anything else.
The minute limits are put on things, that is the minute where we begin to say to the electors that there is something artificial going on here. We are not getting the real picture of where people are and the judgments

December 2, 1992
Private Members ' Business
they would make. We do not give the spendthrifts the opportunity to show people that they are spendthrifts.
That is part of the logic that runs through my mind as to the reason that elections without limits would provide a fairer picture to Canadians of where people were coming from.
Another thing we should look at is the limit today on the period for advertising. We can spend all the money we want until the day a writ is issued. We can spend millions of dollars, if we had it, every day for four years. Then one magic day a writ is issued. All of a sudden, one dime cannot be spent on advertising for example, from the 60th day prior to voting day until the 28th day prior to voting day. Then all of a sudden we can spend, but within limits.
The only time we are blocked from spending money to communicate with electors is the first 30 or 32 days of a writ, the notification of when the election is to occur. There is a kind of absurdity in that too. But I may be forced to swallow that as a principle because it is established. It has been around awhile and members are experienced with it and comfortable with it.
In closing, I would say to the House that we are already seized to the issue. It comes through the electoral reform committee. It comes to us because of court decisions that have struck down sections of the act already. The electoral reform committee will be dealing with it and we will be reporting to the House at the earliest possible opportunity so that we get our conclusions and recommendations to the House and in the public domain as quickly as we can.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to start by thanking the chairman of the special committee which is now examining the Canada Elections Act, the hon. member for Calgary West, the hon. member for Champlain who is on the committee, the hon. member for Gaspe, whom I see more often, the hon. member for Swift Current-Maple Creek-Assini-boia, my colleague from Kingston and the Islands and the hon. member for Churchill.
It is a good idea to let Canadians know what we are doing. For hours on end, Mr. Speaker, for what seems like ages, we have been sitting to consider how to update the Canada Elections Act. There is of course a very important issue, and it happens to be the subject of the
hon. member's motion, which is about individual Canadians having the right to do third party advertising during elections.
I always like to discuss the historical aspect. There are many ways to learn about the history of Canada. I remember, Mr. Speaker, and I am sure you do, since you were a member of this House, when we produced a bill to restrict election expenses. The legislation is very strict, and I am very glad about that. It gives members like me a certain amount of independence, since I do not have to speak at all kinds of gala evenings to raise funds to pay for my election campaign. We know all about that in Quebec, and it is something the people in my province understand. I hate having my hands tied by lobbies of all kinds, because election campaigns are expensive.
In keeping with the spirit of the time, we created a very modern piece of legislation that is the envy of the United States. Personally, I know senators and members of the House of Representatives who envy us, because they say: We, as members of Congress, instead of looking after the needs of the nation, are almost continuously at the mercy of our fundraisers.

This is one of the great dangers of the American system. Elected people most of the time belong-I will not say willingly-to lobbies of all kinds. I am going to be nice tonight. I will not mention the most important lobbies. The danger is that they have to raise money all the time in order to get elected. During that time, of course, they are not looking after world affairs. They are not looking after a good social system or medical system because they are raising money. We do not have to do that in Canada. We have a good law.
I am talking directly to Canadians. If they would only understand that by giving $10 or $100 to the party of their choice they could get money back on their income tax, they would participate. Instead of attacking Parliament all the time, they should say: "I am putting my money where my mouth is. I can choose any political party. I will make sure these people are independent and that they limit their expenses".
What happened during the last election? Third parties came in, as my colleague the member for Hamilton East would say, like a Mack truck while my esteemed friend from Kingston and you, Mr. Speaker, and all my colleagues were desperately watching their expenses right
December 2, 1992

to the penny. In my district I spend, on and off, around $40,000. That is according to the law.
Suddenly third party advertising arrives. Powerful lobbies of all kinds spend an unlimited amount of money and in a way have-I hope it is a good word in English-bastardized a beautiful intention of a pure invention of Canada. It is unique in the world. Third party advertising is leading us directly to the Americanization of our political system and I deplore it. It has nothing to do with my friendship with the American citizens, but I do not like their system. I prefer ours.

There must be limits and I know the judges of the Supreme Court are looking into this. It is their job to analyse the intent of the legislator. We do not give instructions to judges. That is also a Canadian virtue. I like the way we appoint judges. In the United States, they are elected. Elect a judge? Imagine. I would hate to campaign against a judge, lose and live in the same district. But in Canada we have a good system and the judges always try to find out what the legislator meant.
I helped draft this legislation under the previous government. I want it to preserve its original intent which was to give members who wanted it, the maximum amount of intellectual freedom. If they don't want it, that is their problem, but for members like me, who want to be a little more independent within our parties, it means we don't get pushed around as much. We can say: "Listen to me." I remember when I was a young parliamentarian and they told me: "If you don't do this or that, you won't get any money from the campaign fund". Now you understand why I get so passionate and emotional about these issues. Once they told me: "You know, if you talk too much, the money from the campaign fund-" Nobody knew exactly what it was. There was a kind of mystery about it but we put a stop to that.
In Quebec they stopped all that, although there is still room for improvement. But at least the tools are available for those who want to use them. I know I am not being partisan tonight and I know my views are shared by many colleagues in all political parties. Even
Private Members' Business
the Bloc Quebecois, which has just joined us, seems to agree with me. Just imagine. Prud'homme and the Bloc. We live practically next door to each other and more or less share the same parishes, but I know its members support that. I know the hon. member for Champlain do and the hon. members for Churchill and Kingston so it will have to be done.
Every time we are ready to pass some good legislation-this is for the judges who interpret the legislation-everybody gets into a panic and says: "Oh, but the charter, the charter". Well, in section 1, as far as I know, the charter provides that when reasonable-and I stand corrected if I am mistaken, because it is late, it is already 10:45-section 1 or 2 and section 3 deal with freedom of expression but only within reasonable limits. I think it is an extraordinary piece of legislation that we should watch like the apple of your eye, as they say, because it is good law. We must not let people from outside come and contaminate a good political system, a good elections act. We are going to update it. We are going to give the franchise to people who are a little farther away than Canada. We listened. We are very much aware of the judgments of the various courts.
I do regret that in one instance in 1984 we did not appeal. It was a judgment handed down by a judge of Queen's Bench of Alberta. We did not appeal and my government was in power. I have never been a member of cabinet, but just to show I am not partisan it was an election campaign and the Liberals were in power. This wasn't being partisan, it was a fact.
We did not appeal. I am convinced that if we had appealed, we would have won. We must preserve this political system and ensure, as the motion says, that third parties are also restricted. I am not in favour of eliminating them totally because they are Canadian citizens- they have to be Canadian citizens-but there has to be a very reasonable limit which can be controlled. If we control the expenses of candidates and members, then we should also control what third parties do.

speakeroldname: Mr. Michel Champagne (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Forestry):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Forestry
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would also like to take a few moments to discuss the motion tabled by my colleague from Churchill and support the comments made by several of my colleagues who spoke on the

December 2, 1992
Private Members' Business
motion from the member of the New Democratic Party. I believe the hon. member for Saint-Denis made quite a remarkable speech on the issue of third-party advertising during elections. I know, after two election campaigns, that the expenses of candidates and political parties are very much controlled. They are controlled to the point that if someone breaks the rules, action can be taken and it can even lead to criminal charges.
I believe that within the electoral reform committee, on which the three main parties in this House are represented, we agreed to discuss this issue. I also think given the situation and the seriousness of the action that could be taken if the limits imposed on the election expenses of candidates and political parties were not respected, this reform should also apply to third parties. At least we should look at it very carefully, because the legitimate right to vote is granted to everybody, at least those allowed to vote under the Canada Elections Act.
Legitimacy or freedom of speech must also take into account the fact that we must not exert undue influence on the debate or the electorate. We saw that during the last electoral campaigns and also during certain activities, where such an influence may have produced what I would call a negative impact because of that attitude toward people and the ability to spend over and above what is prescribed by our legislation. Even if some courts have ruled that this issue could be unconstitutional because of freedom of speech, I believe the Lortie Commission was very wise in presenting its position and in restricting, up to a point, the amounts that third parties may spend on advertising.
In any case, 1 would like to remind my hon. friends from the other parties that we are examining this issue very closely. I hope the report we table in the House will deal at least with one aspect of the question raised by my colleague, the member for Churchill, in order to bring about some form of control. If we impose some form of control on candidates and political parties I cannot imagine what principle could keep us from imposing one on third parties who pay for advertising. If freedom of speech applies in their case, it must also apply in ours. If political, economical or even criminal restrictions exist for candidates and political parties-because criminal action could be brought against us, the present legislation says so-I cannot fathom logically, and I am not speaking from a partisan standpoint, why a third party
could accomplish indirectly what legislation forbids me from doing directly.
That is the fundamental debate in our committee. We are not working from a partisan point of view, our discussions rise well above such things. As members of the Special Committee on electoral reform we hope we can reach a solution which will respect freedom of speech and each Canadian's freedom to express his or her opinion through the candidates, political parties or even advertisements, and which will ensure that each and every one of us is equal, and has an equal right to chose the government. That is fundamental to our legislation. We hope that solution will also ensure we all have equal opportunity to use advertising because advertising will certainly have a more profitable impact if it is better controlled.

Mr. Speaker, I am delighted with this opportunity to speak to this particular subject.

Third party financing, a motion proposed by the member for Churchill touches a fundamental problem of third party intervention in the election process of members.
There are members of the Special Committee on Electoral Reform here, the chairman was here, the vice-chairman was here and other members of the committee are here. This committee has met on 19 occasions since November 20. On 19 occasions the Special Committee on Electoral Reform has met and only on four occasions has that committee had public hearings. The other meetings were in camera.
No, we were drafting.

I am surprised that there is no input from the public. The public is not able to attend those meetings. I had hoped that this Parliament had learned something from the referendum process that took place here in Canada. The public stated clearly to the members that it did not believe in government from above but in government from the bottom.
This committee has not listened to what the referendum told it. The people who voted in the referendum believed we have to listen to the people. As we are
December 2, 1992

talking about third party financing, this is what really happened. In that referendum the elites, the three parties sitting in this House, all the opposition parties across the provinces, the provincial governments, the newspaper elite and the business elite were all on one side. They were on the yes side on the Charlottetown agreement.
On the other side were the ordinary people. Those ordinary people did not have any financing.
There are more of them.

There were only 14 no committees across Canada. There were over 60 yes committees, and all the money was on the yes sid.
This example shows that money cannot always buy votes. This is the best example we have had in Canada. If the Charlottetown agreement had been a good agreement I am sure it would have passed. It did not pass on its merit. People read the agreement, disagreed, and voted against it in different provinces for different reasons, but they voted against it.
When we talk about third party financing we can see that money is not always the most important factor. What is important is that we have laws that are to the benefit of Canada and candidates who want to work for the benefit of Canada, and I am sure they would get elected. However, what we have been seeing lately, even in this House, is that candidates are being appointed by the leaders. I do not call that democracy.
This is another intervention of our party system. If the leader wants to appoint candidates then we should have a presidential system. The leader should run on a separate ticket and be elected as a president, and then he can appoint his cabinet. There are members here who have been sitting in this House for over 27 years and have never made it to the cabinet. For what reason? For different reasons, not because they were not competent-they are probably much more competent than anybody else-but because they were independent in their thinking.
Private Members' Business
Our system, and this should be addressed by the Special Committee on Electoral Reform, wants members to be the trained seals who just vote as the party dictates.
I sat on the other side of this House and I remember when the Minister of Finance predicted we would have a balanced budget in a couple of years. What is the result now? We have over $500 billion of national debt, just at the federal level.
We should be doing third party financing, as the member for Saint-Denis said. I think I agree with him on that. In Canada we have a system that allows for members to get elected without a lot of financing. For instance, I spent less than the two candidates for the other parties, the Liberal Party and the NDP and I had the most votes. This limit on third party financing is probably very good in certain circumstances.
A United States congressman, once elected, has to go back to another election in two years. He spends all year trying to get financing for his next campaign and sometimes it goes into millions and millions of dollars. Therefore he belongs to those who finance him. I think our system of financing for candidates is probably a valid one.
On the other hand there is the question of free expression. Somebody mentioned that a court decision in Alberta said third party financing should be allowed. At that time nobody appealed that decision. We had three parties, so it means they all agreed.
That was during the election. We did not have time.
I presume they all agreed to have third party financing. As I said in the beginning, the committee sits in camera and I have the list of those meetings in camera-

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we in Canada today are in the worst recession we have had since the Great Depression. How did we get here? This is the government that riding a great boom and growth in our economy after 1984 gave us the free trade agreement. At the same time it gave us a high tax, high dollar, high interest rate policy which made it impossible for Canadians to compete. We can see the results.
Today unemployment is at 11.3 per cent. Canada is being deindustrialized. Over the past four years we have lost 375,000, or 18 per cent of our manufacturing jobs.
The government opposite tells us that times are tough all over. If times are tough all over why have the Americans not lost 18 per cent of their manufacturing jobs as we have? They have lost 8 per cent. Things are not as bad down there because they have managed their economy better than has this Tory government.
We see the deindustrialization and unemployment, food banks, people on welfare and over a million Canadian children living in poverty. What is even worse for our future is that we have slipped in the past year from fifth to eleventh in terms of our ability to compete among the industrialized nations. Our high tech deficit in goods traded is a staggering $15 billion, a further symptom of our inability to compete. Our balance of payments deficit, the deficit we have with other countries, what they are taking out of Canada as opposed to what we are giving them, is a staggering $30 billion. All of this is a sign of a very sick, weak economy.
I give the government credit. I think it is finally starting to realize that it could not stay the course, that its economic policies have been a disaster for our country. What did it do? To give it credit it made some modest moves to try to recognize some of the problems that exist.
In terms of unemployment it said: "We have a plan to get unemployment down to 11 per cent over two years from 11.3 per cent today". It is going to create 5,000 new jobs through its infrastructure programs. These are small expenditures, politically motivated, that will create only half the jobs that Canadian National this week announced it was going to lay off.
The government announced some expenditures in R and D. We were told by the World Economic Forum that our research and development, which is falling is less than half of world standards. No wonder it said we cannot compete. What has this government done? It has finally, having paid lip service to R and D over all these years, said it will spend $400 million more on R and D over the next five years. A pittance. It will hardly boost our rate of R and D by 0.1 per cent.
I give it credit because it has finally recognized that it is not just big business, the big foreign multinationals, that is important. It has finally started to recognize small business and has made some modest moves here-too late. They are not very significant moves but it has at least finally paid lip service to small business.
What it did not deal with in this economic statement were some of the real fundamentals. It made no great commitment to higher levels of education, more people taking science or more people training in the technologies. It did not make a brand new commitment to give us a scientific culture here in Canada. It did not deal with the complex problem of how to get companies into the areas of high tech in which our deficit is growing every year under them. Did they deal with the 30 per cent of our students who drop out of high schools? Did they deal with the 20 per cent of Canadians who are functionally illiterate or the 40 per cent who do not know enough mathematics to get by?
At best, the Conservatives are starting to recognize some of the problems. Their approaches have been nothing but minimalist in dealing with them. They did not tell us where the people who are unemployed today are going to get their jobs tomorrow. They did not tell us where our children are going to find gainful employment here in Canada five and ten years from now. They did not give us a vision of how Canada, as a high wage, resource rich country is going to be able to compete for
December 2, 1992

the value added jobs with low wage countries such as the southern United States and Mexico.
The Conservatives have their heads in the sand. They did not deal with the industries of the future that globally we know are so critical to giving Canadians the high incomes we need in order to sustain our way of life. They did not deal here with a vision for environmental technologies, new materials, bio-technologies, the new medical sciences, communications, transport or aerospace. They did not tell us they are trying to have this country more and more dominated by foreign multinationals which have their best jobs in their foreign headquarters.
This government refuses to support and wants to kill our generic drug industry. The generic drug industry is one of the fastest rising, Canadian based multinationals, value added, profits, jobs here in Canada with the profits being reinvested here. Canadian based multinationals are the types of industries we should be supporting.
With Bill C-91 this government not only wants to impose a tremendous new increase in costs for drugs on Canadians, but it wants to drive this burgeoning new set of industries out of Canada.
This government has tried to stay the course, the Reagan course, but it has not been able to. The evidence is finally overwhelming that its policies have not been working. Therefore, the recognition of its failure is in this mini budget. It has said it has to change the course. It has to do some other things. However, why did it not have the courage to admit how bad things really are? Why did it not have the courage to bite the bullet and make sure that it was going to be investing in the things today that will produce those jobs tomorrow and 10 years from now?
The Conservatives did not have the intellectual integrity or vision to know what was needed. It is very disappointing that this government has had to wait until the eve of an election in order to finally recognize what it is doing to the hopes and aspirations of so many unemployed Canadians, so many young Canadians who are in school but see no jobs waiting for them out there,
Government Orders
so many people who say: "I now believe that it will be impossible for my children to enjoy the things that we have enjoyed during our lives".
This is frightening because we as a country have more potential than any other in the world. We have resources. They alone cannot create wealth but were we good stewards of what we have received from the land, and the water around us? We would be able to transform those goods into value added products that we could be selling on world markets. It requires vision. It requires investment. It requires the best trained people in the world. We cannot be content to give our raw materials, as we have in the past, to other countries and buy back the finished goods, exporting our jobs with them.
We are going to have to transform our economy. This government has not had the courage to do it. It has not had the wisdom to do it. It is a tired government that can only respond. It cannot lead.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I wanted to ask the hon. member a question. He listened, I think, with attention today to the economic and fiscal statement delivered by the Minister of Finance and he probably made a judgment call which I am sure is not very favourable.
I look at the departments of the federal government and see that National Revenue employs over 34,000 individuals. I remember when we were debating the GST the government said it was going to create more exports, it would be easier on the consumer and so on and so forth. Since that time we have lost about half a million manufacturing jobs and the federal government had to hire about 4,000 employees.

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
My question is, if his party was elected as the government, how would he deal with the GST? Would his party continue that process, or as it has created havoc in the country, would his party take another approach?

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the GST has been a real disappointment to this government. It thought the GST was going to be the salvation of our competitiveness.
Yes, it has helped the manufacturers to a certain extent in their exporting but the manufacturers have been losing jobs hand over fist at more than twice the rate of the Americans.
Has it really helped our manufacturers that much? What has it done to small business? The costs of implementing this tax to the private sector alone were estimated by the Canadian Federation of Independent Business to be $9.5 billion. That was more than half of what the government expected to take in from the GST in the first year.
Then we have conflicting statements from this government about the GST. It said the GST was going to be as real revenue-raiser and we needed it in order to increase our revenues and get the deficit down. What did the government find out? Sadly the Minister of Finance had to admit today in his statement that the GST has not produced more revenues than the previous manufacturers' sales tax. This is a tax which in theory may be okay in certain ways, but it is highly regressive so it really penalizes the poor people. Is that okay? I am not sure it is. It told us we needed a VAT, a value added tax, because many other countries had it. Except our major competitor, the United States, does not have it. How stupid can it be? Why is there so much more cross-border shopping?

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, all Quebecers are trying tonight to assess the finance minister's economic statement and are wondering whether the decisions announced today can help get the economy out of the deep recession we are in and create jobs for our hundreds of thousands of unemployed people.
Because the recession is so long, we know the unemployed have lost confidence, consumers have lost confidence and investors have lost confidence. The finance minister's statement should therefore have tried to restore confidence among all these participants in the economy.
Now what do we find in the finance minister's economic and fiscal statement? Instead of decisions to restore confidence, we find a savage attack on the unemployed, an insignificant increase in job creating investments and a deficit for next year that is $10 billion more than forecast. To add insult to injury, the Minister of Finance takes pride in an inflation fighting monetary policy that has led us to the economic disaster we know.
Mr. Speaker, in the space of a few minutes, the Minister of Finance has managed to dismay workers, consumers and the unemployed, increase the mistrust of investors and financial markets and convince everyone that he is completely abdicating his fundamental role of helping the economic recovery.
Let us look at the measures for the unemployed. The minister announced $2.45 billion over two years in cuts to unemployment benefits and gave back $600 million in training, for a net cut of $1.85 billion. Clearly, the government is attacking the unemployed rather than unemployment.
What about the promised investment in infrastructure which the Prime Minister announced at fund raising dinners of the Progressive Conservative Party in recent weeks? Well, these promises only lasted as long as it took to help sell tickets at $500 a plate. After hinting at investments of $24 billion, then $12 billion, today they tell us that $485 million will be invested in infrastructure over two years. This is a completely marginal effort that will have no impact on employment and lets the deterioration of our infrastructure continue.
Let us look at the deficit forecasts. There the Minister of Finance loses all his remaining credibility. Nine months ago, on February 25, 1992, the Minister of Finance announced that the deficit for 1991-92-and there was only one month to go, since that year ended in March 1992-would be $31.4 billion. Now, after all the bills are in, we are told that the actual deficit is $34.5 billion; it was off $3.1 billion with a month to go. That's not all. For the current year, the Minister of Finance announced a $27.5 billion deficit and now nine months later we are told that the forecast has changed; it is $34.4 billion, a difference of almost $7 billion in nine months.
December 2, 1992

But hold on. For next year, he had announced a $22.5-billion deficit. Today, he just told us his current forecast, which is not the last, is $32.6 billion; a $10 billion error in nine months. If the vice-president of finance of any private company-and the government always talks to us about private enterprise-had such a forecasting record, he would be thrown out before he finished his speech. That is obvious. In less than a year, this Minister of Finance has lost all credibility, although this credibility is essential to stabilize the Canadian dollar and bring about lower interest rates, which are the best thing for economic recovery.
This government has missed a great chance to restore the confidence of the unemployed, the consumers and the investors because of its lack of courage and imagination. For instance, it has decided to freeze all salaries and cut operating expenses by 5 percent in all departments. As such, it is not a tragedy but it goes to show how inept it is at making choices. It has made $385 million-worth of cuts in national defence when nothing threatens our security any more. That is ridiculous. It would be possible to cut $3, $4 or even $5 billions in DND.
How do you expect the people of Quebec to see that we are going through difficult times economically when the government of Canada just had an embassy built in Japan on a piece of land worth over $1 billion? We spend to show off while cutting back on unemployment benefits.
Let us look at the restructuring of the Public Service and the departments. This a hot topic these days. We know that the Belanger-Campeau commission estimated at about $3 billion the cost of duplication between departments and ministries in Ottawa and Quebec. We were met with a blunt refusal here in Ottawa. It was out of the question to do away with duplication. Just in labour costs, savings would be in the order of $300 millions.
Government Orders
This government's inability to make choices is obvious. It would much rather cut an even 2 or 3 per cent across the line in the estimates. As I said, it is not a tragedy as such. There are so many people out of work that we take the cuts. However, with a minimum of political guts many more billions of dollars that are no longer spent usefully in some areas could have been saved.
Our only source of comfort is to think that this government has only a few month to go. In fact, before long, the electorate will decide. As far as the people of Quebec are concerned, I am sure they will go for a thorough restructuring of their relationship with the Canadian government. There is no doubt about it, the price of Canadian federalism is too high indeed.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to speak on the financial statement which the Minister of Finance presented today. I am pleased that the minister is one of the few of us in the House at this hour of the night. Hopefully he is listening carefully to what the representatives from the different parts of Canada have to say.
In spite of the fact that he is in attendance and in spite of my respect for the minister, his statement today can only be described as a bit of a joke and a financial hoax. If I did not see him fully clothed, I would say it reminds me of the old tale of the emperor having no clothes, with the exception of a little fig leaf which I will come to later.
The reason I say that is the two fundamental questions we are dealing with, unemployment and the deficit, are not addressed in this paper in any kind of fundamental way. When we look at what is projected, in 1994 we will still have 11 per cent unemployment, the same level we have today, and we will have a $32 billion deficit, $10 billion more than what was projected in the minister's estimates just last February.
Somehow he has been able to ignore the fact that there are 1.6 million unemployed people. Those statistics are not just numbers. They represent real misery and real people. There are 2.5 million people on welfare experiencing the indignity of having to live on handouts

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
from the state when they would like to make a living. There are 4 million in poverty in this rich country, 1 million of whom are children.
Certainly it does not reflect the need that I see in my constituency of Prince Albert-Churchill River. In many of the northern communities we have 70 per cent to 80 per cent unemployment. We have a farm community that is sinking to the abyss. We have more farmers who are over 70 than under 30, an appalling statistic when we look at the future of that industry. Even in the city of Prince Albert, a relatively wealthy city, there are a great number of professional, well educated people, who have done everything right in their lives but cannot find work.
What does the minister persist in talking about? He keeps talking about the fundamentals. What are the fundamentals? Surely one is being able to pay the bills, and cover the debts. Ever since the Liberals introduced a budget in this House in 1974 that started giving tax breaks to the wealthy to the extent that the government was no longer able to pay its debts, its bills, we have seen a constant erosion of the financial situation of this country to the point where today the debt is indeed crippling and something we have to deal with. It is something that in eight years this government has not been able to come to terms with.
Surely another one of the fundamentals is stability so that people can know from one day to the next, from one year to the next, from one generation to the next what their lives are going to be like, what kind of circumstances they will live in.
Looking at my occupation of agriculture, do we see stability or any move toward stability? No, we do not. We have seen the trade wars, the bankruptcies and the loss of hope. What do we see at a time when we need stability? We see this government introducing measures to do away with the Crow rate, the fundamental transportation structure of this country, particularly in western Canada.
We see the government further undermining the Canadian Wheat Board by threatening to take barley out from under its jurisdiction. When it comes to the country at large, we see the free trade kind of philosophy, the NAFTA agreement and the patent drug act, all of which cause more instability in the lives of people.
Surely there is nothing more fundamentally important than a job, nothing more fundamental than the ability of an economy to be able to accommodate the needs and
wishes of people to be able to earn their living, to pay for the food on their table, the roof over their heads, their clothes and their kids' education. Surely that is the fundamental that we should all be striving for, but it is one which this government has lost sight of.
What did we see in this statement? Did we see tax fairness? No, we did not. We see a continuation of those big loopholes that the Auditor General pointed out such as family trusts that allow wealthy families in this country to concentrate ever more wealth in their own hands to the point where this country has the greatest concentration of wealth in the world.
We see the offshore tax havens continue. We see loopholes like the entertainment tax credit which costs us $2 billion a year continue. We see in this statement that revenues are short. It is not surprising when so many people are unemployed, not paying taxes and absorbing services from the government. Certainly it is no surprise that revenues are going to be short. The government should have known that.
In my own constituency the welfare and unemployment bill amounts to $126 million a year, an appalling statistic. Surely that is where the waste of money is as well as the shortfall in revenues. We see a continuation of expenditures like the $4.4 billion on helicopters that cannot land on the boats they are designed for and cannot carry out the auxiliary functions that people had hoped they would.
What have we seen to deal with unemployment? We had great promise of an infrastructure program. I must say that the Minister of Finance and his officials have laboured mightily and produced a mouse. There is very little there for any part of the country, but the further west you go the less there is. When you get to western Canada you get a few roads and the national parks.
The minister talks about UI reform. Rather than putting people back to work in new and creative ways, what do we see? We see a situation where people who quit their jobs are not going to be eligible for unemployment insurance, no matter under what circumstances they quit.
In an era where sexual harassment on the job site, unsafe working conditions and so on are at the top of the agenda, people who respond to that will be told: "Sorry, you are out of luck. You did the wrong thing, there is nothing for you". We see cuts in programs that could lead to value added production, that could lead to
December 2, 1992

investment in new industries like Western Diversification and the green plan.
In the two minutes I have left I would like to spend one minute dealing with the fig leaf, the incentive that we see for investment in small business which is, after all, the major job creator in this country. The changes to the Small Businesses Loans Act, the unemployment insurance holiday, the 10 per cent tax credit are all matters which I think members would generally applaud.
Personally, as the critic for co-operative and community development, I would congratulate the minister for finally taking some action with regard to the unfair treatment that co-ops often experience by making it possible for people forming worker co-ops or other kinds of co-operatives to be able to use RRSP money or RRIF money in order to stimulate co-operative investment. This is a long overdue measure and I congratulate the minister on it.
What could the government have done? It could have brought in some real tax reform. It could have instituted a national investment fund to create value added opportunities, to invest in the knowledge industries, the industries of the future. It could have invested in the economic infrastructure by empowering communities through community economic development corporations, economic development authorities and other institutions like that to take their economic destiny into their own hands in a very low cost effective kind of way. We have not seen that.
What we have seen instead apart from the fig leaf is more GST, more free trade and more of the corporate agenda. With all due respect, Mr. Speaker, I think this is an indication, and I say that somewhat sadly, that at a time when we need creative government action, we have a government that seems to be politically bankrupt in many ways and morally bankrupt. I think when we look at the direction that this paper takes us, it is also intellectually bankrupt.
Canadians are looking for change. This was an opportunity to create some real change, but it was not taken. Therefore, I must submit that we will not see the kind of change Canadians are looking for until we see an
Government Orders
election, until we see a change in government, until we see a change in the fundamental direction in which this country is going so that once again Canadians can be proud to earn a living in their own country.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Christmas season is fast approaching. It is the time when we think of sharing some happy times with family and friends, sharing the bounties of the work that we have done throughout the year and enjoying the fruits of our labour.
This statement today reminds me of a Christmas story that I have heard since I was a little girl. I think it bears repeating here. It symbolizes the trickle-down economics that this government continues to believe in, that continues to enrich those who have the most and impoverish those who have the least.
It is the story of The Little Match Girl, who on a freezing Christmas Eve stood outside the rich people's house and looked inside at the fire in the fireplace, the decorations on the Christmas tree, the toys under the Christmas tree, the big fat turkey on the table, the people in all their finery and hoped just that they might come outside and pay a penny for her matches. As she stood there and waited for the rich people to come out and pay a penny for her matches, she started lighting her matches to keep her hands from freezing. Before they were finished their dinner she had burned up all her matches. Before Christmas Eve was over she had frozen to death in the snow.
This is trickle-down economics. Those who have the least get the least and get poorer and those who have the most get the most and get richer. The principle was repeated here in the minister's statement this afternoon. Those who can compete will prosper; those who cannot will stagnate.
We have a continuation of the policies that have impoverished 3.6 million Canadians, including one million children. We had a proud statement by the minister this afternoon that we will continue to invest in policies to make our economy work better.
This government has brought us the made-in-Canada recession and is telling us that its policies have made this economy work better. Tell that to 1.6 million Canadians

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
who are out of work. Tell that to the children who line up at food banks every day in this country.
We will continue to invest in sound monetary and fiscal policies. I do not think there is anybody but the handful of people on the other side of this House who pretend to govern this country, who believe that their monetary and fiscal policies have been sound. Certainly, it is not the people in this country who wonder if they have a job today or whether they will have a job tomorrow.
This is about scraps from the table of the rich, hopefully falling down and allowing the poor to eat. What we need is economic recovery from the ground up. Even in this, the national capital, one of the wealthiest communities in this country, we have 100,000 people on some form of public assistance or unemployment insurance. That is what is costing us $22,000 for every unemployed person in this country. Right here in the nation's capital, on the Ontario side of the capital, we have welfare up by nearly 25 per cent in the last 12 months.
We have a plan here that is not going to solve the problems of people who wonder whether they are going to have a roof over their head and a meal on the table a month from now. We have a plan here that continues the mistakes of the past, that repeats the unfulfilled promises of eight consecutive budgets that we will reduce the debt and reduce the deficit. What do we have? A steadily rising debt and a steadily rising deficit.
We have an infrastucture program here that is going to invest again in short-term make-work projects. There is no vision of investing in an infrastructure that is going to strengthen the economy of this country in the long term.
The Minister of Supply and Services sits over there. Small towns in his community cannot expand economically because they are under an environmental order not to add any further development. They have wooden sewers that go back into the last century and are not safe or sanitary. Do I see anything in here about improving the water supply for Canadians, treating the water supply of Canadians to stop polluting our rivers, lakes and oceans? Not at all. The rhetoric of Rio that came so freely from the Prime Minister's mouth less than six months ago is totally lost in our commitment of creating
jobs. We see an even further cut from what has already been done in this year's budget to the green plan.
Then we turn around and we see that we paid $22 billion last year in interest to foreign lenders. That is only the tip of the iceberg. That $22 billion at a 50 per cent tax rate means $11 billion in lost tax revenue. One-third of this year's deficit is being lost because this government has not figured out how to get Canadians to invest in their own country and their own future, how to keep that money in Canada that we are paying out in interest to the tune of $22 billion a year, and how to collect income taxes on that income in Canada rather than allow foreign countries to collect income tax on money that we are paying out of the pockets of Canadian taxpayers.
I note with irony a statement on page 11 of the minister's Economic and Fiscal Statement this afternoon indicating that the more we can leave in people's pockets the better it will be for our economy. If the government truly believes that leaving money in people's pockets and letting people purchase goods and services that produce jobs for other Canadians is good economic policy then why is it as the largest single employer in the country, with the largest single work force, insisting on cutting the purchasing power of its own employees and insisting on further reducing jobs when it is time to encourage the private sector to create jobs?
We have a double-whammy of three years of no job increases for tens of thousands of people who are earning incomes below the poverty level working for the Government of Canada. How are they going to pay for food, clothes and education for their children?
We had cutbacks in government spending in the budget this year. We had another 2 per cent cutback in June. Now we have a 2 per cent cutback in the last quarter which is equivalent to an 8 per cent cutback in services to the public. We heard two things from Canadians during the referendum campaign. The first was to stop fiddling with the Constitution and get back to fixing the economy and the major problems that confront this country. The second thing was that they wanted a strong federal government capable of taking leadership, building partnerships and solving the problems of this country. What do we have now? We have a government that is destroying the ability of the Government of Canada to govern on behalf of Canadians.
December 2, 1992

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we know that we are in a transition period from one type of economy relying on heavy industry and the exploitation of natural resources to another based on knowledge, information, high technologies and services. We know this and what we are saying to Canadians in this debate is that we would do much better in using the levers of government. We would not be obsessed with deficit cutting as the government is because first we would want to look after the social fabric of Canada. We would want to kick-start economic growth in partnership, if you like, with the provinces, municipalities, labour and business. We would probably pay attention to water quality. We would pay attention to sewage treatment plants.
We would engage resources in pollution prevention, in the rehabilitation of our rivers and the removal of health-endangering chemicals. That is where we would hopefully put our taxpayers' resources and not in megaprojects, such as tar sands or the construction of a link to Prince Edward Island. That is a very costly and divisive project. Water is a very precious resource and is badly neglected. Water would receive attention at this time by an enlightened government.
Let me tell you what we would not do. We would not fight unemployment on the backs of the unemployed by reducing benefits as the government announced it would. Believe me, it is no fun to be without income for the first two weeks and then have to make ends meet on 60 per cent of one's previous income. To reduce unemployment insurance benefits below 60 per cent is really a disgrace. If that was not bad enough, this government now wants to penalize those who quit their employment by depriving them entirely of their benefits, whether they qualified with contributions or not.
This afternoon I was shocked to see the Prime Minister applaud when the finance minister announced this measure. 1 was almost embarrassed. I asked myself whether the Prime Minister realized what he was doing when this measure was announced. This measure gives the employer greater power than ever. It makes it virtually impossible for the employee to quit if the employee is harassed, sexually or otherwise, in the workplace or decides that the workplace has become unsafe.
Government Orders
Through these measures we see the ugly face of the Conservative government. We see its heartless face that is taking away from the weak in the name of cutting the deficit. What a shame.
I will move on to the freeze on the income of parliamentarians. It seems rather curious that this is being done without looking at the size of cabinet. Why stop at parliamentarians? Would anyone in Canada have suffered if cabinet had been cut by 25 per cent, or even 50 per cent? Would anyone have noticed?
Would any Canadian have noticed the disappearance of eminent ministers such as the minister of multicultur-alism, the minister of forests, the minister for constitutional affairs-who disappeared anyway from the political map after October 26-the minister of state for the environment, the minister of state for financial affairs. These are just a few.
It seems rather peculiar that this government would find the courage to inflict penalties on the unemployed but not on cabinet itself.
It seems to me that this government is retreating from governing. It is not rebuilding the economy of this country. It has axed the Economic Council of Canada, the Science Council of Canada, the Law Reform Commission, and the Institute for International Peace and Security. It has eliminated the Court Challenges Program. You name it.
In addition to that wilful action, in the private sector every day there are plant closures and people laid off by the hundreds. The social and economic costs of these lay-offs are immense, yet there are no adjustment programs.
There is no improvement in the direction for those who are laid off. There are no initiatives for those searching for their first job, for instance. There are no extensions of benefits for those who are running out of unemployment insurance benefits, thus increasing the tax burden on municipalities.
What a hard-nosed, heartless way of governing, certainly not in the name of social fairness but in the name of cutting deficits.
If this government were guided by social fairness principles, then it would have wanted, with this measure today, to close the many tax loopholes identified by the Auditor General in his report. Or it would have imposed a tax increase on those making, say, more than $50,000 a year. Or it would have eliminated some of the major tax privileges such as tax-free expense accounts. You name

December 2, 1992
Government Orders
it. We know and I am sure the Minister of Finance knows where to find his lost sources of revenue.
To attack the unemployed and introduce these measures really is offensive. It is very sad because it is not in the political tradition and culture of Canada in difficult times to go after the weaker elements in society. This has not been our tradition so far. I regret that.
I would have thought that in this particular time the Government of Canada would have removed this illusive pursuit of reducing the deficit, which has plagued this government and preceding governments.
At this time with high unemployment and large numbers of people on welfare, I thought it would have decided that this was the time to move by giving priority to the social fabric of the nation, to the cohesion of our communities where high unemployment has such a devastating effect. We are not giving the individual that sense of dignity, not giving Canadians in large and small communities that sense of dignity that is so badly sought in difficult times. Our youth is crying for attention in terms of their first employment. Our middle aged workforce is going through a crisis at the very moment that it is without employment. Our elderly workers are very dissatisfied with early retirement adjustment programs and tonight they have very little to be happy about, very little. We are very distressed.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is with pleasure that I talk about this economic and fiscal statement of the Minister of Finance.
He certainly does not have an easy task. He has been appointed Minister of Finance when things are really bad so we cannot blame him personally for what is happening to this country.
As Minister of Transport, when I was still on the other side, the minister was hard working and certainly competent within this sphere.
What has happened? He has been appointed Minister of Finance and given the task to defend the previous eight years of this government. He has not addressed the fundamental problems of why in Canada we have a creeping problem of bad forecasting by the Minister of
Finance. I would like to quote Jeffrey Simpson of The Globe and Mail on December 2 in an editorial: "It is a new singer but it is the same old song, the Red Ink Blues".
It is true. Every finance minister since the early 1970s has been making forecasts but always the wrong forecasts. The Minister of Fisheries and Oceans when he was finance minister in 1979 said that by 1985 the national annual deficit would drop to $2.1 billion, but in reality in 1985 we had a deficit of $34 billion.
Alan MacEachen said, when he became Minister of Finance in the year 1983-1984, that because of his administration the deficit would be only $7.5 billion. In reality, in the year 1983-1984 the deficit was $32 billion.
The same thing happened with Marc Lalonde, another Minister of Finance.
We know the story of the former Minister of Finance, presently the industry minister. I remember when I was in caucus and he presented his first budget, he said that after four years of his administration there would not be a deficit.
I asked him a question. I said: "Mr. Wilson, Mr. Crosbie had made predictions. Mr. MacEachen had made predictions, and you are making predictions. How can you be that sure you are going to be different?"
As I said in the beginning, we do not address the fundamental problems of the taxation system in Canada. We reward that formation but we do not reward capital formation.
This is why we read in today's edition of The Ottawa Citizen that the Royal Bank said that 67 per cent of its loans were not performing. This means that they are not paying what is due to the bank, and this is $3.5 billion. Of that Olympia & York and Bramalea alone owe to the Royal Bank $780 million. Those companies are bankrupt.
Who is going to pay for that? It is you, Mr. Speaker. It is other members. It is the small person, the middle class, the worker who puts a little bit of money in the bank. The bank raises interest rates and makes money to pay for Olympia & York, Bramalea and others that have borrowed and spent money outside this country buying properties in the United States and building in London, England. Our taxpayers have to pay for those mistakes.
December 2, 1992

The fundamental problems have not been addressed to reward capital formation. If companies are badly run we reward them. We reward them: they can borrow money. They can borrow money from the banks and money from the state. We give grants, but there is no reward for people who really work hard.
We are always talking about Japan, Hong Kong and Taiwan. In Taiwan the maximum tax is 16 per cent. That is a flat tax, whether one makes $1 million or $100 million, with no exemptions. Its corporations have to pay taxes like everybody. In our system the individual pays most of the taxes. Our government collects personal taxes and very little corporate taxes. Corporations are always exempted. They do not have to pay and they should be paying.
As time goes by I would like to say that the Minister of Finance in his statement does not resolve Canada's
Government Orders
problems. He has been wrong in his forecasting. He was telling us six or seven months ago that we were not going into a recession. He could not even pronounce the word recession. After a while he said: "Yes, we are moving into a recession".
Today we are in a depression. Canada has lost 500,000 manufacturing jobs; jobs that have moved and will never come back to Canada. The government brings in the free trade agreement and now NAFTA, the North-American free trade agreement, that is going to siphon away jobs from Canada. This is not acceptable to Canadians.
